charity.description:
Cool Earth is a unique rainforest charity that works alongside indigenous communities to protect the world's most endangered rainforest. 

Every donation makes the biggest possible difference with over 90p of every £1 donated going directly to our partnership projects.
charity.name: Cool Earth
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Welcome to our Mongol Rally 2018 page in support of CoolEarth.

As you know, we will be grabbing life by the balls this summer and driving from Lincoln to Mongolia in a 1 litre car that would struggle to get your gran to the supermarket, let alone through Asia and onto the Mongolian "roads".

This is all in aid of fun, mindlessness and most importantly raising money for CoolEarth. Reasons to support CoolEarth;

"Half of the world’s rainforest has been destroyed in the last 40 years.  And, contrary to the headlines, rainforest continues to be lost at a faster rate than ever. But it’s not too late. Cool Earth believes the rainforest can be saved. We just need a new approach.

That’s why we don’t create reserves or put up fences. We don’t buy land. Instead, we put local people back in control of their forest.

Local people stand to lose the most from deforestation but the most to gain from its protection. As such, they are the forest’s best possible custodians. That’s why all Cool Earth partnerships are community-owned and led – an approach that research is continually proving to be the most effective way to keep rainforest standing.

By developing local livelihoods, our mission is to end the cycle of deforestation entrenching villages into further poverty. Creating strong, self-determining communities – not dependency.

We are also the only charity that works solely where the threat to the forest is greatest, on the frontline of deforestation. And each of our partnerships forms a shield to make the neighbouring forest inaccessible to loggers – saving millions of acres of further forest" 

You can find out more about CoolEarth here: https://www.coolearth.org/

story:
Rainforest is only safe when there is a village strong enough to protect it.  Cool Earth partners with rainforest communities to improve quality of life, this enables them to protect their surrounding forests from threats such as commercial logging, commercial agriculture and extractive industries.  

Cool Earth works in all three rainforest biomes - the Congo Basin, Amazonia and Oceania.  They invest in 3 key areas - Livelihood Support, Forest Health and Community Investments.

story:
An adventure...... 

The Mongol Rally 2018. Driving 10 thousand miles from Lancashire to Mongolia, all to raise money for charity. The journey in our 1.2L shed of a car will take us on motorways, mountains and deserts. Traveling through a minimum of 20 countries with an average speed of 23mph. We hope to get to the finish line within 6 weeks. We are planning on taking the most difficult route through Turkey, Iran, and finally the Pamir Highway (one of the most treacherous roads in the world).

The rules are as follows.......

- old crappy car no bigger than a 1.2 litre

- no back up or help, we're on our own. If we have a problem (breakdown) we have to fix it.

- no GPS, limited maps

- raise at least  £1000 pound for charity 

Mongol Rally Stats since 2004...

- 1300 cars

- 9 is the average number of breakdowns per team

- 6 tyre changes per car

- distance travelled 177 times around the world 

- total charity raised 1.6 million and rising

Thank you so much for visiting our just giving page. We would be so grateful for any donations to our chosen charities.

story:
Having taken leave of our senses, my son Jake & I are driving a tuk tuk from Cochin in south India to Jaisalamer, 2,500km to the North. Our pimped up 7 horse power 'Shaw' sets off on April 1st (Really!) where our support team wave goodbye as we are now on our own for navigation, breakdowns and general survival. With good fortune and good curry our 145cc 'Bhaji out of Hell'  will get us to our destination by April 14th, with maybe a day on the beach in Goa on the way. It would be great if you could help us support our chosen charities (see below) and in return we promise to master technology and show you our progress once we get going to give you a regular laugh at our mishaps and discomfort.

Your sponsorship will be greatly appreciated and will be shared between two charities we would like to support equally: -

The good people of Cool Earth have set about preserving the rain forests of the world amongst other things and get a nod from Sir David to boot, so are good guys doing the right thing for the future of our planet.

Sense supports people with complex communication needs in a world that relies on being able to see and hear well to be connected

Thanks - Dave & Jake

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
We are taking part in the Mongol Rally in order to raise money for our causes, 'Cool Earth' and 'World at Play'. 

The Mongol Rally is a month long motoring adventure with a starting point in London and an End Point in Mongolia. There's not set route between and nothing but ourselves to overcome the problems we encounter in our tiny 1200cc vehicle. Our chosen route is just over 13,000 miles long and involves 24 countries including, the UK, France, Belgium, Germany, the Czech Republic, Austria, Slovakia, Hungary, Croatia, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Montenegro, Albania, Macedonia, Bulgaria, Turkey, Armenia, Georgia, Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Uzbeckistan, Kyrgistan, Russia and finally Mongolia.

This is the donation page for our charity Cool Earth!

Cool Earth is an experimental NGO dedicated to preventing climate change and deforestation by working alongside rainforest communities and putting indigenous people back in control of the forest. The destruction of the rainforest releases huge amounts of greenhouse gases and so Cool Earth's unique efforts will help stop climate change and reinstate the control of the world's rainforests to the local villagers that inhabit them.

See their websites for more info at https://www.coolearth.org/

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

This summer I will be joining a team of 3 as we attempt to drive 10,000 miles across Europe and Asia in a 1997 1.0L Nissan Micra. Why?! To help raise awareness and support for the charity Cool Earth, who aim to work with local communities to put a stop to rainforest destruction. They need your help. I would be most grateful for any donation you feel you could make to this great cause and all the money raised goes straight to the work that Cool Earth are doing across the world

Before going on to explain a bit about why our rainforests are so important, if you would like to keep track of our progress please visit our team's Facebook page and website where we will have a live tracker. 

https://www.facebook.com/themongrols/

http://www.themongrols.com/

----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Over the last 40 years, half the world’s rainforests have been destroyed. Let me give you some information about the impact this has to our planet.

137 rainforest species are completely exterminated every single day. If deforestation continues at the current rate, not even a quarter of the estimated unknown species living in the rainforests will be discovered before they are killed off.

Not only does the rainforest provide habitats for so many species but over a quarter of the medicines we use today have their origins in the rainforests. Who knows what other cures could be out there waiting to be found? 

Deforestation also drives climate change.  Removing trees deprives the forest of portions of its canopy, which blocks the sun’s rays during the day and holds in heat at night. Losing this thermal characteristic of the rainforests causes great variations in the climate and many adverse effects are felt across the Earth.

These are just a small number of reasons why something needs to be done to protect our rainforests. Despite various conservation attempts, an estimated 18 million acres continue to be lost every year, a new approach needs to be taken. This is the reason Cool Earth decided to go about things differently.

Instead of creating reserves, putting up fences or buying land, they put indigenous people back in control of the world’s most endangered rainforest. These people have lived in the forest for countless generations and their homes are now at the front line of the deforestation.

Working alongside 113 rainforest villages throughout the world, Cool Earth aim to build better incomes, better schools and better clinics to give their partner villages the resources they need to keep their forest intact.

With the help of your donation Cool Earth are able to conserve the rainforests, give power back to those who know the rainforest best and work towards putting the destruction of one of the worlds richest ecosystems to a stop.

I hope I have managed to give you a better understanding of why your help is needed to raise awareness about deforestation and how your support can contribute towards saving our much needed rainforests.

Thank you for taking the time to read my story and I would be extremely grateful for any donation. My initial target is £500.

story:
Hello all!

So this summer I decided to get off my backside and start doing something about the global issues I have previously just bellyached about. I have decided to take on the challenge of driving from the UK to Ulan-Ude in Siberia, in a second hand shopping trolley of a car.
To underline the challenge, we will taking a car designed essential for school runs and shopping trips, through mountain passes, desert roads and no roads at all! To top it all off I am still in the process of learning to drive. It is my intention to keep all updated through blogs, pics and vids with goings during the preparations as well as once we hit the road.

story:
I'm running my first ever half marathon at the Hackney Half on 20th May!!! Anyone who ever witnessed me during PE lessons at school will know exertive exercise has never been a passion nor a skill of mine. However after running my first 10k in February I decided to sign up to Hackney Half (seemed like a great idea at the time....)

As its my first ever half I'm running for  "Cool Earth" a fantastic charity who are working to combat tropical deforestation. Over half of the world's rainforests have been lost in the past 40 years which is having a detrimental impact on the earth's ecological systems and fuelling Climate Change. Cool Earth work with local communities to protect our endangered forests and so far have saved nearly 1 million acres of rainforest with over 200m trees. They're endorsed as an effectively alturistic charity by William Macaskill (author of Doing Good Better - great read if you're interested!) and supported by our favourite national treasure Sir David Attenborough so if isn't a sign of endorsement I'm not sure what is! If you want to read more about the charity their site is here https://www.coolearth.org/what-we-do/

Would really appreciate any donations however small to keep me going and support a cause I'm really passionate about. It will also make the inevitable achey legs and red face on the day worth it. Thanks!

story:
Rickshaw Run 2017 - Team Third Wheel

So a few months ago, Dale and Luca came together and decided that they wanted to drive 2000 crazy miles accross India in nothing short of a glorified lawnmower. Aka, The Rickshaw. 

After much discussion and story telling, we made the decision to do it. 

With a little help from Facebook, we found our third team member Holly. 

In August 2017 the three of us will be taking a journey starting at Cochi, South India. This journey we predict will terminate (hopefully) at Jailsmer, India. 

A few extracts taken from the official Rickshaw Run website are as follows:

"A 3,000km Indian adventure in a 7 horsepower glorified lawnmower. The Rickshaw Run is easily the least sensible thing to do with two weeks"

"No set route, no back-up, no way of knowing if you're going to make it. The only certainty is that you will get lost, you will get stuck and you will break down"

"It's just you and your mates in a wholly unsuitable vehicle, traversing the subcontinent enduring whatever s**t the road throws at you"

Effectively we're completely unprepared but ready to take on the challenge. To put it into perspective, last year a single team in one rickshaw broke down in excess of 100 times. Exciting Stuff.

Of course, all of this is for a good cause, two good causes in fact. Whilst we will be tearing accross the Indian subcontinent, tempting fate with delhi belly and sleeping in our roadside tent, we will be raising funds going straight to the following worthy causes:

Cool Earth - https://www.coolearth.org


"Cool Earth is an environmental charity that works in partnership with indigenous communities.

The charity only protects rainforest that without intervention will be destroyed within the next 18 months.

Cool Earth works strategically, protecting forest that acts as a barrier to a wider landscape.

The charity spends just 10% of your donation on admin and governance making sure as much as possible goes to project areas.

Through working with local people Cool Earth makes sure conservation goes hand in hand with better livelihoods".

Great Ormond Street Hospital London - http://www.gosh.org

"Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity raises money to enable the hospital to provide world class care and to pioneer new treatments and cures for childhood illnesses"

"With more than 268,000 patient visits every year, we need your support to help us give hope to our young patients and their families"

Lets talk donations - 
Ideally we're hoping to raise at least a total of £1000 for these great causes. Our hope is to spread this evenly between the two charities listed above and on our team page. We would be extremely grateful if you could spare anything to donate to these causes.

Remember: Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never share them with anyone or send you unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. They'll make sure Gift Aid (an additional 25%) is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer, too. That means more money goes to the charity, faster, with JustGiving.

Signing off -  

Team The Third Wheel

Thethirdwheel2017@gmail.com

Feel free to send us an email if you want to know anything else, or if you wish to sponsor us. :) 

Thanks for visiting.

story:
What better way to spend our hard-earnt holiday, than thundering over 100s of miles of jungle, dirt tracks, coast, mud and sweat all squeezed into half a horsepower of three wheeled wonder? Well, none of course.


The Rickshaw Run is pretty simple. With no preparation and less luggage one flies to the Indian Subcontinent and does one's damndest to force 150cc of Indian engineering over three thousand kilometres of questionable terrain in around two weeks. Starting in Jaisalmer and taking on nearly the entire west coast of India to limp over the finish line in Cochin, this start to the New Year will be awesome!


For more information, please visit:
http://rickshawrun.theadventurists.com/


Raising huge sacks of cash for excellent charities around the world is central to the rally. Each team raises a minimum of £1000 for charity, £500 for Cool Earth and £500 for a charity of our choice, and hopefully many teams go on to raise much more.


Thank you for visiting our fundraising page. Please dig deep and sponsor us online.

Donating through this site is simple, fast and totally secure. It is also the most efficient way to sponsor us: Anthony Nolan will receive your money faster and, if you are a UK taxpayer, an extra 28% in tax will be added to your gift at no cost to you.

So please sponsor us now!

Many thanks for your support.

eventName: The Size of Herefordshire Rainforest Project
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Join Herefordshire’s Battle to Save the Rainforests. Protect the People of the Forests from Loggers and Gold Diggers and Reduce Climate-Changing Carbon Output

We are raising money to protect and sustain an area of tropical rainforest the size of Herefordshire (that's 2,180 square km or 538 689 acres in old money). 

Visit www.sizeofherefordshire.org for more information.

The great tropical rainforests of the Amazon are under attack from loggers, palm oil agri-business, oil and gas explorers - even gold-miners. The indigenous people who have lived in the Amazon rainforest for centuries are seeing the forests, which they depend on for their livelihood and their homes, are seeing destroyed wholesale in front of their eyes.

WHAT CAN YOU DO TO HELP? ONE STEP WOULD BE TO PROTECT AN AREA OF RAINFOREST THE SIZE OF OUR COUNTY.

story:
Myself, Matt & Nathan are undertaking something that's pretty crazy, probably dumb and likely very fun in August 2018; the Rickshaw Run:

A 3,000km Indian adventure in a 7 horsepower glorified lawnmower.

It'll be nothing but ourselves, a Tuk Tuk and a destination! Departing from Jaisalmer in the north we'll have 14 days to reach Cochin in the south, everything (including the route and repairs) will be down to us!

For this adventure we'll be raising money for the Cool Earth charity; who endeavour to halt the deforestation of the rainforest by placing the forest in the hands of the people that really on it for survival! The rainforest is being destroyed at the fastest rate ever, and more than half has disappeared in the last 40 years. We'll be organising several fundraising events for Cool Earth over next 10 months, so keep your eyes peeled!

story:
We're 4 friends who met through a trendy London start up called Monzo. One night in early September we were chatting about our desire for adventure. In true millennial style the concrete jungle was feeling too monotonous and easy for us. We needed a bit of a challenge, an adventure that would test us more than the Northern Line during the morning commute. This is when we decided to undertake the Mongol rally in the name of charity. 

We're doing it for the world...

In addition, as part of the Mongol Rally we also pledge to raise minimum £500 for its official charity: Cool Earth. Global warming is something impacting communities around the globe. Cool Earth has focused in on one of the drivers of global warming, deforestation.

"Cool Earth has found the key to halting deforestation. We put people, not trees, first." - Cool Earth

We would appreciate your support raising funds for this amazing cause.

story:
Following the smash hit  that was Morocco Monkey Bike Run 2017, and unprecedented demand for a sequel not seen since The Empire Strikes Back or Grease 2, Julia and Joseph have been asked to dust off their motorbikes, their inhibitions and their questionable humour/ cultural inappropriateness for one last oil stained hurrah.

Who needs the northern hemisphere? I hear you ask. Certainly not Jules and Joe. So Peru calls, and this time the international roaming fees are double!

Like any good 80s pop group, the line-up has changed slightly as three become two. But what a two they are too. So, discretely sandpaper your spark plugs in solidarity and donate generously to TEAM BANANALLAMA  because let’s face it - who doesn’t love a sequel?

(All donations obviously go to Cool Earth)

story:
After talking about the Mongolian Rally for a couple of years Olie, my boyfriend, and I have finally entered. We will be driving to Mongolia from the UK and back again in our gold Citroen Saxo - Nugget! 

Cool Earth is the official charity of the Mongolian Rally, we are lucky it's such an amazing charity that we both believe in! So what does cool earth do?  They save at-risk rainforests and shield millions of acres of neighbouring forest. They put local people back in control, giving them the resources they need to keep the forest intact. They never buy land, Instead help local communities take legal control of their forest. Focusing on rainforests most at risk and which would other wise be destroyed within the next 18 months.

It only costs just £60 to keep an acre of rainforest standing! 

-150 acres of rainforest are cleared every minute 

-Rainforests are home to 350 million people and the livelihoods of 1.6 billion people depend on the rainforest.

-Rainforests only cover 6% of the world 's land surface but contain more than 2/3 of its biodiversity, around 6 million species.

- clearing an acre of the rainforest releases 260 tonnes of CO2.


Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Please donate what you can any amount is greatly appreciated it all goes to save at risk rainforests. The top three donors names will be written on our car throughout our trip or if you prefer you can set a challenge! (Obviously within reason, we don't want to end in prison). You can follow our Journey to Mongolia on instagram 'dinokatie' which will be come more Mongolia Rally relevant closer to July!

eventName: Rickshaw Run Sri Lanka 2018 Pioneer Edition
owner: Bush Cookie Bels and Vanilla Miller
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
In a mere four weeks from now our three wheeling endeavour begins - a transcontinental meeting of friends to experience the madness and shenanigans of navigating our way across Sri Lanka in a tuk tuk.

THE GIG

The Adventurists Rickshaw Run will see us with seven days to whiz around the country on a wing and a prayer. It's an unknown route through jungles and beaches in a tin-top lawnmower that's barely powerful enough to carry itself and seldom stays upright around corners. As the Pioneers Edition, we are not even sure if we will make it!

THE WHY

Time spent travelling is quintessentially "taking the long way home". An opportunity to gain perspective about the bigger things in life from experiences outside the habitual routine. Naturally, cherishing our environment and fellow earthlings is part of that, so it's also about contributing to some really worthy charities.

For the honour and glory of this adventure we need to raise £1000. The first half goes to The Adventurists official charity, Cool Earth, to offset our carbon footprint in Sri Lanka. Cool Earth is a non-profit organisation that works alongside rainforest communities to halt deforestation and climate change, and whose work is endorsed by Sir David Attenborough. The other half (and anything beyond!) goes to our chosen charity, Dementia Australia. Dementia is now the second leading cause of death in Australia, and is also a cause very close to our hearts on a personal level. All donations go directly to the relevant charity.

THE SQUAD

Two gal-pals who lawyer by day and delight in tomfoolery, but in terms of adventure that is largely where the similarities end. Bella (aka Bush Cookie Bels) is an adrenaline junkie with a side dish of extreme prankster, and will thrive on the random and unknown with chat that's second to none. Shells (aka Vanilla Miller) is more of a girl guide adventurer, seeking out sunny days by the ocean and using her nose for sweets to keep energy levels high en route.

THE FOLLOW THROUGH

You'll shortly be able to follow our progress and misfortunes via live tracking as well as at our little corner of The Adventurtists blog (link to be updated soon).

In the meantime, here is a snippet of how it went in India, and an indication of what we have got ourselves into: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=lLOQQ7ge_0Q.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. Here's a chance to see two Royal Navy officers, training to be pilots, ride two ludicrously minuscule bikes across the Peruvian highlands. Without the luxury of roads or GPS, we will try to showcase to the world what naval officers can do... Standby....

The journey, on a 48cc 2.6hp moped, will have us navigating our way from Ayacucho to Atalaya in Peru, wherever they are, within a week. Through snow, desert, cliffs and rainforest we will push on; and while
we sit by the road side, bikes stuck in a muddy quagmire and rain pouring down around us, we will know at least we're doing it for a good cause!

We will be raising money to support both Cool Earth and our chosen charity, The Royal Navy and Royal Marines Charity. As Sub-lieutenants in the Royal Navy, we’ve met the men and women who make up the naval service, witnessed first-hand the struggles that military families can go through. Coming from military families ourselves, we are passionate about supporting those who are affected by the strains and stresses of service life.

RNRMC, The Royal Navy and Royal Marines Charity, which is the principal charity of the Royal Navy. They exist to support sailors, marines and their families, for life. They distribute millions of pounds annually to military charities that care for the children, families and veterans of the Royal Navy and Royal Marines, they serve those who serve or have served their country. To see what else RNRMC do, here's their website: https://www.rnrmc.org.uk/about-us
If you would like to donate to this great organisation go here!   https://www.rnrmc.org.uk/donate/donate/10/credit-card

Cool Earth do so much for the world's rainforests and The Adventurists offer this grueling adventure, to those who are fool enough to take it, in order to support their efforts. Extra information about the event and a chance to follow it when it starts can be found here: https://www.theadventurists.com/monkey-
run-peru 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
In mid 2017 we decided to do something out of the ordinary and some say, completely ridiculous.

We signed up for the Mongol Rally 2018.

The Team:

Rich Turner

Sebastian Inwood

James Ridges

What are the rules?

1. You can only take a farcically small vehicle of 1 litre or less

2. You’re completely on your own

3. You've got to raise £1000 for charity


Why are we doing it? 


To raise money to combat deforestation, the proceeds from this campaign will go to Cool Earth,  A UK-based international NGO that protects endangered rainforest in order to combat global warming, protect ecosystems and to provide employment for local people.


Event details

The Mongol Rally thunders 10,000 miles across the mountains, desert and steppe of Europe and Asia. There’s no backup, no support and no set route; just us, and a tiny 1.0 litre hatchback on a crazy trip to Mongolia.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As you will probably already know, I have signed up for a couple of challenges over the last few years, doing a parachute jump, three peaks and part of the Clipper Round the World Race that saw me sail across the Atlantic.

I’ve now turned my attention to the desert, with a week long race, on a Monkey bike, across Morocco. I have to say, this is possibly the most terrifying thing I’ve signed up for as once I cross that start line, I’m all in my own.

Although I was drawn to the adventure first, hearing about Cool Earth made me decide this was the next thing to complete on my list.

Please donate!

story:
Cheers for taking the time in visiting our just giving page; Tom, Chris and I have decided to take on the mammoth task of the 10,840 mile drive from London to Ulan-Ude as part of the 2018 Mongol Rally.

This is going to be a pretty serious undertaking, with 2 months to complete the drive, in our trusty small hatchback - ******** as yet to be confirmed what sort ******** . We'll be driving far past the comfort of England, Britain, and Central Europe, through the war torn areas of eastern Europe, such as Georgia, Uzbekistan, across the vast desolate expanse of Kazakhstan, and through Mongolia, before heading to the finish point in Ulan-Ude - all within a pretty tight timeframe of 2 months, with little spare time for repairs, dodgy border crossings, and injuries.

On top of this, from Ulan-Ude, we will be taking the Trans-Siberian express through Russia back to Europe, and touring our way back to Britain, via Scandanavia. Finishing the whole trip off with a night out in Hull. What better way to return to home soil.

This trip is going to be entirely self funded, so all donations will be going straight to our chosen charities; Cool Earth, as nominated by the Adventurist (organisers of the rally), who do sterling work alongside Indigenous tribes in the Amazon and other rainforests to protect the rapidly shrinking forests; and the ********* (yet to be decided) *********.

Finally, if anyone does car spares, knows anything about organizing visa's, or has completed the rally before, feel free to contact us; we need absolutely all the help we can get.

Much love,

Tom Woodray, Chris Hurrell, Robin Jones - The Stingin' Rodgers

story:
Myself, Curt & Nathan are undertaking something that's pretty crazy, probably dumb and likely very fun in August 2018; the Rickshaw Run:

A 3,000km Indian adventure in a 7 horsepower glorified lawnmower.

It'll be nothing but ourselves, a Tuk Tuk and a destination! Departing from Jaisalmer in the north we'll have 14 days to reach Cochin in the south, everything (including the route and repairs) will be down to us!

For this adventure we'll be raising money for the Cool Earth charity; who endeavour to halt the deforestation of the rainforest by placing the forest in the hands of the people that really on it for survival! The rainforest is being destroyed at the fastest rate ever, and more than half has disappeared in the last 40 years. We'll be organising several fundraising events for Cool Earth over next 10 months, so keep your eyes peeled!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Shiloh, Max and Morgan will be taking on the deadly yet fun Adventurists RICKSHAW RUN down the coast of India come January!! We are doing this not only to see what India can throw at us, but also to raise money for charity! We are 3 builders who met last year while living in London and all ended up working for the same company. We have the oldest Max, the local Sydney boy who loves the surf, snowboarding, The West Tigers, listening to some carton busters and throwing shakas. Then comes Shiloh the bush kid from Winton QLD, home of waltzing Matilda and one of the worlds biggest dinosaurs. If he's not watching the Cowboys play he can be found out building humpies or telling yarns to whoever will listen.
Last but not least is Morgan the young pup still wet behind the ears. He hails from Charleville QLD another bush kid. His hobbies include watching and playing any sport with a ball, and kicking some dirt up on the dance floors at some country shindigs!!
We are looking to get our page out there for everyone to see. By doing this we are hoping to raise a stack of money for our two charity's. Cool Earth, a climate change foundation and Men's Health. So spread the word to all your friends and share our story please. Be sure to follow our journey as it's going to be one funny and wild ride!

Kind regards bare foot builders

eventName: Rickshaw Run from Jaisalmer to Kochi
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Our Adventures:

Now a memory........2009 Team of eight took part in the Mongol Rally in a 1000 CC VW Polo's drove from London to Ulaan Baatar taking the silk route through Europe, Turkey, All Stan's and Russia.  

This time it's another crazy adventure, 14 of us are taking part in India travelling in 5 Rickshaws from north desert's of Rajasthan (Jaisalmer City of "Love") to south of India Kerela Kochi.

While UK negotiates it's exit from Europe, we will be negotiating the crazy traffic of India (people, cars, rickshaws, lorries, cycles, cows, monkeys....list is endless) on highways, dirt roads and city centre's of Ahmedabad, Mumbai etc.   

Why, you may ask!! Well there are 2 reasons. Firstly, it's adventure of lifetime (fully funded by the participants) secondly to raise as much money as possible for Cool Earth Charity.

Cool Earth

Cool Earth is an environmental charity that works in

partnership with indigenous communities.

The charity only protects rainforest that without
intervention will be destroyed within the next 18 months.

Cool Earth works strategically, protecting forest
that acts as a barrier to a wider landscape.

The charity spends just 10% of your donation on admin
and governance making sure as much as possible goes to project areas.

Through working with local people Cool Earth makes
sure conservation goes hand in hand with better livelihoods.

We will be collecting money for Cool Earth. In the last 40 years,
over half of the world's rainforest has been destroyed. This is devastating, not only for the world, but for our future generations. Cool Earth works with local communities to ensure that the solutions are there to stay. and not just a temporary patch-up job.

We would appreciate any donations no matter how small or large because when added together it can make a difference.

YOU CAN MAKE A DIFFERENCE. So please donate now..

https://youtu.be/v4FIn4GWZtc

story:
Welcome to our Justgiving page.

Here is a brief overview of what we are doing and why !!

Along with thirteen friends Nisha and I are driving 3,000 kilometres across India from Jaisalmer in the North to Kochi (Kerala) in the South. Our mode of transport will be a self-drive Rickshaw. This humble 7 horsepowered machine is best described as a glorified lawnmower and worst as a cake tin on wheels.

It is not a race and there is no set route or back up along the way. The link below gives a flavour of what is coming our way. (Please copy and paste the link in your web browser)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lLOQQ7ge_0Q

If you now think we are Bonkers you are probably right but if it prompts you to dip into your pocket and make a donation, however small, to our chosen charity then it is worth it.

We are highlighting the work of our chosen charity, Cool Earth, a charity which works alongside rainforest communities to halt rainforest destruction and climate change. Please take a moment to visit their website (Please copy and paste the link in your web browser):

https://www.coolearth.org

India is home to a third of the world’s poorest, with climate change hitting them the hardest. Unprecedented heat waves, cyclones and floods are already displacing thousands of families. Without action the situation will only get worse.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you Once again.

story:
I've been trying to reduce contributions to climate change in my own life but for 2018 I've decided to reach out and ask other people to join my efforts.

I'll be doing various things throughout the year to raise money for Cool Earth. This will include running events, I'm not sure anyone has ever run for charity before; Meat free Monday, because meat production is one of the biggest contributors to climate change; and whatever else I can think to do in 2018.

Cool Earth is a charity that works alongside rainforest communities to halt rainforest destruction and climate change. It has gained the support of various celebrities, including Sir David Attenborough.

https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cool_Earth

In 2016, the effective altruism organisation Giving What We Can, found Cool Earth to be the most cost-effective charity working on mitigating climate change through direct action. This basically means the most effective use of your money towards tackling climate change is to donate it to Cool Earth.

https://www.givingwhatwecan.org/research/other-causes/climate-change/

I would be grateful if you could help in anyway you can, whether by donating or by working on your own climate change impact.

https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jan/19/how-to-reduce-carbon-footprint

Thank you for reading.

story:
So the adventure continues.....


In short, without much thought we decided it would be a great idea to adventure through India in a 7 horsepower tin can on wheels (also known as a tuk tuk).

The reality has now sunk in...and frankly we're bricking it 😂

The adventure:

We'll be flying to New Delhi and travel via India's famous railway (Sam will be on hand to trouble shoot) across to Jaisalmer. Here we will collect and test drive our very own tuk tuk. We will then be driving approximately 3500km down to Cochin in the south of India over a two week period. Yes people, that means we will be travelling over 200km a day in a lawnmower with a cruising speed of 30mph!!

There will be no route, no back-up and no way of knowing whether we're going to make it! We will most certainly get lost, break down, catch 'delhi belly' and hopefully help save a bit of the world whilst doing it with your generosity.

The charity:

Our chosen charity is Cool Earth. Cool Earth work with rainforest communities to help halt the destruction of rainforests and climate change. Some 120 prescription drugs sold worldwide today are derived directly from rainforest plants. According to the U.S. National Cancer Institute, more than two-thirds of all medicines found to have cancer-fighting properties come from rainforest plants.


Please help gear us up and support our cause with a donation. All donations will go directly to the charity and not in our chai chai (tea) fund :D

Wish us luck!!!

Lots of love
Sam and Kylie
Aka team 'The Daly Lamas'
Xx

A brief guide to the Rickshaw Run: https://youtu.be/lLOQQ7ge_0Q

Track our progress here: https://tracking.theadventurists.com/#rickshawrun

Follow #thedalylamas on Instagram for pictures along the way 

Why save the rainforest?:
https://youtu.be/xaENAl-ffEg
https://youtu.be/tfFym56hEHk

❤️❤️

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On 30th December 2017  Arfon "Bear" Hughes will be taking part in the Monkey Run challenge, along with Paul "Bravo 2-0" Ezard.  We will be dropped off in the Sahara Desert near Merghouza and will have six days to cross the desert on ridiculously tiny and underpowered monkey bikes, to cross the Atlas Mountains and make it to the finish on the Atlantic coast.  

If you haven't seen one before, a monkey bike is essentially a child's motorbike, made popular by the shriners, and has a massive 49 cc engine.

 We will mainly be camping under the stars but due to weight limits on the bikes it will just be sleeping bags to keep the snakes and scorpions at bay.

I would love to say that this was an event into which I put a lot of thought but essentially we had too many beers one evening and signed up.  In the cold light of morn we remembered that neither of us had ridden a motor bike before..... so this really is a challenge!

Cool Earth is a hands-on charity focused on working with indigenous peoples to reforest areas of rainforest ravaged by clear cutting. It is the sponsored charity for the event.  See more at coolearth.org

Any donations would be very much appreciated.  

Paul is collecting his donations separately!

story:
http://www.dailymotion.com/video/x5spzuy

So yet again a few too many beers, we've come up with this genius idea...

Only a handful of people have ever driven across the Amazon and the Andes. Mostly due to the fact there isn't actually a road to allow you to do so. Even fewer have attempted this on a motorbike, and none on what is essentially a child's toy bike.

However, 5 brave pioneers/idiots attempted this in April to see if it was possible. Luckily, one managed to make it, proving that there is a sliver of hope that we'll make it out alive.

Neither of us know anything about mechanics, the non-existent Amazonian road network, or more importantly “Will this snake bite kill me?” in Spanish.

We'll be starting somewhere near Ayacucho and finishing more or less in Atalaya. The rest of the route's details are all currently a tad hazy. What is certain is that it will take place in the Andes Mountains and through a shitload of the Amazon jungle. This will be old-school 'adventuring' at its very best... or worst.

Once we've made it through the world's biggest rainforest and world's longest mountain range. With any luck we won’t have lost our sanity, our limbs and will have actually raised some money for charity.

This trip has already been self-funded in its entirety. We're not out for a free holiday (this is far from it) and everything you donate will go straight to Cool Earth so please support us by donating what you can!

Over half of the rain forest as been destroyed in the last 40 years and Cool Earth wants to put a stop to this  by developing local livelihoods, their  mission is to end the cycle of deforestation entrenching villages into further poverty. Through education and work with in the local communities Cool Earth hope to end the travesty of deforestation. This is very important to us and we really hope you support us with our fund raising efforts.  

Here is some more information about the wonderful work cool earth undertakes : https://www.coolearth.org

story:
The Wartburger Kings are a team who are about to take the adventure of a lifetime as part of the Mongol Rally in 2017. 

The team consists of a pair of regular guys, Brano and Lubo, that are going to drive over 20,000 kilometres in a 40 year old East German car from England to Mongolia and back to Europe, visiting 19 countries on the way all while raising money for a good cause.

Hungry for adventure, the Wartburger Kings are a team of fun loving travel junkies who want to drive their trusty East German Wartburg Knight (353) to Mongolia and raise money for good causes on their way.                    

Cool Earth is a charity that works alongside indigenous villages to halt rainforest destruction. By building better incomes, better schools and better clinics, Cool Earth gives their partner villages the resources they need to keep their forest intact. Cool Earth is now working alongside 65 rainforest villages throughout the world. These partner villages are protecting 352,000 acres of forest that lie directly in the path of chainsaws and bulldozers.

In addition to Cool Earth we'll also be looking to raise over €1,000  for a Slovak children's charity called Hodina Detom (Children's Hour). Hodina Detom is a year-round collection to support projects that help children and young people in Slovakia. Each year they connect those in need and those who can and want to give. 

*All money donated will go directly to our charities. The trip is being funded by ourselves and any sponsors we can get.

Well, what is it all about? Our name says it all. On Sunday 16th July 2017 we will be setting off on an adventure of a lifetime, from Goodwood in Sussex to Ulan Ude in Siberia and back again. All in the name of charity. We will be driving through 28 countries and covering over 14,000 miles as part of the Mongol Rally 2017.

All in a car woefully inadequate for the task in hand. We will be crossing 5 mountain ranges and 3 deserts, where there are no roads. The car we have chosen is a 2005, 3 cylinder Daihatsu Charade. 

The charities we have chosen are Cool Earth, St Wilfreds Hospice Eastbourne and the Samaritans. You can choose which of these charities you ould like to donate to.

story:
Thank you for visiting our fundraising page!

COOL EARTH

Across three continents, Cool Earth has saved 640,000 acres of rainforest, shielded an additional 5,000,000 acres by making it inaccessible, and has put 118 villages back in control of their futures.

They work alongside local people to build better health, better education and better livelihoods to create resilient and empowered villages.

Rainforest is only safe when there is a village strong enough to protect it. Cool Earth has put more rainforest under the protection of indigenous people than any other NGO or government.

charity.description:
Cool Earth is a unique rainforest charity that works alongside indigenous communities to protect the world's most endangered rainforest.

charity.name: Cool Earth
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Half of the world’s rainforest has been destroyed in the last 40 years.  And, contrary to the headlines, rainforest continues to be lost at a faster rate than ever.

That's why we don't create reserves or put up fences. We don't buy land. Instead, we put indigenous people back in control of their forest. 

By developing local livelihoods, our mission is to end the cycle of deforestation entrenching villages into further poverty. Creating strong, self-determining communities – not dependency.

We are also the only charity that works solely where the threat to the forest is greatest, on the frontline of deforestation. And each of our partnerships forms
a shield to make the neighbouring forest inaccessible to loggers – saving millions of acres of further forest.

story:
Hey everyone, Thanks for checking out our fundraising page and hopefully you will chose to donate a small contribution to help us support the Mongol Rally Charity Cool Earth.

Our plan is to undertake the huge journey, that is the Mongol Rally. This is a 10,000 mile trip from London to Mongolia with the finish line in a town called Ulan Ude just North of the Mongolian border. This Mammoth road trip has to be completed in a car that is 1L or less with no off-road adaptations to make the journey easier. The trip will be a challenging but EPIC adventure across deserts, mountain ranges and into totally unfamiliar lands.

We have chosen to do this trip in support of the Cool Earth. This is the official Mongol Rally charity that works with local communities to save the worlds most at risk rainforests. With the size of rainforests globally decreasing rapidly this is a very worthwhile charity to support. They have already saved areas of rainforest by working closely with the people who live in them which is a new strategy that is proving majorly successful. 

Please help us raise money for this worthwhile charity by donating. Just  follow the instructions on the page.

Also please like our Facebook Group to get more info and updates on our progress:

https://www.facebook.com/tartantrailblazers/

If you would like to learn more about the Mongol Rally or the work of the Cool Earth then please follow the links below:

http://www.theadventurists.com/mongol-rally/

https://www.coolearth.org

Thank you.

eventName: Carbon offsetting for volunteering in Nepal
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
On March 24th I will be heading of to Nepal to volunteer with VSO for 3 months, after the fantastic response I had with my fundraising campaign for VSO, I exceeded my target which is excellent news! 

So, ever the optimist I thought those who haven't yet made a contribution might like to consider donating to Cool Earth as a way of offsetting my fairly carbon intensive journey. Cool Earth, if you haven't heard of them already, is a charity that works alongside indigenous villages to halt rainforest destruction.

There are projects running in Northern Peru, Central Peru, Eastern DRC and Eastern Papua New Guinea. These projects prevent palm oil, logging and mining deforestation threats by developing communities and putting them back in control of their forests.

At least 90% of each donation goes directly to the indigenous partners of Cool Earth. If you would like to read more before chipping in their website is really informative and clear. 

I am still planning on selling my clothes and offering a chores for charity service for people local to Bristol so please contact me here at itilly@me.com for any queries!

https://www.coolearth.org/why-rainforests/

story:
3 Serbians, a Chilean, a Colombian and a Costa Rican traveling across the whole of India, top to bottom, on a couple of rickshaws. 

This ridiculous adventure, The Rickshaw Run, involves 3 weeks of perilous driving of a glorified lawnmower across the entire subcontinent (4000 km). This is not only an epic mental challenge of mind-boggling proportions that will hurl us into diarrhea-stricken culture shock. Turns out this whole ordeal is a fundraising event organized by The Adventurists, a UK based company that intends to make the world more exciting (and has raised over 5 millions GBP in the process). So, we are gaining an extraordinary experience while raising money to protect the rainforest in the Amazons through this NGO: Cool Earth. Pretty awesome indeed. 

Save a tree, support outlandish escapades, and be grandiose. All proceeds go directly to the preservation of world’s most vulnerable rainforest. 

Donate now.

story:
After getting the bug for adventure through trip though India and South East Asia, on various modes of transport, including Bajai, Rickshaws, Vespas and a knackerd old camper van. I have decided to challenge my self even further... and i have entered into the worlds toughest air race, The Icarus Trophy. This is the the worlds first long distance powered paraglider race, spanning from Seattle to south California. 


...Why you may ask... All in order to raise money for some of Fantastic charities around the world. 


These include... Anak Anak orphanage in Bali... Cool Earth... and Alziemers Society. 


The race takes place over 1700km and is completely un-assisted. so requires sleeping rough, traveling light (very light) and a lot of flying. So far i have a total of 0Hrs in the sky and limited survival skills. So this is shaping up to be one hell of a challenge, which is why i am asking everyone to get behind me, Donate Donate Donate and make the whole thing worth while. 


I am forking out the money for flights, equipment and fuel myself, so any donations will go straight to the charity, however if you are feeling generous enough to help me out please feel free as every penny and pound helps. I am also looking for corporate sponsorship to turn this dream into a reality so if anyone has any contacts... please help me out.

story:
The Mongol Rally; a 10,000 mile long drive from London here in the UK to UlanBataar in Mongolia and then 300 miles north to the finish line ulan-ude in russia. Our route spans almost half the globe and takes us through Europe, Turkey, Georgia, Azerbaijan, across the Caspian Sea into the vast wilderness of Central Asia, at times through inhospitable terrain....

At the finish, a total of 15/20 countries. All this to be completed in a Suzuki Jimny. When all said and done it does seem like quite an undertaking for two guys who haven't been driven like this before 

And so while at a first glance it might seem like a 'Gap Year' , we stress that the organisation and effort we are putting into this is all for a good cause and we really hope you can help us reach our goal.

If you want to find out more about the team, the route and the rally, visit our blog page. http://blogging.theadventurists.com/my-adventures/13131

eventName: Walking Hadrian's Wall for the Amazon Rainforest
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Departing on 23rd April, Shirley, Richard and Evelyn are Walking Hadrian's Wall to raise money for Cool Earth's project in the Western Amazon in Peru which helps Ashaninka villages to protect the rainforest against the threats of illegal logging and cocaine production. This project is particularly important because it helps form a protective shield to make millions of acres of neighbouring rainforest inaccessible to loggers. Supporting this project also helps the indigenous communities to develop sustainable livelihoods, selecting what they need from the wider world while conserving their environmental resources, and to maintain a strong traditional culture.

charity.description:
Cool Earth is a unique rainforest charity that works alongside indigenous communities to protect the world's most endangered rainforest. 

Every donation makes the biggest possible difference with over 90p of every £1 donated going directly to our partnership projects.
charity.name: Cool Earth
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My name is Tino. I'm going to be 4 on the 24th May. I love presents but I love animals even more. Especially those living in the rainforest. My favourite animals are the Hyacinth Macaw and the Toco Toucan.  But I love so many - the Andean cock-of-the rock, the emerald tree boa, jaguars, anacondas, hornbills, ring-tailed lemurs and fossas to name just a few.  I've seen many of them in the zoo, but one day I would like to see them in the wild, in the rainforest. 

We have a book in school, called The Rainforest. It has all my favourite animals, but it also tells about how people are cutting more and more trees in the rainforest and the animals are losing their home. Without a home, the animals will disappear. Will the rainforest be there when I'm grown up? Will I be able to see the macaws and all the other rainforest animals? I hope so...

I'm small still but I want to help the rainforest. I'm having a party for my birthday and have invited my friends. There are always many presents at birthdays. I'm fortunate enough that I will have lots of lovely presents from my family. So I'm asking my friends, instead of giving me presents, to help me help the rainforest.

Cool Earth is a charity that works with local communities to protect the rainforest from being cut down. This impacts many things like climate change, local community welfare, and biodiversity which I hope to understand better as I grow up. However, what I do understand now, is that it helps save the habitat of the rainforest animals. So please, help me help them.

As little as £1 or £2  will sponsor a tree in the rainforest and £30 secures protection for half an acre of endangered rainforest in South America. I'm hoping that with a little help from my friends, I will be able to raise £60 to sponsor an acre of rainforest.

Thank you and see you at the party!

charity.description: Evidence Action is dedicated to improving the lives of millions of people across Africa and Asia by delivering evidence-based interventions where the need and opportunity are greatest. Our approach fills the gap between research about "what works" and implementing solutions for people in need.
charity.name: Evidence Action
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Jack is running 4K at the Sawston Fun Run on Sunday 13th May.

He decided to raise money for a charity that provides clean water, because he learned at school how important this is.

Diarrhea is the second-leading cause of childhood mortality, often as a result of unsafe water. Evidence Action helps communities install chlorine dispensers, allowing users to add exactly half a teaspoon of diluted chlorine to a jerry can before filling the can with water. The water stays clean for two to three days. At a cost of $1.28 per person per year (April 2018), the Dispensers for Safe Water scheme is a proven, innovative, and cost-effective approach to increase rates of household chlorination.

Every pound we raise will support one person for a year!

charity.description: A child dies every two minutes from malaria. We are one of the world’s leading non profit organisations specialising in protecting the most vulnerable from the burden of malaria and other communicable diseases. To know more about how we spend your money and where we work, please visit our website.
charity.name: Malaria Consortium
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Sylvia Meek
story:
Dr Sylvia Meek (pictured left), Malaria Consortium's Technical Director, recently passed away after living with cancer for 18 months. Sylvia’s contribution to the fight against infectious disease,and malaria in particular, cannot be overstated. 

In 2003, Sylvia was instrumental in transitioning Malaria Consortium from a collaborative Department for International Development resource centre to the evidence-based, health research and implementation charity we are today. She had a vision to reach the most vulnerable and bridge the gaps in health systems where they were weakest, whether those gaps were between research and implementation, facility and community, or public and private sectors.

In Sylvia's honour, we would like to continue to influence lives in the field that she loved so much. 

With the blessing of Sylvia’s family, this scholarship fund will help to train a number of entomologists in the Greater Mekong Subregion and in sub-Saharan Africa.

Photo: Dr Sylvia Meek meets with community drug distributors supported by our integrated community case management and nutrition project.
title: Sylvia Meek Scholarship for Entomology
Name: Sylvia Meek Scholarship for Entomology

charity.description: A child dies every two minutes from malaria. We are one of the world’s leading non profit organisations specialising in protecting the most vulnerable from the burden of malaria and other communicable diseases. To know more about how we spend your money and where we work, please visit our website.
charity.name: Malaria Consortium
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Dear all

I have signed up to run the Paris Marathon on Sunday 8th April. I hope to make it around the 26.2-mile course without collapsing of exhaustion but as this is my first marathon, I cannot make any promises. So, this is where you come in as I feel like I will have a much better chance of success if I am running for a purpose.

For a while I have debated various different charities including Save The Children,  Syria Relief, Air Ambulance, ActionAid, Cancer Research and UNICEF. I did a little research into each because although some charities appeal to me on a personal level more than others, I wanted to make best use of your kind and generous donations. I ended up searching google for hours, on a mission to find the most cost-effective charities. I wanted to know which charity does the most good in terms of lives saved or improved for every pound it receives. Eventually, I came across www.givewell.org, a non-profit organisation that evaluates charities to identify those that do the greatest good. They assess and report on each charities evidence of effectiveness, transparency and cost-effectiveness to make peoples donations go further. Each year, they publish a list of their top-rated charities.

On this list was Malaria Consortium, a world leading non-profit organisations specialising in the prevention, control and treatment of malaria and other communicable diseases among vulnerable populations.

Current statistics from the World Health Organisation estimate that 445,000 people die as consequence of malaria each year. In 2015, 303,000 children died before their firth birthday. It is estimated that malaria kills one child dies every minute. I find these horrifying statistics incomprehensible in this day and age but unfortunately, they are accurate. There is strong evidence that seasonal malaria chemoprevention provided by the Malaria Consortium substantially reduces cases of malaria.

Please help me to raise some money for this incredibly worthy cause.

Thank you very much

Issa

If you would like further information, please visit:

https://www.givewell.org/charities/malaria-consortium

http://www.malariaconsortium.org

http://www.who.int/mediacentre/factsheets/fs094/en/

http://www.who.int/features/factfiles/malaria/en/

story:
I somehow managed to shave my head the other day. Something I've wanted to try for at least a year and a half. I always wanted to do it for charity and raise some funds whilst doing it because well realistically any money going to a good charity is money going somewhere good. Anyway, I shaved my head in the heat of the moment with some pals on New Year's Eve and had no chance to set up this page. The charity I have chosen to try and raise some funds for is Malaria Consortium. A charity which is doing fantastic work into trying to diminish to devastating impact that malaria is having across Africa at present day. Being a non-profit organisation, the charity makes use of all proceeds. If you would like anymore information about what the charity does then google is your best mate. Here's also a link https://www.givewell.org/charities/malaria-consortium and plenty of information can be found here. All sizes of donations go a long way. Stay safe. X

story:
Hey friends and family,

To support Malaria Consortium’s fundraiser to buy bicycles for Ugandan community health workers, I will be cycling to work and back every day, come rain or shine, until 23/12.

Given that it is during a London winter, you might call that a challenge!

In order to raise money for the campaign I will be taking your bets on my fastest time (one way) and whoever is closest wins their favourite bottle delivered to their door!

To support this campaign, please email me your time and favourite drink (m.blondeel@malariaconsortium.org), and make any donation to my crowdfunding campaign.

I live in Hackney Central (E81PE) and my office is in Old street (for those wanting to have a good chance).

I thought you might want to show you care about good causes in these turbulent times…

Place your bets! 

To donate and learn more about the project please go here here: https://www.justgiving.com/campaigns/charity/malariaconsortium/bicyclesforhealth 

I will announce the winner on December 24/12 on this page.

eventName: For every £1 donated to fight Malaria I will not tweet a reason Rome fell
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
On Sunday 4th December Arron Banks mansplained the Roman Empire to Mary Beard. In solidarity I tweeted that I would tweet one reason Rome fell for every like I received. I have thus far received over 800 likes and rising. I am in crisis. 

I have tried, valiantly some might say, to reach my total, but am running out of energy at CCC (300 for those who don't speak Latin). Twitter have said they will let me not tweet some reasons Rome fell, but only if you donate a pound instead of my explaining why Rome fell. Please help. 

The Malaria Consortium is one of the most efficient charities in the world, as rated by Give Well. They save lives, not only mine. Please help me (and them, but mostly me). At the time of writing in need £553 pounds. Please help.

charity.description: A child dies every two minutes from malaria. We are one of the world’s leading non profit organisations specialising in protecting the most vulnerable from the burden of malaria and other communicable diseases. To know more about how we spend your money and where we work, please visit our website.
charity.name: Malaria Consortium
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IFlv1kHaabc

In eastern Uganda, rural community health workers have to travel many miles every day, walking from village to village and household to household to treat sick residents and educate communities on how to protect themselves against malaria.

Malaria still accounts for over 400,000 deaths worldwide per year, despite being a completely treatable and preventable disease. This is equivalent to 40 times the total death toll of the Ebola crisis, except it is every year.  The disease is particularly devastating to children and pregnant women, who are especially vulnerable. In fact, in 2015, 70% of malaria deaths were children under five years old – many of whom could have been saved if they’d had access to prompt health services.

In the Eastern Ugandan district of Tororo, specifically in Iyolwa subcounty, Malaria Consortium recruited 215 community health workers. These health workers struggle to reach some of the most remote homes, leaving households without access to essential services, in particular services that could save a child or pregnant mother’s life.
This is where we need your help.

With your donation, Malaria Consortium will provide community health workers with bicycles that will double or triple the distance they can cover in a day and will allow them to reach more of those who most need their support.

There are currently 215 community health workers in Iyolwa, who walk long hours every working day to visit one or two homes in their area, each reaching approximately 470 homes every year.

Our target of £10,000 will provide each of them with a bicycle, which means they can reach three or four more households.  Over a year, this means each community health worker can make up to 1,170 more visits than previously. Collectively, all 215 could make as many as 350,000 more health visits to those in need.

A bicycle is a highly effective long-term investment: just £46.50 can provide a community health worker with a bicycle that will allow him or her to save many more lives.

Malaria Consortium works to improve the lives of all, especially the poorest and marginalised, in Africa and Asia. We target key health burdens, including malaria, pneumonia, dengue and neglected tropical diseases, along with other factors that impact child and maternal health.
title: Bikes for community health workers
Name: Bikes for community health workers

Malaria still accounts for over 400,000 deaths worldwide per year, despite being a completely treatable and preventable disease. In the Eastern Ugandan district of Tororo, specifically in Iyolwa subcounty, Malaria Consortium recruited 215 community health workers. This is where we need your help.

story:
I am helping to raise funds to buy bicycles for community health workers in Eastern Uganda, so that they can travel to rural homes to treat sick children.

The campaign aims to reach £10,000. To support this, I am donating the travel costs I save from walking to work everyday in London for a month until Christmas. 

Any contribution to my page will help me increase this to a £200 target -- this will buy four bikes for community health workers to travel to save lives!

------------------------------

About the campaign and why we're crowdfunding for it: 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IFlv1kHaabc&feature=youtu.be

charity.name: Malaria Consortium
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I know first-hand the great work that Malaria Consortium do on the ground in the fight against malaria, neglected tropical diseases and childhood illnesses. I've seen it with my own eyes the impact that its work has on some of the most vulnerable communities in Africa and Asia. However, around half a million people still die each year from malaria, most under the age of five. Any number is unacceptable for a disease that is completely preventable and treatable, but this number remains shocking.

Please support me as I run the London Marathon in aid of Malaria Consortium. Any amount is massively welcome. Here’s what money can buy in the fight against this disease:

£5 pays for a long-lasting insecticide treated net (LLIN), protecting 2 lives for up to 3 years 

£10 pays for 200 rapid diagnostic tests for malaria

£25 is enough to train a volunteer to test for and treat malaria

£50 can buy, deliver and hang mosquito nets to help at least 20 children sleep safe

£100 can buy malaria tests and treatment to help 100 children who are sick

I'm going through over 6 months of pain, early mornings and non-weekends in my bid to beat my previous marathon PB of 3 hours 24 minutes and your support will certainly spur me on to achieve this.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
AS A TEAM, WE ARE (SORT OF) CLIMBING BEN NEVIS!

5 times up and down the shop stairs = ~12.5 metres done. At the end of each shift, some of us will be doing these extra trips for as long as it takes!

We need to do it 110 times in order to reach the summit of Scotland’s highest mountain, Ben Nevis = 1345m (4,411 ft) above sea level.

Like tackling poverty, it’s much easier if we all work together.

The whole point is to raise money for Oxfam to tackle poverty in the UK
https://www.oxfam.org.uk/shop/oxfam-unwrapped/fight-inequality/beat-uk-poverty-ou1038in?intcmp=ou-home-product-beat-uk-poverty

Despite being one of the world’s richest countries, poverty is rising in the UK. It’s a huge injustice. But your donation will help to set it right – by fighting poverty on your doorstep. From helping people to learn new skills, to tackling inequality and ending dependence on food banks, this gift means you’re doing what it takes to help push for a fairer, more equal society here in the UK.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Since March 2011 the humanitarian crisis in Syria has been escalating:

- Nearly 100,000 people have been killed in the conflict so far.

- 6.8 million people need urgent assistance inside Syria, 3 million are children.

- 1.8 million refugees have fled to neighbouring countries

There are lots of ways you can get involved and make a real difference:

·     Walking or running for Syria in our sponsored Peak District Challenge!

o   Four levels of difficulty: Copper 25km, Bronze 50km, Silver 80km or Gold 90km.

o   20-21 September 2013

o   £49 entrance fee, all sponsorship goes directly to Syria!

·         Donating directly to this page

·         Raising money yourself- create a page and link to ours!

o   Some ideas:

§  Hold a collection for Syria at your school, place of work or worship.

§  Get sponsored! Try a walk, bike ride or a bit more of a challenge...

§  Hold a day at work – “Bring £1 to work for Syria”

o   Whatever you do, get in contact and we can give you support and a helping hand with your fundraising!
title: Support Syria!
Name: Support Syria!

story:
Live Below The Line is a campaigning and fundraising event that runs from May to June, with the Hunger Project. The UoL Oxfam Society are partaking in the challenge between the 4th-8th May! Living on £1 a day for all food and drink.

With a group effort we hope to raise more than £500 to support Oxfam's work - 82p of every £1 donated going directly to saving lives in emergencies, especially the recent devastating Nepal Earthquake. This is important for us, it's going to be a challenge, but we're hoping to make a difference - no matter how big or small! Every £1 donated will be matched by the UK government! Just click on Gift Aid when you donate.

Join in! It's a brilliant way to raise awareness of world hunger and food poverty in the UK, and change your perspective about how other people live around the world! For more information follow the links below...

http://www.thehungerproject.co.uk/getinvolved/live-below-the-line/

http://www.oxfam.org.uk/get-involved/fundraising/fundraising-events/live-below-line-2014

Thank you for your support!

story:
Me again. I'm running the London Marathon for Oxfam on Sunday. This year, things are tougher for them, and the projects they fund, for reasons I'm sure you know about. I thought long and hard about whether to stick with them after all these years, and decided I would.  It would be great if you could show them (and me) your support with a lovely, big, juicy donation. Thanks very much. 

This'll be my 13th London Marathon. The marathon organisers have clearly had enough: they've made next year's auto-qualifying standard considerably harder, and probably out of reach. In case I miss it, why not give the next five years' donations now?

My running number is 25646, which might help you track me, if you want to use the website, or the tracking app (www.virginmoneylondonmarathon.com/en-gb/event-info/spectator-info/).

The photomontage shows me in 2004, 2005, 2007, 2015, 2016 & 2017.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Oxfam has 4 teams in the affected areas (Leyte and Samar) providing household level water purification. Oxfam is delivering sanitation kits to 10,000 people this week, and is working with others to help get food markets back up and functioning, as well as getting cash into the hands of the most vulnerable.

Water and sanitation equipment is arriving into the country, which will be immediately taken to affected areas.

 

Oxfam looks to provide 500,000 people safe and clean water, tents and tarpaulins for emergency shelter. Oxfam will be supporting households rebuild their farming and fishing businesses, at the same time getting markets up and running so that food is available again in local shops.

WHY???  (i asked myself the same question).  The answer is simple; To raise funds for the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam. I was hoping you could help me.  I will do all the hard work - all you have to do is to show your support by donating to my just giving page. ANY amount is much appreciated and it will certainly help to cheer me on. 

I would like to thank you in advance for your support. :)

story:
100km walk in 30 hours in the South Downs National Park: 13-15 July 2018

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page for this epic 100km challenge.  Am I crazy? Probably! Do I need your help and support? Definitely!

At school, we regularly raise money for so many charities through bake sales, raffles, quizzes etc but this one is massive!!

It will be a huge personal challenge to be able to complete the 100km walk: starting at 6am on the Saturday morning and walking all day and night until we finish, hopefully before midday on Sunday.  I walk in the hills and mountains as you all know and usually small day walks and the occasional Duke of Edinburgh trek over 2 days, but this goes way beyond that experience.

I would love for you to sponsor me to contribute towards our team target of £3000. So please click to donate as much as you can afford.  We have to raise the money before July so the charity will let us take part.  We will be walking over the weekend of 13-15 July 2018.

Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event. 'The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours in a team of four, with a support crew of two members to help you get to the finish line.

Trailwalker is distance of 2.5 marathons and the ascent of Snowdon and Ben Nevis combined.

If we hit our fundraising target we'll be able to fund the provision of live saving water hygiene kits to 241 parents and their children in the Niger delta. Keep funding and we can help support even greater things. 

THANK YOU!

story:
Collectively we have decided to take part in the Trailwalker 2018 event. This is a 100km foot race through the South Downs National Park using trails and dirt tracks but also must be completed in under 30 hours. This is going to be an enormous challenge for us all but we are looking forward to having the opportunity to make a difference in whatever way we can. We will all be raising money for Oxfam, who are actively trying to reduce poverty, hunger and social injustice on a global scale. We have all been fortunate enough to have been put in a position where we can strive towards achieving our dreams in a sporting and academic capacity, however not everyone is this fortunate. We believe that everyone everywhere, should have the right to reach their potential and that poverty should not be a limiting factor in determining the level of success people can achieve, but unfortunately it is. By donating, you will not only be motivating us to run/walk/crawl 100km, you will be directly working to combat injustice and inequality on a globe scale.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

The reason for creating this page is my passion for the charity, Oxfam. Oxfam support over 94 countries across the world, providing security, clean water and the tools and equipment needed for everyone to live a healthy and fulfilled life. Oxfam support those facing poverty and every penny raised will go directly to supporting those in need of Oxfam.

I am a Psychology student at Plymouth University and I have been given the amazing opportunity to potentially steward for Oxfam. This will mean I work at some of the most popular festivals throughout the summer and ensure everything runs smoothly. As well as becoming a steward, I wanted to help Oxfam further, by deciding to fundraise £200 I will be able to pay for 24 water wells to be drilled and built. This means clean water will be provided for over 20 communities, something we take for granted, but many desperately need.

Thank you so much for reading this and having a look at my page. Please consider donating and if you do donate, thank you so much!!
