charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
I’m on my mission to give aids to the people who are suffering and to make them live their best life in this world.

As we all know, majority of people globally struggles to survive for their life which includes suffered kids, oppressed women, and families living in extreme poverty. Refugees are fleeing away from their unstable countries to seek for asylum, they are in need for survival kits and health treatments. So, I’m planning to start a charity drive to help them as much as I possibly could. In order to execute this mission,

I’ll contribute 20% of what I’ve received from my graphic design service, to charity.


I believe in power of giving. “If you contribute more, you’ll get more in return.”


Please help me to reach my target and dig deep now. There will be lots of opportunities for you to support me and get the benefits at the same time.

Oxfam is one of the world’s largest charity organization and I’m very proud to be one of their supporter in contributing whatever I’ve got to make this world a better place to live. So, I would like to take this opportunity to personally invite anyone of you who are reading this post to contribute a part of your value for the cause. 

This is the least thing I could do to pay my contribution to the world. Even though my graphic design service could not help directly in terms giving aid or manpower, but I’ve always wanted to contribute some portion of my services for charity. So, this is my way to be the part of making others living their best life in this world. My goal is to raise as much as possible for the charity drive by raising my service standards to the best quality as possible.

What inspires me to do the charity drive is by looking inspiring from big entrepreneurs out there giving away their life and money to help others. Bill Gates is one of the people I am inspired by, whom donated most of his wealth for charity reasons around the globe. I do realize that I’m not that so called a big company to donate most of my wealth to charity. But I believe that with every small step I’ve made, I could make a difference in someone’s life.

I chose Oxfam as my charity platform because they are doing a great job on giving aids to the needs out there in all around the world. Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal – an end to poverty for everyone. I believe on what they believed, “In a world rich in resources, poverty isn’t inevitable.” I feel that I’m not the one whom need the most from the resources, so I think I should give my part to someone who need it the most. Oxfam believe that everyone should be able to eat, drink, earn and learn as much as we do. 

Through Oxfam and their partners, 4.3 million people got access to clean water, 2 million people got food, cash or vouchers to survive a crisis, and 1.7 million women were supported to exercise their rights. They couldn't have done it without someone like us. 

On average for every £1 donated to Oxfam, they invest 84p on their humanitarian, development and campaigning work. They invest 8p to raise further funds, and they invest 8p on support and running costs such as paying the salaries of staff who work all year round to deliver their work and who ensure they are effective and accountable.

To conclude and to mention it again, the idea behind the charity drive is to cut off 20% from every income I’ve received from my graphic design service and donating them to charity. So, obviously, the more I get, the more I will give in return and more people I could contribute to. This is my goal. All donation will go straight to my profile at JustGiving.com and will be donated to Oxfam. 

Thank you for all you support!

Regards,
Azri Omar

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Why am I running my first ever marathon? I ask myself this every time my alarm goes off to go for a run at 5:30am...

When my alarm goes off I wake up in the knowledge that I have access to food, clean water, and have a job to earn a wage. For lots of people around the world they do not have this same access.

Often people are stuck in poverty or crisis due to factors out of their control. Take the 665,000 Rohingya refugees who have fled their homes, fleeing after 7,000 of their friends and families were killed in one month. 
That's 7,000 people killed in the time it took for you to open your advent calendar this Christmas

And why?  Because in 1948 when Myanmar was granted independence Rohyinga people were not granted citizenship, even though they had been living there for generations, ignored just because of who they are. Not what they have done, or anything else. Simply for being themselves.

So this is what brings me to run the London Marathon for Oxfam. While I recognise I am lucky to be in the position I am, I recognise this is largely attributed to factors out of my control, just given to me through my luck of upbringing. Is this fair?

Many people are stuck in poverty just because of where they happened to pop out into the world and catch their first breath; faced with many factors out of their control.

 Oxfam recognises there are many routes/reasons to poverty and tirelessly works to alleviate them and bring people out of poverty. Constantly refocusing and changing it's campaigns to the latest crisis or need. Oxfam are currently on the ground helping the Rohingya people, and have currently touched base with 185,000 providing access to clean water and food. 

So I hope by running the marathon I am able to raise money and help people get out of poverty and have a basic standard of life that we all deserve.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.




****UPDATE*******

The last few weeks there have been shocking revelations about Oxfam UK in the press. I have read and reviewed all the information carefully, and I am still proud to be running the marathon for Oxfam UK.

Here are my reasons:

1)    It won’t be Oxfam which suffers from fundraising cuts it will be the people most vulnerable caught in crisis

2)    Oxfam is in a unique position to shape the future of the Aid industry and stamp out abuse

Oxfam is one of the largest most recognised charities in the world, it is now in the spotlight and will continue to be in the spotlight. By continuing to support Oxfam, we can push Oxfam to set a gold standard in safe guarding, and best practices in vulnerable situations to ensure this never happens again. We don’t need Oxfam just for the charity it can give, we need Oxfam for it’s unique position it now finds itself in to drive real change.

3)    The horrendous actions of the minority shouldn’t punish the good work of the majority

9 people have been accused of sexual misconduct out of a global organisation of 10,000 employees. The rest of these 10,000 people are just as shocked as we are. If we applied fundraising cuts like those proposed to Oxfam to Hollywood following the Harvey Weinstein scandal film screenings would be empty and DVD shelves bare. 

An interesting article on the psychology of outrage and shift in severity can be read here https://www.ft.com/content/5954a160-1240-11e8-8cb6-b9ccc4c4dbb

“Righteous outrage is a powerful weapon, and one that has smashed many barriers of injustice. We should pull the trigger of that weapon with care, not with abandon.”- Tim Harford, The Financial Times , 16/2/18

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hey everyone 

Thanks for visiting our Just Giving page! We are a team of four women who are willing to undertake the endurance of the 100K Oxfam TrailWalker Challenge through the South Downs from the Queen Elizabeth County Park in Hampshire, starting at 6am on the 14 July to trek day and night non-stop until we reach Brighton! The event is timed and we plan to finish in sub-24 hours so we can be in Brighton for breakfast! 

This will be the ultimate challenge for our team as we have never undergone an ultra before! Made up of runners, hikers, trailwalkers and cyclists, though our outdoor activity styles are different we all share a love of a challenge and a passion for life. This challenge will definitely be our toughest to date but we are excited to be part of it and work to become Trailwalker Legends!! To hike, walk and run solid for 24 hours will test us to our limits of mental and physical strength. The route was set by The Gurka Signals over 30 years ago as the ultimate test of teamwork and endurance for new recruits with a total ascent of 2,500m - the equivalent of Ben Nevis and Snowdonia combined - this will be no walk in the park. To achieve this challenge we will be training for months to make sure we are Trailwalker fit and to make you all an Oxfam proud!

For more information about the challenge check out Oxfam's website https://www.oxfam.org.uk/Trailwalker. We aim to raise a minumum of £1400 which will provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap. £1650 would provide safe drinking water for 1,650 people. Clean water is an essential for life and should be a basic human right. Please help us make that happen. 

Thank you 

Hannah, Louise, Carrie and Tilly

story:
Many thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On Saturday, 14th July 2018 I will be setting out to complete 100 km across the South Downs Way in two teams of four.  Testudinidae britannica A and Testudinidae britannica B are both teams of mixed ability and experience but with the single-minded determination to walk, jog and run the course together in under 30 hours.

Oxfam Trailwalker 2018 is a team endurance event, starting at Queen Elizabeth Country Park, near Petersfield, along the South Downs Way to the finish line at Brighton Racecourse.

Organised by Oxfam GB and the Queen's Gurkha Signals, money raised will support both the work of Oxfam as well as the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

We were inspired by watching the London Marathon last year and set ourselves the challenge of running for the very first time in 2018. Oxfam helps fight against poverty around the world so as well as the personal challenge of running our first ever marathon, we will be driven by the thought that we are helping others live an easier life with the things that we take for granted...things like food, water, shelter and safety. We are just lucky to have been born poverty free...millions around the world, and even in the UK are not so lucky and by reaching our fundraising target (£2000 each for me and my husband Nick) we will be contributing £4000 to help fight poverty.

Please help us by giving as much as you can. Watch out for our fundraising events as well. We will be organising a Silent Disco and will publish details soon. Try and come along if you can.

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
I grew up in Mexico City and my family still live there. As you will know, Mexico has now been hit by three devastating earthquakes in recent weeks which killed more than 250 people and injured 700 more.

I am blessed to be able to say that all my close family and friends are safe, however it wasn’t until they described to me the current situation that I realised the scale of the devastation suffered by my home city and country.

Thousands of families have lost their homes including friends of my mum, but the most affected people are those in the most deprived communities who have lost everything and are in desperate need of help.

A lot of my friends and relatives have been actively providing support and volunteering around the city and it makes me sad to be so far away at this time and not being able to be there to do my bit. That is why I decided to start a fund and give up some of my time over the next three months to raise money. I have chosen to raise money for Oxfam who have created a dedicated ‘Earthquake in Mexico’ fund, which will be 100% used for support services and relief and recovery efforts for affected areas.

We are so lucky to live in a country where we are safe from natural disasters like those recently seen in Mexico and in the Caribbean, as well as to benefit from the basic safety net provided by the welfare state.

If you can spare a bit money and would like to donate through my just giving page then I will be very grateful. If you would like to find out a bit more or would like to help me with my fundraising endeavors I’d love to hear from you.

Many thanks Maribel

story:
On the 13th of July 2018, I will be taking part in the Trailwalker. The aim is to walk 100km of the South Downs Way in 24 hours with a team of 3 others. That means hiking through the night, depriving ourselves of sleep, living off sugary snacks and caring for our feet like our lives depend on the absence of blisters.

We've started training already, putting in the km's along parts of the route and so far our feet remain mostly intact. That said, our longest hike so far was 35km, which is a third of the event. Gulp.

The event is organised by Oxfam and ran in conjunction with the Gurkhha Welfare Trust, so proceeds will be split between two very worthy organisations.

story:
The idea of this page is to enable you to donate excess credit from your PAYG mobile phone account to an excellent cause. You can do this by texting OXFA70 £n to 70070, where n is 1,2,3,4,5, or 10. So to donate £10, you'd text OXFA70 £10 to 70070.

You'll receive an acknowledgement text which includes a link so that taxpayers can Gift Aid their donation. You'll also be offered a choice between anonymity and having your contact details passed on. Please choose anonymity - I don't want to know who is donating, I just want you to donate to my chosen cause!

100% of text donations and of any Gift Aid goes to the charity. It isn't restricted to PAYG; for Pay Monthly, the donation is added to your next invoice. It is open to users of all UK mobile networks, and the admin is done by JustTextGiving. 

You can also donate by card using the purple 'Donate' link on this page if you prefer, and a small service fee is deducted from your donation.

story:
Starting on the 1st March I'm going to be giving up alcohol for at least a month. Possibly longer! I'm a big fan of beer so this is a huge thing for me! I'll admit that it's not totally for selfless reasons. I'd like to be a bit more healthy and not spend my money on beer all the time, but I thought why not make it a thing and raise some money for Oxfam in the process!

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. In just 15 years, extreme poverty has been halved. 15 more years and we can end it for good.

Being a volunteer of Oxfam for a number of years now they were the obvious choice as I'm fully aware of the amazing work they do for people in extreme poverty. Sponsor me today and 82p of every pound you donate goes goes directly to emergency, development and campaigning work.

It would be amazing to raise at least 200 pounds as this would pay: -
To train 4 family's to grow their own food or,
For 320 mosquito nets for children or,
To drill 24 wells for clean safe drinking water.

Please donate as little or as much as you can afford, thank you.

First Point Group has partnered with Oxfam as our company charity this year in order to give back to the local communities where many of our clients and candidates operate in. 

FPG has set up this donation page to collect donations from internal activities from our 10 global offices. These include adhoc events such as fancy dress days, collecting spare change in the office, pub quizzes and other events.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.  Running the London Marathon has always been on my bucket list and I'm so happy that I'm able to do this whilst raising money for a charity that I really believe are doing amazing things.

Oxfam helps support millions of people living in poverty around the world and are constantly helping those affected by humanitarian crises and natural disasters.  Not only do Oxfam provide emergency aid to those affected by wars and tragedies, they also work with local communities to set up irrigation systems, farming and training so that societies can become self-sufficient and break out of the poverty cycle. If anyone would like to learn more about the work that Oxfam do, please visit: www.oxfam.org.uk/what-we-do

It is estimated that half of the world (over 3 billion people) live on less than $2.50 a day and 80% of the world lives on less than $10 a day. Especially with the natural disasters that have recently occurred and the current conflicts going on in the world, it is so important that those of us who are able to, make an effort to help those who are so much less fortunate than ourselves.  Any contributions you can make to this very worthy cause would be greatly appreciated.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure.  Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails.  Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. It's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thanks,
Kami

owner: Melinda Warby - Tyneside Rejects and the Lady
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks very much for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page! Mug shots above...

In a moment of madness we all agreed to take part in Trailwalker 2018 for Oxfam and The Gurkhas Trust.  We will join many others between the 13-15th July 2018 to walk across the South Downs starting in Queen Elizabeth Country Park (near Petersfield, Hampshire) and ending on Brighton Race Course. All in under 30 hours.

Steve Perrins, Graeme Fletcher and James Mortimer are all fine, athletic specimens, ex-army and if it wasn't for me (and Steve's knees), I am sure they would be marching round in no time!  Sorry lads!

For my part, this is the first time that I have ever attempted anything like this. Training has begun in earnest and to save the ears of my fellow team members from my grumbles and groans on the way round, I will be putting a vast "Rocky training" play list together!

Now for the dough.... there will be many of you I am sure who would pay good money to see the Tyneside Rejects and the Lady go through this pain. I am pretty sure I won't be looking much like a lady by the end of it! Thankfully it will be dark!  ANY donations that you are able to give will be gratefully received and hugely appreciated.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.


Thank you all in advance for your generosity.

From

Steve, James, Graeme and Melinda (aka.. the Tyneside Rejects and the Lady)

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Each Trailwalker team pledges to raise £1,400 for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust as part of their challenge. Broken down between all 4 walking team members, this works out at just £350 per person!

The money will be used for many different causes such as providing live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap. It will also be used to fund a Gurkha Welfare Trust nurse for six months, helping to provide medical aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities and much much more. 

Please help us smash this target and pledge what you can. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. story:
Oxfam need our help to reach 500,000 people affected by Typhoon Haiyan.

Typhoon Haiyan, one of the strongest storms ever recorded, has struck the Philippines. Oxfam is ready to deploy water and sanitation materials to those affected.

Rapid assessment teams are on the ground to provide urgent emergency supplies and shelter on the islands of Samar, Leyte and Cebu where near-total devastation is reported.

Donate now to help Oxfam reach people with life-saving aid.

Every penny and pound really does count. £27 could provide 10 Oxfam buckets to help provide clean water. £50 could provide 100 emergency health kits.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. story:
Our names are Dylan, Henry and Sam. We are all seven years old in year three and we live in Christchurch in Dorset. 

We were very upset by the fact that 93,000 people have died in the Syrian civil war and wanted to do something to help. We kept on watching it on the news and although we know this isn't going to happen to us we did imagine what it would be like if 93,000 of us died or if we or our families had to run away from our house and leave our things.

So me Henry and Sam decided to do a fun run in October. We are doing lots of training so we get really good at running. We want to try to raise £50 each.

What's happening in Syria is terrible and the more people who know about it the better as we want to show the people of Syria that we have not forgotten about them and care about what is happening.

We want to stop bad injuries and deaths and want to raise the money to get a tent to help people and maybe help them to buy a house. We think Oxfam will help make things a bit better.

So we want to get people to sponsor us.

The Fun Run will take place between Southbourne and Bournemouth Pier in October half term. My little brother Rufus who is 6 will ride on his bike with us to help encourage us to keep on going too. Lily who is Henry's little sister will also ride along with us too. 

 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
GBI Cycle Challenge - Luxembourg to Dusseldorf - DONE!

On 3rd July 2013, I took part in a cycling challenge from Luxembourg to Dusseldorf covering 402km over 3 days (Luxembourg, Belgium and Germany)

This is my longest bike challenge so far and did it to support Oxfam UK (Syria Crisis Appeal).

It was an amazing experience/ journey… Great views, New friends and raised money for Charity.

I can’t wait to do it again next year!!!

If anyone wants to join in, then the challenge will be to cycle from Budapest to Munich..

It’s a long way - but you will not regret it!

HUGE THANKS to everyone who has alread supported me..

You can still donate online or by texting SHEZ48 £10 (or whatever amount you like) to 70070. It's free, easy to set up and every penny goes to charity!

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Cynthia Li
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page, I would like to share our journey and story with you all.

Our beautiful mummy’s chapter has sadly come to an end on earth, she went to sleep peacefully and beautifully on 26th January 2017. Her soul was returned to heaven to embrace her new journey as angel.

She had so much love and joy to give - she was selfless, courageous, strong, determined, kind and thoughtful. She has taught us so much about what it truly means to be a family and shown us the importance of loving the people that you meet in your life; be it your spouse, your children, your friends or a stranger in time of need. Her heart lives on through all of us and all those who have ever known her. 

In her final moments, we were with her every step of the way. She used all her strength to open her eyes and looked at us individually to say "I love you" and then a final "I love you all". She told us that she was going to sleep and tomorrow will be a better day.

She fought so hard and so well - sometimes things aren't meant to be and it’s ok because we’ve learnt to let her be free from the body that she was trapped in. Her last eye contacts was fixated on my dad and she used such energy to say "I love you" - A selfless act.

We are fundraising for our mummy’s favourite charity, she used to say the more charitable and kindness you can show and act on, one day you will return to the heavens above as an angel.

I will leave you with her words that she used to say to me: "It's ok to have good days and it's ok to have bad days - you're only human! 

In the end what pulls you through the tough times is the power of the mind. Take a chance even if the chances are slim it's still a chance, as long as you believe it you can do it, it will happen. Love your children, love your spouse, be kind to others, be kind to yourself. 

Even when the time does come, face it with bravery and dignity but don't face it alone. You're only going to sleep and if you're not afraid of going to sleep you're not afraid of anything else. 

This is not dying, this is just a beginning to a new journey and make every moment that you have a precious one too, think of happier times don't look back with sorrow and continue fighting to the very end. Stay in the moment, take one step and one day at a time and always try your best, never live a moment of regret."

Sleep well my gracious angel, I love you so much and I'm so proud of you - we all are. Your gorgeous smile and kind heart will always be in our memories. Love you mummy. Xxx

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
The devastating earthquakes and after shocks which have hit in Nepal in the last few weeks have left 8000 dead, 14000 injured, over 700,000 homeless and 8 million affected. Already a country battling poverty, Nepal is suffering immensly as a result. 

Although several thousand miles away, each and every one of us is still able to help out. For SURC , Nepal is a country close to many of our members adventuring hearts and so we've decided to get fundraising.

What is happening?
 
SURC (Southampton University Road Cycling club) are putting on 48-hour non-strop rollathon in support the Oxfam's Nepal Appeal to try and cycle the equivalent distance of Southampton to Kathmandu.  It’s taking place on 29-31st May on Campus.  We'll keep 8 sets of rollers constantly going by alternating riders with the intention of riding this massive distance. There will be music, lights, a big crowd and food/drinks to keep everyone going through the nights.

How can I get involved?

As you can imagine, SURC will need lots of people for this mammoth task, that is where you come in. If you can give just an hour of your time over the weekend that would be amazing. If you are free and around, I urge you to take part. The sign-up is here https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1eaWQQpZI98lyPqFtiZ6USzrJufIaDqeLTUIbv4suE9Y/viewform?usp=send_form.

If you can't make the weekend, then we'd love if it you wanted to make a donation directly to Oxfam through this website.

Thank you for you support.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
We are the Sir John Lawes School Oxfam Youth Action Group, a group of young people from ages 11 to 18 who campaign, fundraise and raise awareness for Oxfam. We are united by our desire to bring about social justice and help those who are suffering in the world.

Our current focus is on South Sudan, where fierce fighting has forced more than a million people from their homes. Oxfam has already reached 261,000 people at several locations across South Sudan with food, clean water, sanitation, and hygiene materials and training. They urgently need help from people like us to be able to offer assistance to more people and prevent the crisis from turning into a catastrophe.

We chose this project to work on as South Sudan is something of an unseen crisis, which isn't usually prominent in the media, and which many people in our school and the wider community may never have heard of before. As such, we set up a 'mock refugee camp' at our school one lunchtime to raise awareness amongst the student body.

We will be camping for the night at school, and would massively appreciate any donations, however big or small, that you are able to give. Together we really can make a difference.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you.

Susi, Dottie, Jack, Charlotte, Chloe, Kyran, Zoe, Miriam, Polly, Louis, Aimie, Meg, Lauren, Ellen, Lena and Cameron- the SJL Oxfam Youth Action Group

eventName: A Night With Sara Shahidi And Friends
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page for "A Night With Sara Shahidi And Friends".

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. In just 15 years, extreme poverty has been halved. 15 more years and we can end it for good.

Oxfam supports refugees by helping to provide life saving hygiene kits to stop the spread of disease, provide families with clean drinking water and help to build toilet and washing facilities for families made homeless. In Syria, Jordan and Lebanon, Oxfam provides life-saving clean water, sanitation and vital support for families who have lost everything.  In Greece, Italy, Serbia and Macedonia Oxfam provides water, food, clothes and personal hygiene kits, as well as longer term psychological and legal support. And around the world, Oxfam is making sure that people fleeing conflict have the life-saving essentials they need.

story:
Today (February 12), the Disaster Emergency Committee has said that it's members would not be not be offering help to those affected by the recent floods in the UK. See Daily Express article.

As a result, Oxfam's Twitter and Facebook have been overwhelmed with seemingly outraged comments by users who say they will no longer donate to Oxfam.

We feel it is important to show Oxfam that this view definitely isn't shared by all, that we continue to support their work, and that they have made the right decision to put their resources where they are most needed -- which is why we have created this fundraising campaign!

On the 24th and 15th June this year a team of 4 of us from Wadhurst will be doing the Oxfam Trailwalker Challenge. The aim is to walk a 100km section of the South Downs Way in under 30 hours, in order to raise money (50 / 50) for Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. Oxfam is a charity which I’m very happy to support, as it continues to do fantastic work in many of the world’s poorest countries, whilst the Gurkha Welfare Trust operates in Nepal in the verypoor communities which suffered greatly in the earthquake a few years ago. story:
"I won't be doing it again" purely because of the true fact that it is EXTREMELY TOUGH. 100km isn't a joke, that too within 30 hours.

On top of that having a close friend's reception on the evening of the night and not just attending but a performance is being prepped for. So many have been saying that I am dreaming of being able to barely even move after getting back home from the event in the morning. But I somehow feel like it is a challenge so taking on one after another.

Please donate what you can and help us reach our group target of £1400, make it worth every step we take to complete 100km from day through the night and back to day again. We shall try our best to ENSURE we complete this challenge as a team. And my personal challenge to perform at my friend's reception.

story:
On the 15th July 2018, eight of us will trek 100 km along the South Downs in under 30 hours - starting Saturday morning and hoping to finish sometime Sunday.  We are doing this to raise funds for Oxfam, but also as a personal challenge.  

Organised with the Queen's Gurkha Signals, Trailwalker is a unique opportunity to put our mind and body to the test.

Help us step in the right direction and raise money for a great cause “The Gurhka Welfare Trust's work “Established in 1969, The Gurkha Welfare Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows, and their wider communities are able to live with dignity in Nepal. This is achieved primarily through the provision of financial, medical, and community aid.

story:
So last year we had a mad idea to raise some money for a good cause and chose to do the TrialWalker challenge - 100km in 30 hours. 

After training, training and training it wasn't the wall that hit me, more over the blisters and I had to stop at 50km.

I was gutted and as much as i wanted to go on my feet would not let me. So this year i have new boot (bigger last last years) and now focusing on what i need to do.

I know I asked last year and thank you to so many of you that contributed, this year I've set up the page but appreciate that many of you already did it so I won't be pushing but if you would like to sponsor heres the link 

TrialWalker2018 here we come!

story:
Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event. 'The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours in a team of four. We plan to complete the 100km in less than 24hrs.

We have 2 teams of 4 people all of who are old friends from The University of Essex, with an emphasis on the word "old". Indeed we should all know better, but a certain bravado and over competitiveness has spurred us all into action!

All the money we raise is going to The Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows, and their wider communities are able to live with dignity in Nepal. This is achieved primarily through the provision of financial, medical, and community aid.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Stourport High School has a long history of supporting worthy causes. Oxfam is just such an example and this year has launched a Nepal Appeal.

Nepal has recently been hit by two massive earthquakes and a landslide. It is a poor country with limited resources. We,as a country, have strong links with Nepal through our military association with the Gurkhas and as such the country needs our help.

On the 10th July students will be undertaking several sessions on Oxfam, the Gurkhas and Trailwalker (a charitable event set up to raise money for the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam). This will raise awareness and hopefully inspire students to get involved along with raising awareness of the wider world around them.

Any donation, large or small, will massively help us to reach our target.

Thanks in advance.

story:
4 people, 100km, 30 hours. 



On 13-15 July this year, my team and I will be taking on the Oxfam 100km challenge from South Downs to Brighton in the UK.



Oxfam Trailwalker is a life-changing experience and every step we take helps raise vital funds to support people living in poverty. We will be part of a global phenomenon where ordinary people achieve something extraordinary and make a lasting difference by supporting Oxfam’s work around the world. Together they are promoting education, ensuring access to clean water, teaching skills to grow food and advocating for their basic rights.



We have a goal of raising over £1500, a small donation of £5 or £10 goes a long way. We appreciate your support and thank you for any donations you could spare xx

story:
Hi all,

Those of you who know me know that I hate any and all exercise. I’ve been known to claim running for 10 minutes “in a row” as my greatest sporting achievement.

While I want to challenge myself (😓😓😱) I also want to raise some money. Oxfam has had a lot of (deservedly) negative press recently and because of this has lost a huge number of donations, which genuinely do help to improve people’s lives across the world.

It’s hard to fully comprehend how lucky we are to have so much. Please help me raise some money to help others have what we take for granted: safety; education; shelter; food, and clean water. 

And please wish me luck 😩😩😩😩

story:
Please don’t feel you need to donate.

It’s all Phil Topham’s fault. He’s  a nice chap and I was standing next to him when he found out one of his team had had to drop out of the Challenge. Apparently you need 4 people per team and so I said I’d help if he couldn’t find anyone else. 

So here we are.

I’m not expecting to raise anything really (apparently you have to have one of these pages to take part). As a late entrant, I’m doing the walk more to make up numbers so that the money raised by Phil and friends will get to where they want it to be, ie Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. .

If there has to be a cause then it would be memory of a Nepalese friend who could not have been prouder of his country or the Gurkhas while he was alive. He taught me a lot about standing up for people and being stalwart in support.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Oxfam Oxy-Gym has been set up for people who love a gym challenge or who just love challenges. The idea is to raise money through sports.

The Press Up is one of the best Chest, Shoulders and Arm building move's around, it show's both strength and endurance.

The Challenge
Start standing then go into the press up position, do one press up, then stand. Then back into the press up position, do two press ups and stand. Then back into the press up position and do three press ups and then on until failure. How many press ups can you get up to?

Nominate 3 people after the challenge, put your challenge on FaceBook for everyone to see.

Text OGPU 83 to 70070 to donate £3 now.

All money raised will go to Oxfam's Water and Sanitation projects.

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
We all did Trailwalker last year, coming in the top 50 of over 400 teams, and plan to get round, ideally a bit quicker, this year. We are all now over 50 so maybe we need to manage our expectations a bit!!!  We all joined the Army in 1987. Jon Cole, Jim Forest and I starting our careers at Sandhurst and Tol-Saheb as a recruit in Pokhara, Nepal.  Jon and Tol are still serving, but Jim and I are now both “civvies”.   Viasat are, as last year, kindly sponsoring our team strip.  Whilst this is a significant endurance event for us, it is about the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam and helping ex-servicemen and their families, and the people of Nepal. 

Nepal is one of the poorest countries in the world, and has suffered a great deal in the last few years.  It also has a long standing and close relationship with the UK and the British Army.  During my military career I was blessed to serve with Gurkhas, at home and on operations,  have been lucky enough to trek in Nepal and also settled many Gurkha soldiers and their families into Stafford, a new location for them as part of the Regiment I commanded back in 2007-2009.  Gurkhas are superb soldiers and officers and still provide a brigades worth of manpower to the Army.  

Thanks, Neil..

story:
Hello,

Last year whilst out hiking with some friends someone in the group (George the 10th) came up with idea of doing something for charity which we all agreed would be a nice wholesome thing to do. Within the next couple of months over a few ropey phone calls and texts we were signed up to take on the Trailwalker challenge, personally I was thinking more along the lines of sitting in a bath of beans but I was out voted by the rest of the group and so the training begun. Since then we have been busy training racking up the miles getting our feet and sanity ready for the challenge and as the date get closer and closer the fear of failure is creeping so that's where you come in as if I can raise a load of money that extra pressure of not letting you guys down should see me past the finish line.

eventName: Putting our heads together for Syria!
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our Oxfam JustGiving page.

Jay and I decided that Syrian refugees needed more help, obviously! What's going on in Syria is both horrific and totally unacceptable. No one deserves to have to flee for their lives, only to then find themselves stuck in 3rd world conditions because other countries don't know what to do with them. We chose UNICEF and Oxfam as they both have a great track records for helping refugees and those in crisis. If we raise enough on this Oxfam page and our UNICEF page, as a thank you and just for a little fun, WE'LL SHAVE OUR HEADS!!!

Thanks for the support :) please share! 

Lots of love, 

Marchie and Cheshire xx

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Trailwalker is the challenge of a lifetime. As more than 400 teams take on 100km of the South Downs Way next July, they will be helping to end poverty with each step. The money raised will be used by Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust to improve lives around the world.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty to everyone. In over 70 years we've become world leaders in emergency water and sanitation, and experts in providing shelter, food and protection. 

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community.

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hello Again,

You lovely lovely people were so generous last year raising over £6000 for the Gurka Welfare Trust. So we decided to put ourselves through it again. On July the 14th and 15th of this very year we will be walking 100km over the South Downs way non stop, day and night. Last year it took around 24 hrs to complete. It was extremely tough, mentally and physically. For Dan it was the toughest, as he was driving the support vehicle. He had to wait on his own for hours and hours suffering torturous silence and deafening bird song that has left him half the man he once was. So in vengeance against his fellow peers, he will actually walk it this year and prove he is not just a sandwich and potato pack lunch supplier.

Please be generous and help Oxfam and the Gurkas build better lives for others less fortunate.

Thanks

Dan, Olly, Phil and Jon.

charity.name: Oxfam
owner: Edward, Henry, Louise and Steph... Team name: Are we there yet?
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page! 

On July 14/15 Edward, Henry, Louise and Steph (team name: Are we there yet?)  will be hiking 100km in under 30 hours, across the South Downs in an effort to raise £2000 for Oxfam.

This 100km Trailwalker involves starting in the early hours of Saturday morning and walking continuously, through day and night, until we (hopefully) make it to the finish line before 1pm on Sunday. No rest for the wicked!

No doubt this will be enormously challenging, not only is it a long way but the chosen route means we will scale the equivalent height of Ben Nevis and Mount Snowdon combined along the route.

Please help us by donating! Not only will your support give us a greater sense of pride, motivation and achievement, but it will have an even greater impact on the fantastic causes that we are raising money for. 

Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust

Oxfam, fighting to beat poverty on a global scale; and The Gurkha Welfare Trust, supporting ex-servicemen and their families of Nepal, are the event charities, and ones that we are hoping to raise money and awareness for and to support their fantastic work.

For more information on these fantastic causes please go to [ https://www.oxfam.org.uk/ and/or https://www.gwt.org.uk/ ]. 

We are looking forward to updating you with our training and preparations, followed by news and information during the event. 

We would be most grateful for any donations, and to encourage you further, please read below for 11 Facts About Global Poverty. 

Huge thanks in advance. 

Edward, Henry, Louise and Steph


11 Facts About Global Poverty:

1.    
Nearly 1/2 of the world’s population — more than 3 billion people — live on less than $2.50 a day. More than 1.3 billion live in extreme poverty — less than $1.25 a day.

2.    
1 billion children worldwide are living in poverty. According to UNICEF, 22,000 children die each day due to poverty.

3.    
805 million people worldwide do not have enough food to eat. Food banks are especially important in providing food for people that can’t afford it themselves. Run a food drive outside your local grocery store so people in your community have enough to eat.

4.    
More than 750 million people lack adequate access to clean drinking water. Diarrhoea caused by inadequate drinking water, sanitation, and hand hygiene kills an estimated 842,000 people every year globally, or approximately 2,300 people per day.

5.     In 2011, 165 million children under the age 5 were stunted (reduced rate of growth and development) due to chronic malnutrition.

6.     Preventable diseases like diarrhoea and pneumonia
take the lives of 2 million children a year who are too poor to afford proper treatment.

7.    
As of 2013, 21.8 million children
under 1 year of age worldwide had not received the three recommended doses of vaccine against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis.

8.    
1/4 of all humans live without electricity — approximately 1.6 billion people.

9.    
80% of the world population lives on less than $10 a day.

10.
Oxfam estimates that it would take $60 billion annually to end extreme global poverty--that's less than 1/4 the income of the top 100 richest billionaires.

11. The World Food Programme says, “The poor are hungry
and their hunger traps them in poverty.” Hunger is the number one cause of death in the world, killing more than HIV/AIDS, malaria, and tuberculosis combined.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Many thanks to Finn Comfort and Foot Solutions Richmond for providing us with top quality, properly fitted Tibet walking boots. 

https://www.footsolutionsrichmond.co.uk/

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

PAUL - I am doing trailwalker to challenge myself and raise money for  charity in the process. We are aiming for £1400 as a team effort so please donate to this worthy cause.

ZOE - I'm doing this challenge to help and support people in need. I feel Oxfam on the whole does a great job around the world,  I would love to see them in action. It would be great to help re-build lively hoods after day to day crisis, this is my way of giving and challenging myself at the same time and as a way to up my fitness. This is going to be a hard challenge mentally and physically, but very rewarding. Please sponsor me to help us raise our team target of £1400.

PHIL - Some of you may be aware that for several years now I have been constantly over weight and this is my way to focus and kick start the rest of my life as a slimmer person. Trailwalker is the biggest
challenge by far that I have ever undertaken and will help so many other people by helping myself. Please help me raise money to reach our team target of £1400 it would be great to exceed this. Please dig deep and sponsor me so that we can help support the less fortunate.

VICKY - Those of you who know me of old, will know that when growing up I wasn't at all the sporty type. But as the years have passed I've began to enjoy fitness and hate to be second best so put 100% effort into everything I do. I have only become involved in trailwalker if I'm
truly honest because I can't say "no". However now fully aware of the
challenge I am about to undertake and many blisters later, I am more than a little nervous. Trailwalker is a great way in which to challenge yourself individually and also help Oxfam get more pennies in, to support the less fortunate. So please sponsor me guys and help me reach our team target of £1400!!! xx

story:
﻿﻿Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

The Turnaround Kids represented by staff from FRP Advisory and Barclays are once again heading to the South Downs to complete Trailwalker, raising money for Oxfam and the Gurka Welfare Trust to improve lives around the world. 

Trailwalker is the challenge of a lifetime as we walk (or run!) starting on Saturday morning and continuing through the night, covering 100km (62.5 miles) of the South Downs Way in under 30 hours (but hopefully much faster!). Please help us to raise money for a great cause and make all those blisters and sore feet worthwhile.

﻿Our three teams are formed of both Trailwalker legends and Trailwalker new comers, with our first ever all female team walking this year!

story:
Hi All,

Thanks for visiting my Justgiving page, very much appreciated.

For those that know me, you'll understand a 100km walk will be a tough ask, especially my tendency to pick up stitches fulfilling the most basic of tasks, e.g getting out of the bath or walking up the stairs(hence I moved into a bungalow). So why not join me on this painful experience and donate to a great cause in the knowledge that in couple of years they may honour my achievement by creating a film aptly named 'Walk, Fat boy, Walk'

Thank you in advance for your donations, most of you are great friends :-)

Many Thanks,

Chris Jones

story:
In 2016, Craig, Will and I tackled the National Three Peaks challenge and thoroughly enjoyed the experience. 

The time has come for another challenge, and this is definitely a challenge! 100km in 30hrs!  And to show us how it's done, Craig's wife, Tracey, has decided to join us as the fourth member of The Todmorites team.

Raising funds to help fight poverty in Africa and support the families of the Gurkhas, makes this challenge even more worthwhile for us.

We will be cramming lots of training into the next few months in preparation of Trailwalker 2018 which takes place on the 13th July.

The 100km/62mile trek will start at Queen Elizabeth Country Park and follow the South Downs Way to the finish at Brighton Racecourse.

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
A short time ago we decided that walking 100km was a good idea. After some research and little training, we are now not so sure...

We are doing it though. Some of us have bought walking boots and some of us have even done 30-minute leg workouts in preparation for the big day!

It will take around 27 hours for us to complete the walk, without sleep so this is a massive physical and mental challenge not to be done without the proper training. 

Our challenge mum Cathy will be making sure that we complete the course by driving us around, watering us and keeping us generally alive as we make it through the course.

Kathryn, Rick, Scott and Emily are the brave legged people taking on the walk. It will be a test of endurance, but more so of our friendships. It's gonna change us.

Please show your generous support for (us) the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

Donation Rewards!

- Every Donation will receive an on-the-day personalised team selfie!

- For a £20 Donation, you'll get a shout-out on one of our awesome Instagram stories during the event.

- For a £30 Donation, we will perform an action of your request on the walk, filmed and sent to you!

There will be a special reward for the highest donation!

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Susie, Rob, Tom and I are taking part in Trailwalker 2018 to raise money for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust.

Starting on 14 July, our challenge is to walk 100km across the South Downs in 30 hours or under. We'll have 2 support crew members who will meet us at checkpoints along the way to help us reach the finish line.

We've never walked this far before and we're perfectly unprepared...

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty to everyone. In over 70 years they've become world leaders in emergency water and sanitation, and experts in providing shelter, food and protection.

The money that we raise will be split between these two worthy causes and anything that you can give will make a difference.

Thank you!

Saba, Susie, Tom & Rob

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community.

story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our Intake 02 QOGLR JustGiving page.

Intake 02 QOGLR

Each participants taking part in Trailwalker is from the Intake 02, who joined the British Army in the same year 2002, and are from the same regiment, 10 QOGLR. We decided to form up the team for two reasons. Firstly, we would like to raise some fund to support Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. Secondly, we are aiming to bring all numbaries together from across the brigade and stand them together for this good cause.

Just like, "Little drops of water make the mighty ocean", each of your generous hearts helps us to reach our goal. It's not only limited to the numbaries but anyone with a kind heart can be as generous as they like to be. Your generosity will help us to push each step towards accomplishing the goal.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
I signed up to the Edinburgh marathon earlier this year and was looking forward to a challenge in one of my favourite cities in the world. My friends then told me about the Hairy Haggis and pretty soon I found myself committing to a 5k, 10k, half marathon and full marathon all within the space of 2 days. It'll be my longest run yet and I'm going to need all the inspiration I can get to help me round!

Over the last few years I've become more involved with Oxfam both in terms of fund raising and filming projects for them and at every step I've been amazed by the work they do and ambitions they have to help people. 

Last year I took part in the 'Send my Friend to School' campaign. Along with 20 other charities they are aiming to get every child in the world into school by 2030. They already have great support from many countries and, even though the target now looks set to be realised by 2084 at the latest, it's still an incredible ambition. Before that I went with Oxfam to South Sudan and saw first hand the devastating effects of civil war over there. I also went to see their work in the Philippines in the aftermath of typhoon Hyaan, where they were on the ground rebuilding lives the day after the typhoon hit. 

It really is incredible work they do in so many areas, in so many countries, so any help you can give would be very much appreciated. It will also help reassure me that signing up to the Hairy Haggis was a good idea after all!

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
I am making a fool out of myself for charity by learning the TROMBONE!!! Here is a poem I have written to entice you even more to donate to this amazing charity:

My name is Freya, and I'm 5 ft 1 / I've never been known to not get things done

But when I decided to learn the trombone / I thought, 'Oh dear Lord! Let's not hope I'm alone!' 

But thankfully lots of people applied / to learn a new instrument! 'Hooray!', we all cried!

So now I am taking my grade one exam / to help all the people who work at Oxfam

I hope that you think that this poem is great / and my final thing to say is: DONATE!

story:
I signed up to trail walker because, honestly...............

...........I got drunk and agreed to it 😬

But I am so glad I did!!

Before agreeing to take this challenge I’d never even ran 5k before, and now with the help of my team I’m going to do something I never thought I could achieve before. Not only is this going to be the biggest physical challenge of my life to date, but being able to raise money for people in need at the same time is an added incentive.

So please spare some cash to help me achieve my target. If I can drag my chubby backside for 100k I reckon that’s worth a few quid 👍

story:
It's that time of year again for the Manchester University Music Society's Grade-1-athon, an annual event where music students sit a Grade 1 exam on an unfamiliar instrument! Following on from the success (??) of last year, I will try to tackle Grade 3 French Horn for my Grade-1-athon. This is lots of fun for us and, in doing so, we hope to raise as much money as possible for a superb charity - Oxfam. Be generous!

Mae'n amser ar gyfer y Grade-1-athon y Gymdeithas Gerddoriaeth Prifysgol Manceinion, digwyddiad blynyddol lle mae myfyrwyr cerddoriaeth yn sefyll arholiad Gradd 1 ar offeryn anghyfarwydd! Yn dilyn llwyddiant (??) y blwyddyn diwethaf, byddaf yn sefyll arholiad Gradd 3 Corn Ffrengig. Mae hyn yn lawer of hwyl i ni ac, wrth wneud hyn, rydym yn gobeithio codi arian ar gyfer elusen gwych - Oxfam. Byddwch yn hael!

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As you may have already heard, I am taking part in the 2018 Trailwalker Challenge run by Oxfam to raise money for the Gurkha Welfare Trust. If you're not familiar with this charity, a little background story to who and what the Gurkha's are:

The Gurkhas are soldiers from Nepal who are recruited into the British Army, and have been for the last 200 years. Gurkhas are known to be as fearless in combat as they are good natured in daily life.

Roughly 19,000 Gurkha soldiers have died during the many wars they've fought at Britain's side. Many thousands more have been wounded, and more still have returned to a life of hardship in Nepal. 

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provides medical, financial and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and their communities. More information can be found on the website at https://www.gwt.org.uk

The challenge itself is taking place on a 100km route across the South Downs from 13-15 July with a team of 4 of us aiming to finish this monster walk! It's quite easy to underestimate what walking 100km (60 miles) entails. Having just completed our first 30 mile training walk I can tell you that it's a lot of blisters, sore knees and stiff hips! Add in to the mix the element of sleep deprivation from walking right through the night and the fact that we'll have to do double the distance of our longest walk so far.. you start to see that this will be no walk in the park. To put it another way, we'll be walking the distance of 2.3 marathons over terrain with the equivalent elevation of climbing Ben Nevis.. twice.

Any contribution you can make to this great charity is most welcomed, thanks for reading.

Arron

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
I first met Jimmy and Big G in Mexico back in ‘91 and travelled  with them around South America for several months. Jimmy has been walking the Camino in different parts for years and has invited me to give it a go this year. 

It has given me the opportunity to support my friend Dave who has worked his socks off recently as a fund raiser for Oxfam trying to help the charity recover from one of its most challenging times. The work Oxfam does is amazing and I see this as a small contribution to help the charity and to support my friend. Please donate what you can.

story:
Running these 10km means a lot to me. It symbolically means giving a voice to all women on earth. To the one that can’t talk, to the one that won’t dare, to the one that have the courage to do so and deserve to be heard. Yes, I would like to run for us. Because we all matter, we all are unique and powerful. And Yes, it is  important to keep reminding it because words are power and behinds these words lies faith and conviction. Furthermore, we still live in a world where women have too little power given and are still diminished. How many times were women asked if there are (finally) in a relationship instead of being asked what were their dreams and aspirations? Not often enough. How many times were women reminded how important they are? I don’t know about you but it never happened to me. How many times were women truly allowed to express what they feel inside instead of being repressed? 

So, to all women that have lost faith in themselves, to all women that don’t trust their inner power, to all women that still feel repressed, I will run. I will run for us. I will run to get back what we have lost on the way, to be proud of who we are and to keep claiming equality. 

And when the race will be done? I will keep running, always, through my dreams, my aspirations, my words and actions. We will keep inspiring each other and keep working on reclaiming the respect we deserve. 

« Let women be provided with living strength of their own. Let them have the means to attack the world and wrest from it their own subsistence, and their dependence will be abolished. » Simone de Beauvoir. 

I also would like to share this TedTalk link called "We should all be feminist" that I found very inspiring. 

https://www.ted.com/talks/chimamanda_ngozi_adichie_we_should_all_be_feminists?language=fr

For everyone that would like to follow the Facebook page created "A Run for equality" where I put update on how the training is going, you just have to click on the link and like it :)

https://www.facebook.com/A-Run-For-Equality-2060427940841796/

story:
On Saturday 14th July (and hopefully not too much of the Sunday) Sam, Morgan, Dad and I will be setting off on a 100km trek across the South Downs.

Starting as a military training exercise in Hong Kong in 1981, the Trailwalker now takes place annually where participants have a maximum of 30 hours to make it through the course. 

We'll be putting up with blisters, cramps and climbs - not to mention each other. 

We are raising money for The Gurkha Welfare Trust as well as Oxfam; our pledge is to raise £1,500 so any donations would be very much appreciated. 

We've had a few good practise walks already. Night-walking may prove a bit trickier; I fear it may be slightly different to our ambles home after nights out (downside - less kebab stops; bright side - headtorch).

One thing that we are still after is a support crew for the day. If anyone is up for a challenge of a different kind, meeting us at the various checkpoints with supplies then please let us know!

(2Fast2Furious was already taken...)

story:
Hello! My name is Cathie, online I'm known as Lil' Miss. Geek Chic.

This year I am working with Oxfam as a marketing coordinator. Prior to taking on this role I didn't really know a lot about who Oxfam are and what they do, but since working with them I've learned a whole lot more about them, their work and the world.

I started to feel that what I was doing wasn't enough, I wanted to make a contribution to the organisation that would really make a difference... and then I had an idea.

What if I got the Oxfam logo permanently tattooed on my arm?! Well, I'm up for the commitment but I'm going to need some fantastic support from you guys to do it. You can read more about why I am doing this here: http://lilmissgeekchic.com/sponsor-me-to-get-tattooed-with-the-oxfam-logo/

So go on... give generously, you'll change a life.

story:
Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event. 'The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours in a team of four, with a support crew of two members to help to get to the finish line.



Each Trailwalker team pledges to raise £1,400 for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust as part of their challenge. Broken down between all 4 walking team members, this works out at just £350 per person! On average most teams raise in excess of £1,700, so we hope that with your help, I can help my team to achieve our goal!

WHAT YOUR MONEY CAN DO
    
  • Provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Nigeria from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap.
  • Fund a Gurkha Welfare Trust nurse for six months, helping to provide medical aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities.
  • Give six vulnerable Gurkha veterans or widows a year-long welfare pension, enabling them to buy basic food and everyday essentials.
  • Show staff and students at a Bangladesh school how to respond to disaster - making sure they stay safe should the worst happen.

History

Exercise TRAILWALKER started out as a military training exercise in Hong Kong in 1981. Organised by the Queen's Gurkha Signals, and taking place along the famous Maclehose Trail, the exercise sought to test the endurance and teamwork of soldiers of the Queen's Gurkha Signals over a long and arduous course.

In 1986, Trailwalker was opened to civilian participation for the first time, and now, 30 years later, following the move of the Queen's Gurkha Signals to the UK, the 100k event takes place across the South Downs, with hundreds of civilians setting off from the start line alongside the Gurkhas.

story:
4 people – 100km – 30 hours

Described as “the challenge of a lifetime”, Trailwalker is a 100km trek over the South Downs Way in less than 30 hours. I’ve decided to embark on this crazy challenge with three crazy friends: two crazy kiwis, Nicole and Nathan, and a crazy Spaniard, Pol.

This crazy event is organised by Oxfam, and helps raise money for the lovely Gurkha Welfare Trust charity. The Gurkha Welfare Trust was founded in 1969, when it was realised that a great number of Gurkha soldiers and their families in Nepal faced destitution in their old age. Many of these soldiers had served alongside Britain in the Second World War and other conflicts; however they had not served the 15 years needed to qualify for an army pension. The core of the Trust's work has always been the Welfare Pension, which is currently distributed to over 5,500 brave Gurkha veterans and widows. The Trust also offers comprehensive medical and community programmes across Nepal.

You can find out more about the Trust here: https://www.gwt.org.uk/

We’ve been training hard, and we're more than determined to reach the finish line.

story:
Local Music, Global Impact 

Hi- 

In October 2018 an Oxjam Music Festival will come to Hemel for the first time. Oxjam Hemel will be a one day event to showcase local talent and raise as much money as possible for Oxfam.

Local bands, artists and djs will be invited to play a one day multi-venue event, we want to bring the community together to celebrate musical talent in the name of charity. 

To help raise awareness and cover any costs to the event, we will host a couple of fundraisers- including a pub quiz, cake sale and a half marathon attempt on 16/09 (wish me luck). 

Ticket information will be available soon. 

Any money you can donate will go to a fantastic charity doing amazing work across the globe to help end poverty for good.

 Thank you so much for all your help and support,           The Oxjam Hemel Festival Team: Shannon, Dom, & Emily

story:
Team Rato Mato Chiplo Bato

There is a saying in Nepal. Red mud leads to a slippery path. We have chosen this famous saying as our team name because it shows that there is hardship and struggle in life, the path you choose may well be a slippery one.

This 100km journey will embody our group name; metaphorically, spiritually and physically. At the end of this journey we want to say proudly that although the path we travelled was a slippery and difficult one. We persevered and we conquered.

The team

The team consists of 4 people. Aseem, Abinash, Avishek and Chris. We've known each other for a long time and we have a strong team chemistry built over years of friendship. A good foundation is key to success. 

Why did we decide to do this? 

We all share the same background. Being raised up in the army barracks since young, our Gurkha dad's literally being our heros and inspiration, we thought it was our turn to do something for the Gurkha veterans and their family that are facing hardship around the world. 

They supported us and paved our way forward to a brighter future. It is now time for us to stand up for these brave heros and push ourselves every step of the way to achieve our goal.

The money raised from this will be given to the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam. You can read more about these two amazing organisation below. 

https://www.gwt.org.uk

https://www.oxfam.org.uk

Ticking gift aid does not cost you any extra, it's a tax relief so your money and contribution can be increased by 25% without any cost. All by ticking a little box :)

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

May 7th will be my first triathlon. It's only a 'mini' one, or 'sprint triathlon' as the pro would say  (400m swim, 21k cycle, 5k run).  But it's a challenge for me.  I'm glad to say it's one that my middle son, Alex, and his friend Maddie, are joining in on too.

I'm raising funds for Oxfam because I know what good work they do, and that now more than ever funds are needed.  

If you can sponsor anything at all that is truly welcome.  If you instead sign up as a regular supporter of Oxfam, or decide to increase you current subscription, then Ashley Insight will put £20 sponsorship onto this tab for you.  https://www.oxfam.org.uk/donate 

I know some of you will have seen the horrible headlines of what happened in Haiti in 2011.  Oxfam has upfront that what happened was awful, and wrong.   Some people cancelled their support, but there is also a  band of people signing up for the first time or raising their contribution to Oxfam, because they see its work in a wider context.    I've worked inside Oxfam for a year now, and I see how seriously gender justice is taken. And I know it is even more central  going forward.  The irony is that Oxfam is a rare organisation that tries to challenge the deep-rooted barriers women face, such as discriminatory attitudes and violence.  In my own team, we work on projects that support women small scale farmers and shrimp producers with their production and their leadership roles, and also work to challenge social norms that undervalue the unpaid care that women do, or keep them out of economic opportunity.  

Next time around, I will revert to raising funds for deafness or other causes outside of my day job, but this year is a time for solidarity with Oxfam and the people it is helping day by day.

UPDATE MAY 7th

It's done!   Gloriously sunny but hot. The swim was fine, the bike ride not as bad as I feared and actually quite nice at times, and the run was the toughest 5km I've ever done. It was also one of the fastest, but with a mix of fast and plodding stretches.  After endless prep, 2 hours at the pool waiting to start, it was all done and dusted in less than an hour and a half.

Thank you everyone SO much for your support.  I knew on Saturday when I started wondering 'why did I sign up for this' that with so much support there was no question of wobbling.   Your contributions to Oxfam are hugely appreciated and will go to fund very necessary work.


The small print

story:
IMPORTANT: 

EVERYONE THAT SUPPORTS OUR FUNDRAISING EFFORTS MAY CLAIM ONE OF THE EXCITING PROMISES LISTED AT THE BOTTOM OF THIS PAGE! CHECK THEM OUT AND LET US KNOW WHICH YOU WOULD LIKE WHEN YOU MAKE YOUR DONATION!


This July, we will be attempting to trek 100km across the South Downs in less than 30 hours. Woop woop!

This long-distance trek is an exhilarating endurance challenge in which teams of four walk through day and night to raise money for the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam.

After departing at 7am on Saturday 14th July, we hope to cross the finish line before 1pm on Sunday 15th July, with the help of our wonderful support crew meeting us with snacks, hugs and blister plasters at nine check points along the way.

We will be hugely grateful for any and all donations to the fantastic causes we are supporting. So c’mon folks, please dig deep and support us in this crazily exciting challenge!

Big love and even bigger blisters,

Jo, Rosie, Oli and Nancy xxx


A little bit about the charities...

Why the Gurkhas?
Roughly 19,000 Gurkhas have died during the many wars they’ve fought at Britain’s side over the past 200 years. Many thousands have been wounded, and more still have returned to a life of hardship in Nepal. The Gurkha Welfare Trust provides medical, financial and community aid to Gurkha veterans and their families in Nepal.

Why Oxfam?
Oxfam is a global movement fighting poverty around the world. It does this through a combination of rights-based sustainable development programs, public education, campaigns, advocacy, and humanitarian assistance in disasters and conflicts.

NB: Whilst the unscrupulous acts of some disgraceful individuals have tarnished Oxfam’s name, we have chosen to continue supporting it. We believe the vast majority of people working with Oxfam are honourable people doing vital work. The charity is making a huge effort to stamp out abuse (you can view their action plan here https://www.oxfam.org.uk/february-2018-immediate-response-actions-sexual-misconduct ) and, most importantly of all, we want to support Oxfam because of the millions of people across the world who benefit from that vital work. The people in Yemen who, after three years of war, are now being faced with the world’s largest cholera outbreak... More than half a million Rohingya people fleeing to Bangladesh to escape horrendous abuse in Myanmar... 3.8 million people driven from their homes in the Democratic Republic of the Congo… These are just a few examples of those being supported by Oxfam during times of desperate need.


Promises to choose from...

FOR DONATIONS OF £5 OR MORE WE WILL:

- Send you a list of 20 reasons why we love you

- Draw a caricature of you

- Plant a flower in your honour

- Write a personalised poem about how awesome you are

- Play a musical instrument to you (flute, saxophone or guitar)

- Make a word search all about you

FOR DONATIONS OF £10 OR MORE WE WILL:

- Send a chocolate cake to your home

- Perform and record a song of your choice

- Take your dog on an epic walk

- Make a play dough version of you and photograph it at a London landmark of your choice

- Send you your own personalised pet rock

- Send you an interesting book in the post

FOR DONATIONS OF £20 OR MORE WE WILL:

- Sit on top of one of the lions at Trafalgar Square with a picture of your face and a sign saying how awesome you are

- Provide a night of babysitting (number of children unlimited)

- Become your pen pal for one year

- Make you a piece of bespoke pottery

- Write your name across our faces in black marker pen for the whole weekend of the challenge

- Print a picture of your face and carry it on a flag with us for the whole challenge

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
£100 for 100km

We are totally mad but Team Couch to 100km has taken on the challenge!! Please donate, all funds raised will go to the Gurkha Welfare trust and Oxfam. 

Trailwalker is the challenge of a lifetime. As more than 400 teams take on 100km of the South Downs Way next July, they will be helping to end poverty with each step. The money raised will be used by Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust to improve lives around the world.

Oxfam is a movement of millions of people, all working towards one goal - an end to poverty to everyone. In over 70 years we've become world leaders in emergency water and sanitation, and experts in providing shelter, food and protection. 

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community.

story:
We are a group of active mums in Muswell Hill who met through our love of running. 

We are taking on the Trailwalker UK challenge organised by Oxfam - trekking 100km in 30 hours across the South Downs in July 2018.  We will test our endurance to the limit by setting off on the morning of Saturday 14 July north of Portsmouth and hiking continuously (and through the night), arriving in Brighton on Sunday.

This is no mean feat and will require a lot of training, but we love a challenge - they don't call us MMMavericks for nothing.

Please support us in raising funds for Oxfam to alleviate poverty worldwide.
