story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

After years of paddling in the shallow waters of gentler runs, I’ve decided to take the plunge and will be running the Edinburgh Marathon in 2018. I have found running is something that I’ve been able to continue as I get older and, when my wife went through the experience of cancer diagnosis and treatment in 2012, it provided a good therapy for me. It was a time and space to think, pray and sometimes shout (much to the interest of guided busway passengers). When she finished the chemo- and radiotherapy in 2013 I ran a half marathon for Marie Curie.

At the time I thought that was it and I had no further running intentions – I was wrong!  

Heather is now approaching 5 years post-treatment and I am very grateful for her health and the care that she has received from all the great team at Addenbrooke’s Hospital, Cambridge. As a GP in Cambridge I am very aware of the pressures that all medical teams work under in primary and secondary care. I am also very aware of all my patients and the different, challenging and also difficult journeys that we have been making together these past years.

In recognition of all of this I will be running the Marathon in May. Though I have promised to do it without the shouting!

So why Oxfam?

Well, initial links are that we have donated to Oxfam as a charity for some years and that my daughter volunteers in one of the Oxfam
shops in town. But more than that this last year we have been made aware of poverty and injustice more than ever and Oxfam is passionate about tackling that everywhere. Something I hadn’t been aware of is that money raised may be supporting people here in the UK as well as in countries like Ethiopia or Haiti. That global approach is something I wanted to get behind.

I would be so pleased if you could get behind me as I train and run for Oxfam. If you could donate something that would be great. If you can keep an eye on my page and maybe send me a message to encourage my training that would be great too.  Now we see if the doctor can practise what he sometimes preaches!

Thank you for reading this!

Julian.

story:
Welcome to my Trailwalker 2018 page!

We've embarked on this crazy journey to raise money for two very worthy causes - Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. Trekking 100km in 30 hours across the south of England won't be easy, but with training, dedication and a bit of the ol' Kiwi "She'll be right" attitude, we hope we can rise to the challenge and reach our fundraising target of £1,300.

Our team of four comes from diverse backgrounds - a PHD student from Barcelona; a marketing guru from Paris; an engineer from the bustling metropolis of Ashburton; and me, a fairly non-athletic lawyer from Wellington who has never attempted anything like the Trailwalker in her life. But this makes it all the more fun - and there's a first time for everything right?!

A special mention must go to my lovely Dad, who completed Trailwalker NZ 2008 around Lake Taupo at the ripe old age of 51, and who has given us many Trailwalker tips and tricks - and inspiration - from afar.

If you'd like to help us, please click the 'Donate' button and follow the prompts. We would be so grateful for your support!

If you'd like any further information, please get in touch or visit the Oxfam or Trailwalker UK 2018 links on the right hand side of the page.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Please dig deep and donate now.

story:
We are completing the 100k Trailwalker event on the 13th - 15th July where we will aim to complete the gruelling distance within 30 hours. This is ran through Oxfam and also in aid of the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

Dan, Tom, Alfred and Chris have been lifetime friends since school and are coming together to complete this endurance task (and test their friendship to the limit!)

With no walking experience, the task and journey ahead has already proved extremely difficult. The team have undertaken a 37 mile practice walk in the Derbyshire Dales with blisters, swelling, aches, bites, bruises, falls, lost trainers and terrible singing all already under their belt.

It’s clear to see that undertaking this challenge is going to be simply brutal. Walking for 30 hours straight, through into the night, racking up 100k and more steps to break a Fitbit.

We are raising funds that will go towards the amazing Gurkha Trust which you can find more about here https://www.gwt.org.uk and Oxfam which you can find out more about the event here https://www.oxfam.org.uk/trailwalker

We have a target of 1000 pounds and know that every pound donated will give us the boost we need to get through each of those miles! Thank you in advance for your generous support and all the boys encourage you to take on your own challenge!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

On the 14th of July I will be walking 100k (63 miles in old money) along the South Downs way, all in one go, the target being 30 hours. This is a monumental physical and mental challenge, probably tougher than anything I have tried before. I'm not scare at all, honest!

We are raising money for the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam, your generosity in sponsoring me would be truly appreciated.
title: Gary Wellsted - Trailwalker 2018
pageSummary: I am walking 100k (62 miles) in 30 hours
pageSummaryWhat: I am walking 100k (62 miles) in 30 hours

story:
I'm excited to be running the London Marathon in 2018 as part of #TeamOxfam. I decided I wanted to have run the marathon a few years ago but realised that I'll need to actually run it for this to be true...!
It's great to have the opportunity to raise money for such a brilliant cause and I'm extremely grateful for all contributions.

Oxfam is an amazing charity that helps fight poverty around the world.  They get help to people that need it; whether it's an emergency helping with food and water, or one of their long term projects promoting education and schemes that help communities help themselves.  It's a great motivation for me over months of training, and on race day, to know that the relatively small commitment from me will have contributed to helping those that really need it.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

We are committed to hiking 100km across the beautiful South Downs in less than 30 hours.  well thats the plan at least.




In the post Christmas haze it all seemed like a good idea...... and a long way away.  Mid-July, no worries,  plenty of time.  

We'd be grateful for your support  - 10p per km would be great. Double up to 20p per km if we finish without arguing.  Or 10p per metre of strapping, tape and blister plasters we will need.  Or even how many beers we will consume on our training walks (ok,  that's maybe not the point...)  but the simple thing is that any amount however small will go to a great cause and will spur us on even more.

The Oxfam Trailwalker is a gruelling 100km hike in less than 30 hours on a route set by the Gurkhas, who are there to man checkpoints and support the teams throughout.  Each team is made up of 4 walkers and 2 support crew. Its a team event - we have to walk together and finish together.  Our support crew will be meeting us at various checkpoints en route over the 30 hours.



Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

The mission, which we have chosen to accept, is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours. That's more than two Marathons, back-to-back. We blame clever marketing for our acceptance of this challenge - that and our good friend for convincing us this would be a good idea, before pulling out and wishing us 'good luck!'

All joking aside, we are super excited to be taking part in this incredible event for such a worthy cause. From women's rights to water; emergency relief to education; Oxfam's work is making a real difference to the lives of people in poverty. But they need our support to reach more people. By donating today, you can bring hope to people across the globe and create a better future for generations to come.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Thank you so much in advance for your support - we'll certainly need it!

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
On 13-15 July we aim to walk, jog and run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 15 hours in a team of four to support the work of Oxfam as well as the Gurkha Welfare Trust.

Right now, Oxfam are responding to emergencies around the world. 
In Bangladesh, over a million Rohingya people need life-saving assistance and Oxfam are there helping 185,000 people access clean water, sanitation and emergency food supplies. They are also providing emergency assistance in Yemen, where families are on the brink of famine.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust provides financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the Gurkha Community. 

Any donations will be hugely appreciated and will help spur us on as we undergo our training regimes in the upcoming months ahead of this daunting endurance challenge.

Pretty much you are the ones making the difference here, so thanks a MILLION for keeping it awesome!

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Now that I am in my 60th year I have decided to prove that I am not getting
old. On the 14th and 15th July 2018 I am embarking on a 60 mile (100kms) nonstop walk over the South Downs to be completed within 30 hours. It is organised by trailwalker and run by the Gurkhas. In reality I have been in training since 1st January and everything aches………(sometimes where I have not even got places) but I am determined to finish. Apparently I am not allowed to take a horse or two.

I am doing this to raise money for The Ghurkhas ( My Dad who served in Burma in the second world war always said when the Ghurkhas were there you know you were safe) and also Oxfam who I know have had bad press recently but still provide much needed assistance most of the time.

Unfortunately you cannot take a horse with you and in total you climb higher than Ben Nevis and Snowdon put together. Kill me now……

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Sally got us joined to a WhatsApp chat one day about the idea of tackling the Trailwalker 100KM challenge and at the time we all thought yeah no problem! :) So we duly all signed up and now the challenge is on!!

Training is well under way for the BIG event itself on 14th-15th July 2018. Some of the training walks have really not been fun at all with loads of rain and mud, but we've had each other to spur us on!!

The challenge is for us to complete 100KM across the South Downs in under 30 hours as a team of four! The Queen's Gurkhas can complete this course is about 9 hours... reckon it may take us a couple more than them!! ... We've been told there will be a Queen's Gurkhas curry waiting for us at the end. 

We won't want to disappoint our sponsors for this excellent cause and amazing charity do the work it needs to around the world, so please help us with your encouragement however big or small with donations.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
We’re a team of six embarking on a challenge to complete 100k in under 30 hours in the UK south downs this July. Four of us will be walking the distance and two will be providing support along the way. The journey will test our willpower, endurance, mental strength, but most of all our ability to work together as a team to complete this challenge together, to help end poverty in the world. 

The walk is for a charitable organization that provides support for hundreds of thousands of people across the world.

Oxfam https://www.oxfam.org.uk/what-we-do

The Gurkha Welfare Trust https://www.gwt.org.uk/

Will you help my team and I reach our fundraising goal to help those in need? We promise to complete the journey in 24hrs, and have committed ourselves in putting in the necessary training to make this happen.

story:
On the 14th and 15th of July, I'm doing Trailwalker. That's 100 km in 30 hours (gulp), following a set route across the South Downs. Some of the walking will by necessity be at night by head-torch. It might not be raining, but then again...

We are a team of four (also Laura, Ingrid and Jo), raising at least £1400 between us, but we're hoping we can exceed that. Trailwalker is run in aid of Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust, which provides pensions to the veterans, as well as medical and developmental aid to their families and communities in Nepal. Both are amazing causes, which have helped countless people in need over many decades. Please give generously! The money doesn't go to us, but direct to the charities.

Thank you for talking the time to visit my JustGivingPage.

This year I am going to be talking part in my first ultimate long-distance challenge, the Trailwalker for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. My three teammates, myself and many others will have to run, jog or walk 100KM in under 30 hours between 13-15th July.

The reason I have chosen to undertake this challenge this year to support Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust is because, I want to be able to help the many ex-Gurkhas and their widows, living back home in Nepal, that still live in poverty. I served under the British Army as a Gurkha soldier for 20 years and this year I want to help give back to the community that I grew up in. Growing up in a rural village in Nepal I experienced the difficulties of poverty, and so I understand how important charities like Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust are; how big of an impact they can make in a small community.

Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust provide remote villages in Nepal with:
- Financial aid such as welfare pension for ex-Gurkhas and their widows (approximately £70 per month) to buy basic necessities such as food
- Medical aid which has helped over10,000 individuals last year alone
- Water and sanitation that helped bring clean water to more then 21,000 people last year
- School programmes which benefited around 40,000 children living in poverty last year

You can help support me today by donating to my page. No donation is too small!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
Thank you for your support

You can learn more about the Gurkhas here at The Gurkha Welfare Trust https://www.gwt.org.uk website.

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. In just a few weeks time, Teams Totally Logic and Madness! will be embarking on a challenge of a lifetime. 

Trailwalker is billed as the ultimate team endurance event. The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km (60miles) across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours in a team of four, supported by our own support crew and the Queen's Gurkha Signals. Training has already begun!

Our teams have  pledged to raise at least £1,400 each for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust as part of our challenge. We would love to raise much more than that!


Established in 1969, The Gurkha Welfare Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows, and their wider communities are able to live with dignity in Nepal. They achieve this primarily through the provision of financial, medical, and community aid.

Oxfam are one of the world's leading providers of humanitarian aid in emergencies with recognised technical expertise in clean water, public health, food security and the protection of civilians.

Every member of Teams Totally Logic and Madness! are in no doubt that this challenge is going to be like nothing we have ever completed before!  Your support to help us achieve our fundraising target will be really appreciated and help us keep putting one foot in front of the other when the going gets tough. Thank you!


Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Oxjam Wakefield music festival is coming in October 2018!

Donate to help make a charity DIY local music festival possible, all money raised will be donated to Oxfam to support the fight against poverty worldwide. 

The multi-venue festival will take place in Wakefield city centre bringing you an eclectic mix of the best local music and art. Follow us on Social media for updates and find tickets for the event at wegottickets.com

Around the globe, Oxfam works to find practical, innovative ways for people to lift themselves out of poverty and thrive. We save lives and help rebuild livelihoods when crisis strikes. And we campaign so that the voices of the poor influence the local and global decisions that affect them.

We hope to see you at the festival!

WANT TO GET INVOLVED? 

Send us an email oxjamwakefield2018@gmail if you are interested in volunteering, fundraising or if you have any creative ideas!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

The four of us (Adam Strowger, Chris Beal, Chris Barnes and Alex Lilly) will be trekking 100km across the South Downs in (hopefully) under 30 hours to support Oxfam's work addressing the structural causes of poverty and related injustice around the world. 

We're anticipating a tough ride, with Trailwalker testing our minds, bodies, patience and friendship, but with the right boots and a good quantity of cashew nuts, we're going to make it.

We're also predicting a tricky journey to reach our hefty donation target, so any contribution you could make towards our efforts would be greatly appreciated. We'll make sure to keep you updated throughout training and as much as possible on the walk itself. Please help make our blisters worthwhile.

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hi guys, welcome (back!) to our team JustGiving page!

Following on from last year's mammoth effort from the original(ish) Blisters crew (Yasmin, Tash, Anna) we are back with one new recruit (Liz) and with a new aim - complete Trailwalker 2018 in sub 24hrs!….

Trailwalker 2017 saw us raise our target and beyond, completing the task in 26 hrs 13 minutes in some of the worst conditions. We've just about mentally recovered, bodies are back to just about working and the feet have just about healed - except you black toe nail, never you.   

***THE FACTS***

Over the 13th and 14th July 2018 the four of us will walk 100km in 24hrs. The equivalent of 2.5 marathons back to back, 149’000 steps, the total ascent of Snowdon and Ben Nevis combined- 2500m. We have 9 checkpoints along the way where our awesome support crew will be feeding us, wiping our tears and bandaging our feet. We start at Queen Elizabeth Country Park in the Southdowns and finish at Brighton Racecourse the following day- come and support us!

***THE CAUSE***

Now you may be aware of some appalling stories regarding Oxfam that have recently reached the media, we were also gutted to read such horrendous stories however they do not detract from the fantastic job Oxfam have done and the cause we are embarking on this crazy mission for...our goal is to raise £1400 which would provide life-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap.

***THE CHALLENGE***

Most of the team know we can complete the walk, it may have been the hardest thing we've ever done and we may have cried alot (and there's every chance Liz may be rubbish) but this year we ask for your wonderful generosity in sponsoring us not just to finish the race but to complete it in less than a day which will involve a hardcore mental attitude, Yasmin marching us from the front and possibly some running. 

You can follow our journey on Instagram and Facebook @blistersbeforemisters

For corporate sponsorship and all Mister applications please email blistersbeforemisters@hotmail.com

Raised:10%
 

Team target: £1,400.00

Raised so far: £140.00

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page!

On the 27th of October 2018, Oxjam Music Festival is taking over Cowley Road in Oxford! 

One wristband will give you access to multiple venues all day to see dozens of bands play. It is a great opportunity to spend an awesome day while supporting your local music scene and helping to fight poverty and inequality with Oxfam.

Tickets to the event will go on sale soon. But if you can't attend or want to start supporting out fight now, you can donate as little or big (!) as you want thanks to our JustGiving campaign.

Every penny donated could help UK families put a warm meal on their plates every day, give children abroad access to education, provide drinking water to deprived communities, or even open land ownership to women in third-world countries.

Options are endless and 1£ goes a long way. This is why we, volunteers at Oxjam, fight for every day, and your support is paramount! 

You could donate as little as the equivalent of an after-work drink, it would really make a difference! 

To learn more about Oxjam Oxford, visit and like our Facebook page www.facebook.com/OxjamOxfordFestival/ to get all updates about events happening throughout the year and the festival.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Most of the team know we can complete the walk, it may have been the hardest thing we've ever done and we may have cried alot (and there's every chance Liz may be rubbish) but this year we ask for your wonderful generosity in sponsoring us not just to finish the race but to complete it in less than a day which will involve a hardcore mental attitude, Yasmin marching us from the front and possibly some running. 

You can follow our journey on Instagram and Facebook @blistersbeforemisters

For corporate sponsorship and all Mister applications please email blistersbeforemisters@hotmail.com

story:
Oxjam is a festival like no other. It’s a new type of festival.

Not only is it the UK’s largest grassroots music festival, it’s also dedicated to eradicating poverty around the world, with all money raised going to Oxfam. Now that’s something we can all get behind.

Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn’t inevitable. Since the Festival’s inception more than 60,000 musicians have played to an audience of 1.5 million people, raising £2.8 million to support Oxfam’s vital work.

By supporting Oxjam then, you are also supporting your community and your local independent music venues, you’re providing a platform for up and coming musical talent and you are raising money to fight poverty worldwide.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I have not done anything like this before. I mistakenly took the words ‘trail walk’ literally when Glen advertised for people to join him in this challenge back in October last year. I thought at least it’s not running it can’t be that bad. However, upon closer inspection of the elevations between checkpoints and the realisation that 100k equates to 62 miles (2.5 marathons) and having watched countless videos of previous Trailwalkers (last year it rained all day and they looked so miserable) I understand what a huge undertaking this will be. I will appreciate whatever you would like to donate and my promise to you is that I will give it my all - both in the preparation and the completion in under 30 hrs.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Last year a few friends attempted to complete this challenge, but due to injuries and awful weather conditions they unfortunately did not manage it. This year I thought I would give it a go, thinking it's only walking that can't be too hard!!!!!!!!. I have joined the guys from last year and a few others who are determined to beat the challenge, and quickly realised it ain't just walking to the shops and back. After completing some training walks I realised I'm not the fittest person in the world with feet and legs aching and this is walking nowhere near the 100km distance set out in front of us. The walk takes us from Portsmouth to Brighton across country with a 30 hour time limit. Money raised will be shared between the Gurkha welfare trust and oxfham.

This is not an easy challenge so please sponsor me and I will give it my all.

Follow the link to see our challenge in full https://www.oxfam.org.uk/trailwalker

In Christmas of 2013 Foreign Concept, Stray and Xtrah got their heads  together and decided that rather than let some sought after unreleased music sit idle on their hard drives they would put it to use and offer people the chance to download the tracks whilst raising money for charity. 

This year Foreign Concept has gone one step further and we at Critical have all gone through the vaults and put an album together, again for a good cause. This time we have chosen Oxfam. Oxfam is a vibrant global movement of dedicated people fighting poverty. From saving lives and developing projects that put poor people in charge of their lives and livelihoods, to campaigning for change that lasts.

All monies go directly to the charity.

I’ve always felt like we wanted to do something for charity but never been sure what. I enjoy bike riding, and I also enjoy spending time outdoors. As a result, I’ve decided to challenge myself July 2019. Over the course of seven days, I will climb the highest mountains in Scotland, England and Wales. But instead of driving between these peaks, I will be cycling all the way.
I will be cycling approximately 480 miles, In addition to this, the three highest peaks in Britain – Ben Nevis, Scafell Pike and Snowdon – will have me climbing nearly 3000 metres on foot through the landscapes of Scotland, England and Wales. 

I plan to take this event very seriously and train to be able to perform this challenge within the time scale I have set. Oxfam is an amazing charity that helps to fight Poverty across the world and that’s a cause worth any efforts I can give.

Thank you.

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
I live with western priviledge... and have no real concept of the suffering many people in many countries have little choice but to endure. My aim is to one day in the not to distant future travel to some of those countries and  make a physical difference and offer my help in whatever way I can . Until then....my legs suffering for a few hours is a very small price I can pay to lend support and bring some awareness to the fight against poverty and suffering.

 Oxfam is a global movement of millions of people who share the belief that, in a world rich in resources, poverty isn't inevitable. In just 15 years, extreme poverty has been halved. 15 more years and we can end it for good.

To spread that change and make it last, political solutions are also needed to tackle the root causes of poverty and create societies where empowered individuals can thrive. We will always act, we will speak out, and we won't live with poverty.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. 

The team are signed up for another Trailwalker challenge, a100km walk over the South Downs which we are aiming to complete this year in under 22 hours. Last year we were one of the oldest (combined age) teams in the competition.

We are walking to raise money for Oxfam and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. 

Oxfam have had a challenging year. But Oxfam's work is keeping people alive who would otherwise die. Oxfam uses our money to support 65 million people around the world - many of them children - who have had to flee their homes as a result of conflict and are often living in desperate conditions in camps or in the open. Your donation will make a real and rapid difference to people who are suffering badly.

We promise to suffer badly also, but in a very different way, as our penance for asking you once again for your support! All the money goes to Oxfam. None of it goes towards the costs of organising the challlenge which we have paid for through our entry fees.

If you feel able to support us - brilliant and thank you.

story:
Namaste

Firstly  we would like to Thank you so for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page .


Trailwalker (Oxfam) is an annual charity event that requires its  participants to cover the distance of 100km within 30 hours. 

Army spouses from the Regiment (QOGLR) have decided to participate in this life time challenge. The participants in our team- ( QOGLR Ladies -The A Team)  consists of Kabita Gurung, Geeta Rai, Prema Gurung and  Dimple Limbu and   Arpana Gurung (crew support).

Under this trail walk  challenge, we are required to complete 100km courses in less than 30 hours. The complete  route is  farther than 2 marathons, plus the height of Ben Nevis and Snowdon combined together. 

It is certainly not going to be an easy task navigating our way through the very hilly South Downs of England. However, as we are raising funds for the below mentioned charities which are very close to our heart , we will give our 100% and fight till the end.

The two charities we are raising money for are; 

1.     Oxfam.org.uk provides invaluable support to the less fortunate around the world. They are working towards one goal- an end to poverty in everyone.

2.     The Gurkha Welfare trust supports our own heroes, The Gurkhas. They provide financial, medical and development aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities in Nepal as well as welfare advice to the UK Gurkha Community.

Collectively all team members  are aiming to raise £1400 for these charities.  We have made the commitment in regards to time, effort and expense but it is your small financial support that will encourage and help us achieve our goal. So, please do give generously  to this extremely worthwhile and noble cause  and help us meet if not exceed our fund raising target of £ 1400.

No donation is too small. As, the fund raised  will positively impact lives of thousands who are in desperate need of help and support, any amount you donate will be highly appreciated.

Once again, thank you for visiting our page and sponsoring us to help make the world better place to live in for everyone.  


Thanking you in anticipation

QOGLR Ladies

(The A Team)

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my page. I'm gonna tell you a bit about myself.

I made it to the UK just half a year ago, coming from Barcelona. After a month here, I moved to my current home, where I met my flatmates (Camille and Nathan). That was the starting point. The three of us enjoy good challenges and Nathan told us about this event. There was no hesitation. Together with Nicole we formed the team and signed up immediately.

Reckless, one might say. A 100km walk is not an easy stroll in the park. But we are all ready for the challenge. Nevertheless, we can't do it without you. This is not just a walk for fun. We need to fundraise money for the Gurkha Welfare Trust. To know more about what the project is you can check this website: https://www.oxfam.org.uk/trailwalker/fundraising-advice/about-oxfam-and-the-gwt

In short, The Gurkha Welfare Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows, and their wider communities are able to live with dignity in Nepal.

We're getting ready for the challenge, can you help us as well?

story:
﻿﻿﻿﻿Welcome to my Big Day Out!

This year on the 14th of July I'm going to try and walk 100km in less than 20 hours for charity.

I w﻿ill be taking part in the Trailwalker 2018 event, this is an event organised with the Queen's Gurkha Signals which sees teams of 4 people attempt to trek across the South Downs from Petersfield to Brighton In under 30 hours.

I'm hoping to raise at least £700 in support of the Gurkha Welfare Trust, this is an amazing charity supporting Gurkha Veterans and their families in Nepal. Setup in 1969 this charity provides help to 5,500 Gurkha veterans and their widows, many of whom were left destitute after serving with the British army in the 2nd World War and other conflicts.

Please help me by donating to this great charity.﻿

story:
We are 4 friends who accepted a challenge to walk 100km (63 miles) in under 30 hours. This challenge will take place on July 14th-15th, starting at Queen Elizabeth Park, The New Forest & ending at Brighton Racecourse.



We've been training hard - we have suffered blisters, hip pain, knee pain, extreme hunger, rain, scary night walks, mastering farm gates (Kinga) - mastering climbing them (Nicky) but it's all been fun and preparing us for this epic challenge...100km in one day....ahhhhh



The event is organised by Oxfam - raising money to reduce poverty.  We aim to raise £3000 which will help to start 12 farms / small holdings for families.  Providing, food, education, an income & a future for generations to come. 



If you would like to support us please donate via this page.  We will also be running fundraising events in the coming months so keep your eyes peeled for those on our FB or Insta pages.



Thanks for your support - it will make the blisters, painful knees & hips worth it!



Lots of love N,H,K & R x x x x x

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Scrambled Legs will be taking on the Trailwalk challenge of walking 100K (60 miles) in 30 hours  on 14th and 15th July. We start the walk at the Queen Elizabeth Country Park in Portsmouth, walking along the South Downs Way to the finish line at Brighton Racecourse. The main objective for taking on this challenge is to raise essential funds for charity, but also for other reasons too - personal challenges, camaraderie, fond memories and endurance training. There will probably be a few occasions along the walk we will want to forget! 

We have a tough 15 week training programme leading up to the main event, and need to ready to walk 100K, assisted by our support crew, who will meet us at each check point and be responsible for keeping us physically and emotionally upbeat throughout the 30 hours! 

We are raising money and awareness for Oxfam UK and the Gurkha Welfare Trust. Oxfam is a global movement of people, all working together for one goal - an end to poverty for everyone. The Gurkha Welfare Trust provides financial, medical and development aid to ex-Gurkha servicemen and their communities in Nepal.

You will be able to track the progress of Scrambled Legs throughout the 30 hours, and we are aiming to finish the event in 27 hours. I am sure you will appreciate this challenge is going to be the toughest any of us have done. We start at 10am Saturday morning and hopefully will be complete by 1pm on the Sunday, walking through the night, with tight target times at each check point to enable us to continue the event in the maximum time allowed of 30 hours, with no sleep!

Please consider how you can support us, by donating and sharing our journey with your friends and contacts on social media.

Thanks in anticipation 

Cheryl, Martina, Eric and Laura - Scrambled Legs 

Support crew: Tanya Norris, Andy Hunter, Liz Kapusta and Claire/Niamh Hunter

story:
Hello folks,

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Me and my friends - colleagues - are taking the Trailwalker challenge once again this year. It is a 100km walk across rolling hills of South Downs in England which has to be completed within maximum 30 hours. We are going to walk non-stop through the night, with just short breaks, and no matter the weather conditions are. Last year it took us amazing 27 hours and 27 minutes to complete the walk, and this year we aim to be even better.

If you think it's a brave and challenging thing to do....maybe something you don't think you could do yourself, and if you perhaps admire our decision and determination, please support our team ''Shovel Monkeys'' and donate ANY amount of money. ANYTHING is highly appreciated and EVERYTHING goes to support the Ghurkas in Nepal.

You can also easily donate via TEXT MESSAGE - just send a text SHOV81 £5 to number 70070.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event. The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours in a team of four, with a support crew of two members to help to get to the finish line.

Story

A short time ago we decided that walking 100km was a good idea. After some research and little training, we are now not so sure...LOL

We are doing it though. Some of us have bought walking boots and some of us have even done 60-minute leg workouts in preparation for the big day!

It will take around 20-25 hours for us to complete the walk, without sleep so this is a massive physical and mental challenge not to be done without the proper training!!!! 

On our challenge, trainer/coach/manager Mr Pramod will be making sure that we complete the course by driving us around, watering us and keeping us generally alive as we make it through the course.

Shamir, Kul, Varsha and me are the brave legged people taking on the walk. It will be a test of endurance, but more so of our friendships. It's gonna change us. We are very motivated to take on this ultimate challenge. We will be walking, jogging, running and if needed crawling to complete our pledge. So please stick behind and support us.

WHAT YOUR MONEY CAN DO with Gurkha welfare trust.

  • Provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterborne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap.
  • Fund a Gurkha Welfare Trust nurse for six months, helping to provide medical aid to Gurkha veterans, their families and communities.
  • Give six vulnerable Gurkha veterans or widows a year-long welfare pension, enabling them to buy basic food and everyday essentials.
  • Show staff and students at a Bangladesh school how to respond to disaster - making sure they stay safe should the worst happen.

so, please dig deep and donate. 

Donation Rewards!

- Every Donation will receive an on-the-day personalised team selfie!

- For a £20 Donation, you'll get a shout-out on one of our awesome Instagram and snapchat stories during the event.

- For a £30 Donation, we will perform an action of your request on the walk, filmed and sent to you!

There will be a special reward for the highest donation!

story:
Since spring 2017 a staggering 18.8 million - 70 per cent of Yemen's  population - are suffering from food insecurity and acute malnutrition. 

The famine is being compounded by Yemen facing the world’s worst ever recorded cholera outbreak, which has spread across the war-ravaged country.  More than 1 million cases have been reported and over 2,200 people have died since the start of the epidemic.

I will be working with Oxfam GB to help raise money for delivering aid for the people in Yemen. Between July 22nd - 23rd 2018, I will be participating in a '40 hour famine' - no food and water for 40 hours. 

I kindly ask all who are willing to support me to donate what you can. Millions of Yemenis are in desperate need of help, but your donations can help bring food and water to families in crisis. 

Thank you!

story:
We're mad, getting older, but still able and most of all, we like a challenge. Back in December some mad fool had the idea to suggest to his mates that we all take part in the Oxfam Trailwalker 100KM challenge.

Trailwalker is the ultimate team endurance event. 'The challenge is to walk, jog or run 100km across the South Downs Way in under 30 hours in a team of four, with a support crew of two members to help you get to the finish line.

We are entering two teams. 

"Brighton or Bust" sees a total Romsey contingent of Peter "Chubb" Robinson, John Fahey, Simon Haythornthwaite and Mark Hutchings. 

"Four Walkers & a Funeral' which includes Rod Clark, Chris Lloyd-Tunstall, Ian Davies and Mark Fower. 

Such an extreme challenge cannot be completed without a Support Team. We owe great thanks to our very own Kings of Logistics, Richard Hughes, Mike Feast and Tony Godleman.

Starting at Queen Elizabeth Country Park near Petersfield, the Trailwalker route will take us along the South Downs Way to the finish line at Brighton Racecourse at which point we will be hungry enough to eat our own walking socks, hallucinating due to lack of sleep not to mention a 30 hour period without visiting a pub. Yes, it's a challenge for us middle-aged men of Hampshire.

Each team needs to raise £1400 in order to be considered worthy of this challenge, and to get a T-shirt of course ; )

If any Business owners out there would like to donate by company cheque (do they still exist?) then get in touch and I'll give you the necessary details.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Love you all and thank you for your support !

Oxfam Trailwalker 13 - 15 July 2018

charity.description: Oxfam is a global movement of people who won’t live with the injustice of poverty. Together we save lives in disasters. We help people build better lives for themselves. We speak out on the big issues, like inequality and climate change. And we won’t stop until we end poverty for everyone. Join us
charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hi Everyone,

Lets talk about a challenge!

On 15th July 2018, myself and three team mates will be walking 100 Kilometers to raise money and awareness for Oxfam UK and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Oxfam Trailwalker begins at Queen Elizabeth Country Park passes through stunning but challenging terrain of South Downs National Park and finishes at Brighton Racecourse.

Teams of four enter this event and have 30 hours to walk or run the 100 km trail, although our team is hoping to finish within 20 hours. It’s very likely that we’ll walk through the night (with little or no sleep) until the end. The event raises vital funds for Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. The Gurkha welfare trust is a charity that provides financial, medical and community aid to ex-Gurkha servicemen and their communities in Nepal.

My team "GasPanic" is hoping to raise funds to help some of the world’s poorest people. Our fundraising campaign will also enable Oxfam to respond immediately to emergencies around the world, as well as to fight poverty at its roots by campaigning against injustice and empowering people with life-changing projects.

My Trailwalker team members and I will be going the distance and we hope that you can support us in this massive challenge. Please consider how you may be able to get behind us, either by donating us or sharing our journey with your contacts in social media. If you would like to support us then please find more information about our goals and activities on this page and where to donate for this good cause.

100 km is a long way to walk! But putting ourselves through months of intense training will be worth it for the impact our fundraising has on others through Oxfam & The Gurkha Welfare trust. Your support is what will take me and my teammates over that finish line.

We ask you to please give generously and consider that your donation will make a real difference.

Thank you!

Yogen

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Last year I set myself the challenge of running two 10k's and a 20k for MacMillan. Due to health issues, I only completed half of the first 10k in March, managed to run the June one in good time but was not fit enough for the 20k. So this year I am taking it easy - 100k walk in under 30 hours. Then maybe I will re-visit the 20k, who knows!

The training has been fun so far but the 30hrs will be a challenge, so here is why I am doing it:

Oxfam has raised funds over the last 12 months which have:

- provided responses to climate changes for 85,000 people
- helped 350,000 people improve their crops, goods and services
- helped 2 million people get clean, safe water and sanitation
- helped 500,000 women increase their ownership of land/assets
- supported 9 million people in 31 humanitarian emergencies.

Funds from the walk also go to the Gurkha Welfare trust, which in 2016-17:
 - gave pensions to 6000 impoverished veterans or widows
 - hosted seven medical camps treating over 18,000 people
 - built/repaired schools for 40,000 children
 - piped drinking water to homes for over 20,000 people
 - built 1000 earthquake-resistant homes and repaired 300 more.

Thank you for your support.

Looking for a challenge for 2018, this landed in my lap. I mulled it over for a few days, joined and then tried to back out! 

Emily and Anna were having none of it. “Our goal is to finish” they said. “You’ll feel great afterwards” they said.

When Emily invited me to join the team I barely hesitated. It was only a week later that the enormity of the challenge dawned on me. I am now terrified and excited in equal measure but at least my thighs if not my feet have already benefited.

Bring on the walks in the rain, slightly hysterical banter, heartfelt support and advice, navigational mishaps, and elation at challenges both big and small being tackled and overcome (anyone who has ever seen me climb a fence will know that there will be many), all to support Oxfam and the incomparable Gurkas who, incidentally have completed the challenge in under 10 hours.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I'm not quite sure how but I have ended up as part of a team taking part in a long distance walking endurance event this July. As a team of 4 and with a support crew of 2 we have 30 hours to walk 60 miles from Petersfield to Brighton. 

We are raising money for two great causes - Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust so if you could spare us a quid or forego your daily Costa today and donate to my page instead you would be my hero. 

If you are about to click on the "donate" button to sponsor my mid life crisis then thank you! Oxfam, The Gurkhas and our team are very, very grateful.

If you are unable to donate then we would welcome any messages of support to get us through the dark times we know will come at some point during the event!! Thanks for reading xx

story:
Thank you for taking time to visit my JustGiving page.

Our wonderful friend, David had the privilege of serving with the Gurkhas, including some time living in Nepal.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust with Oxfam organise the Trailwalker 100 km across the South Downs. Our challenge, as a team of 4, is to complete the 100km (~63 miles) in less than 30 hours. In doing so we hope to raise as much as we can to invest back into the Gurkhas and into rebuilding Nepal, where they are still recovering from the 2015 earthquake.

So, thank you for anything that you can give us to inspire us through our 100km!

Best wishes

Rob & the team

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I will be attempting to complete the challenge of my life... a 100 km walk/run to be completed within a continuous 30 hour period. I have teamed up with three other individuals to complete this epic journey which starts at Queen Elizabeth Country Park and ends at Brighton Racecourse.

The first charity I’ll be raising money for is Oxfam. It is one of the world's leading providers of humanitarian aid in emergencies with recognised technical expertise in clean water, public health, food security and the protection of civilians. When an emergency happens, Oxfam are there to respond. Right now, Oxfam are responding. And we couldn't do it without the vital funds from incredible supporters like you.

The second charity I’ll be raising money for is The Ghurka Welfare Trust. Established in 1969, The Gurkha Welfare Trust exists to ensure that Gurkha veterans, their widows, and their wider communities are able to live with dignity in Nepal. They achieve this primarily through the provision of financial, medical, and community aid.

These charities are providing provisions around the world which are helping the families and individuals who are in dire need of support. Without these organisations, we are one step further away from curing world poverty. I’ll be pushing my body to the limits. It’s going to be a true test of my endurance, and most importantly mental strength. So please, look to support those in need. Every penny counts.

Thank you for your donations :).

charity.name: Oxfam
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
We (Aleks, Alice, Brian and Heather) will be attempting to walk 100k in 30 hours, hopefully a bit less!

We'll start at around 7am and make our way across the South Downs to Brighton.    By the power of cereal bars and Jelly Beans we will walk all day and through the night before a sprint  (yeah right) to the finish line on Brighton Racecourse.

The course record is a mind-bending 9 hours and 50mins held by the Queen's Own Gurkha Logistics Regiment.  Our target is simply to finish in the time permitted and as a team.    

The four of us first walked together with our dogs in Sierra Leone, which is where the team names comes from.   Only a few kms and with a beer on the beach at the end this will be a very different walk.   100km is far too much for the dogs but they will be supporting us in our training.

We're all excited about this challenge and supporting two great causes, the Gurkha Welfare Trust and Oxfam.  The Gurkha Welfare Trust is a fantastic charity supporting Gurkha veterans as well as their families and communities.  The opportunity to support this charity is particularly important to Alice and Heather who had the privilege of living and working closely with Gurkhas while in Afghanistan and Iraq.

We'd really appreciate your support.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hello!

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We are an international groups of friends living in the UK and wanted to do some fundraising for charity this year. We decided on the Trailwalker event because it is also a personal physical and mental challenge for us as well as a good cause to fight for.

The Oxfam Trailwalker GB event supports Oxfam and The Gurkha Welfare Trust. These charities support projects to fight against poverty, for development and support in humanitarian emergencies. 

Gurkha soldiers and their families in Nepal often face destitution in their old age. The Gurkha Welfare trust supports these Gurkha veterans, their dependants and their communities to live their lives with dignity in Nepal.

What can your money do? With our minimum team target you can contribute to provide live-saving hygiene kits to protect 241 parents and children in Niger from waterbourne disease. Kits include water purification tablets, safe water storage, cups and soap. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We are Trekking 100km non stop across the South Downs in under 30 hours to help end poverty with Oxfam and the Ghurka Welfare Trust.

Oxfam works with others to overcome poverty, injustice and suffering around the world. You'll be helping to make that work possible. Our work breaks down into three overlapping areas, all of which are vital to achieving our aims.

The Gurkha Welfare Trust was founded in 1969, when it was realised that a great number of Gurkha soldiers and their families in Nepal faced destitution in their old age. Many of these soldiers had served alongside Britain in the Second World War and other conflicts; however they had not served the 15 years needed to qualify for an army pension.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
A new type of music festival that is part of Oxfam’s rich musical history. This one will be held in our own very local town! Tunbridge Wells.

Oxjam started 2006 with the aim of creating a network of music-loving people across the UK, all united by a shared goal – to raise money to fight poverty and suffering around the world.

It’s a community festival run by volunteers and made up of multi-venue festivals and gigs taking place across the UK throughout October. It’s all about supporting independent music venues and providing a platform for up and coming musical talent while raising money to fight poverty and inequality worldwide. Now that’s something we can all get behind.

Since 2006 we’ve gone on to host more than 60,000 musicians playing to an audience of 1.5 million people, and have helped break bands such as Everything Everything, Foals, Young Fathers and Drenge. We’ve also had backing from the likes of Metronomy, Annie Mac, Mr Jukes and Fatboy Slim.

charity.description: Imperial College London is a world leading, science based university, whose research explores the interface between science, medicine, engineering and management to deliver practical solutions.The Faculty of Medicine is a centre of excellence in research, development and teaching, and aims to improve patient care in associated NHS Trust hospitals.
charity.name: Imperial College
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

SCI needs as little as 50 pence per person per year to treat children and at risk adults for the neglected tropical diseases schistosomiasis and soil tranmitted helminths in Africa.

Treatment for schistosomiasis (SCH) and soil transmitted helminths (STH - whipworm, hookworm, roundworm), prevents anaemia, impaired growth and development in children and the development of life-threatening conditions of bladder cancer, kidney malfunction or liver and spleen damage.

SCI assists Ministries of Health across sub-Saharan Africa to control and then eliminate schistosomiasis and STH from their population utilising the World Health Organization’s Drug Donation Programme for praziquantel and albendazole. 230 million people, one-third of the total population of Africa, need a regular annual treatment of praziquantel, and 400 million people need a regular annual treatment of albendazole, to eliminate these parasitic diseases from their bodies (map – Distribution of NTDs in Africa).

SCI needs as little as 50 pence per person per year, to facilitate delivery of treatments in Africa.

Treating NTDs is a ‘best buy’ in public health according to The World Health Organization (WHO).

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
We are climbing to the summit of Africa’s greatest peak (all 5,895 meters/19,341 feet!) to raise funds to stop people going blind from avoidable causes such as Cataract, River Blindness and Trachoma.

We are climbing to the summit of Africa’s greatest peak (all 5,895 meters/19,341 feet!) to raise funds to stop people going blind from avoidable causes such as Cataract, River Blindness and Trachoma.

Having seen first-hand the impact of these devastating eye diseases and conditions through our work at Sightsavers, we decided to take on this gruelling challenge with our partner organisation, Standard Chartered. We thought that trekking for 7 days at high altitude, with only a month to train, would be a fitting way to show our dedication to the cause

There are 253 million visually impaired people worldwide yet 80% of blindness can be treated or prevented. Seeing is Believing (SiB) was launched in 2003 as an initiative of Standard Chartered Bank to prevent, treat and cure blindness across the globe. The Bank partnered with the International Agency for the Prevention of Blindness (IAPB) and leading international eye-care non-governmental organisations – including Sightsavers - to improve access to eye-care in communities where help is most needed.

Since starting in 2003, SiB projects have reached over 150.3 million people and helped prevent blindness by funding more than 160 eye-care projects in poor communities globally. The Bank has committed to raising USD100 million for SiB through fundraising and matching all public donations dollar for dollar.

Our international team comprises Bjorn, our Regional Finance Manager for East, Central and Southern Africa, Ziporah our Research Advisor  based in our Kenya office and Taome our Social Media Officer in our UK office

It costs very little to protect someone’s sight so, no matter how big or small, your donation will make a huge impact.

35p will treat or protect 1 person from blinding trachoma.

£8 will fund an operation to stop the pain and suffering of someone with advanced trachoma and save their sight.

£30 could pay for a sight-saving life-changing cataract operation.

£140 protects an entire community against the threat of trachoma.

All donations from UK residence will be kindly matched by the UK government from the 9 October 2017 to 9 January 2018!

All donations from UK residence will be kindly matched by the UK government

 
So please donate what you can to support our efforts. We would all be very grateful indeed for your support.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Beauty is in the eyes of the beholder but what if the beholder didn't have sight!?

Without eyesight I can only imagine how someone would feel... Angry, Devastated, Afraid, Frustrated, Isolated, Alone, Different, Lost, Confused.... These are just a few of the many emotions blind people and their parents feel when their child is diagnosed with a lifelong eye condition.

The beauty of this world is felt by the heart but seen by eyes. I believe no-one should be denied this independence, this basic human sense or jewel of the body, if something can be done to rectify it.

“There are only two ways to live your life. One is as though nothing is a miracle. The other is as though everything is a miracle” and I believe that every dream can come true with hard work and determination. My name is Sehrish Zafar and I am an entertainment journalist and a TV Presenter. I understand it is not easy to encourage people to think optimistically, so that's where my charismatic personality and charm can help inspire people to make a difference in the society.

I am currently a freelance TV Presenter for various UK asian channels; I host at many stage events: fashion, charity, political and award ceremonies especially within our community. I am a graduate of BA Business Management and an award holder of 'Miss Perfect' at college.

Other achievements include fundraising for charities like Save the Children, Ucare Foundation; working as an Events Director of Pakistan Youth Foundation - Organised dinner events for Pakistani politicians, protests against Burma and Gaza Killings, promoted local community cultural music events, visited House of Commons and Pakistan High Commission on many occasions to support our community.

As I have selflessly helped support the dreams of others and those of my community, I hope I will continue to receive the help and support I seek to fundraise for those in need the most. I am fasting in aid of Sightsavers and your generous support in this great cause will aid me to do more for the ones who need the help most. 

 

Sightsavers believes that no one should be blind from avoidable causes, and that people’s whose sight can’t be saved should live with dignity and independence.

 

Did you know?

There are 39 million blind people in the world

80% of blindness can be prevented or cured

Around 90% of visually impaired people live in the world’s poorest countries

So the problems Sightsavers are trying to tackle are pretty enormous.

 

So please dig deep and donate now.

 

Thank you,

Sehrish

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hiii,

Those who know me already know my story for those who don't here it is....

I was diagnosed with right homonymous hemianopia when I was 19. This is a visual field loss on the same side of both eyes. In my case it was caused by a stroke. Dispite this happening I still finished college and continued working with the support of my family and friends. It has had a huge impact on my life, i won't ever be able to drive although before being diagnosed I wasn't aware of how serious my sight loss was I had taken lessons and failed my practical test 6 times! Yes how embarrassing lol. My stroke was a silent stroke it could have happened at any time. 6 years later leading us to now I have a heart monitor implant because I randomly black out. So this is just a little way of helping others.

Although my sight cannot be regained there are people who are struggling with sight loss daily who can actually be helped. 

All I ask is for people to donate as little as a £1 to help save someone's sight.  

£12 - could protect 35 families from river blindness a year!

 £28 - Could pay for a  cataract operation and give someone their sight back! 

£140 - Could treat and protect an entire village from trachoma! 

Just a few examples of what your money could be doing. If you wouldn't hesitate to help me if I could get my sight back please don't hesitate to help others. 

Thank you in advance for anyone that donates it means more than words can express.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
On 1st June 2018 I will be setting off with my daughter, Olivia, to cycle from home, near Bristol, to Land's End and back - a distance of around 475 miles over 8 days. I am 61, Olivia is 22. 

In September last year I suffered a torn retina, which was repaired by wonderful staff at Bristol Eye Hospital. It gave me an insight into the devastating effect loss of vision can have on ones life. 

In January last year, whilst visiting a village on the Mekong River in Laos, I saw a young boy who had a vision defect that resulted in him being excluded by his fellow peers and destined to a life of poverty.  A simple operation would remedy that defect and allow him to lead a full and active life as he grows up in his village. 

Sight Savers delivers that treatment to those like him and thousands of others.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

80 per cent of all blindness could be prevented or cured. It is a staggering statistic: that’s over 31 million people, most of whom live in the poorest countries in the world. And with poverty being both a cause and effect of blindness, a cycle is created that can be hard for communities to break out of.

Sightsavers wants to eliminate avoidable blindness and get equality for people with disabilities. They help blind people to see, prevent others from going blind unnecessarily, and support people to live independently if their sight loss can’t be undone.

The causes of avoidable blindness go further than eye disease, so Sightsavers doesn’t just slap a sticking-plaster on the problem – they campaign to make a fairer world and change lives for the long term, helping to eliminate avoidable blindness and get equality for people with disabilities. Help us to support Sightsavers in this incredible cause.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Phoebe was born with very dense cataracts covering  both eyes, at just 8 weeks old she underwent surgery to both eyes. With fantastic opthalmolagists looking after her, she has been given the very best chance in leading her life with vision. 

We are fortunate enough to have access to an amazing eye hospital and fantastic doctors who have taken care of Phoebe since she was born. Sadly, not everyone is as lucky and there are children in the underdeveloped world, who’s sight cannot develop without this surgery. 

We want to pay it forward and help as many children who aren’t as fortunate as our little girl.

Cataracts are the leading cause of blindness around the world. £5 is all it takes to give the gift of sight to a child.

Our initial goal is to support  children around the world and give them the same chance to regain their vision as we were able to do for Phoebe.

Your donations are very much appreciated and will go directly to sightsavers. You’ll get some lovely homemade cake in return 🍰❤️🍰

story:
I will be undertaking a mammoth trek of 100km from London to Brighton in 24 hours. Some of you may remember I did this some years ago, but  completed the trek slower than my target time of 24 hours, due to awful weather and blisters the size of cocktail sausages. So a few years older, fatter and creakier, I have foolishly decided to have another go. 

Now my knees, back and ankles aren't so good, and I often make an "oof" noise when I get out of a low chair, but I am determined to finish in under 24 hours. I will be supporting Sightsavers, whose work fighting avoidable blindness and supporting people with disabilities I whole-heartedly believe in (I do work for them, after all).

So please give generously if you can, and take comfort in the fact that I haven't asked you to do this with me...

story:
There are 39 million blind people in the world.  80% of blindness can be prevented or cured. The gift of sight has far-reaching benefits for the individual and their family.

Sightsavers tackles the main causes of avoidable blindness including trachoma and cataracts.  It costs just £8 for a trachoma operation to stop someone from going blind, and £28 for an adult cataract operation to give someone their sight back!

A donation to Sightsavers would make a wonderful wedding gift for Joel and Elsa!

charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thank you to all who supported the Cake and Samosa sale, we did amazing!!! Together, your efforts will transform so many lives. Each one of you is truly awesome and I have been blown away by your generosity, not just with donations but with the time you have dedicated and support :D

We are organising and hoping to cycle from London to Paris to try raise awareness and funds for sightsavers. Most of us are lucky enough to conceive/see, so we are able to carry out basic tasks and live independently. We can dream, empower and be included, but unfortunately some members of our human family are struck by preventable blindness which leaves them detached and in most instances trapped in inconceivable poverty. Mobility not just physical but social and economical is lost to blindness. 

We are therefore hoping that we can in someway help lift this veil of blindness so on a practical level, we can help make people more independent physically and this will filter through to all aspects of their life.

Our only motivation is Hope - that our actions and contributions can help and will make a difference.  Small steps may lead to others to  see rainbows, the raw world in all it's vividness. So, we hope, restoring vision will  provide opportunity to others to experience all that we do on a daily basis. Have the same chance. Just like when we awake, open our eyes  and let the world pour into us, we can also others to experience this too.

We appreciate and thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page. We take this step with all of you in our minds as it is our actions together that crystalise in a power that makes a change. Your donations is what will lead to the real difference. 

As always, peace to you all x
title: Cycling from London to Paree for Sightsavers
Name: Cycling from London to Paree for Sightsavers

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Sightsavers believes that no one should be blind from avoidable causes, and that people whose sight can’t be saved should live with dignity and independence.


There are 39 million blind people in the world, 80% of blindness can be prevented or cured, and around 90% of visually impaired people live in the world’s poorest countries.


Sightsavers tackle the main causes of avoidable blindness, and work to  educate, enable social inclusion, and help affected communities.


Watch the Sightsavers TV advert to see the faces of children when they receive a simple operation that enables them to see for the first time. It costs just £120, but that is beyond the reach of many in the poorest communities across the world.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
What's my challenge?

  • I'll be trekking up Mount Kilimanjaro (Tanzania) ideally to the summit at 5.895km above sea level (and down again) this June, 2018, covering about 62km over 6 days and 5 nights. Challenge accepted!

Which charity am I fund raising for?

  • Sightsavers.  A UK registered charity founded in England in 1950.
  • I've been donating to Sightsavers for a couple of years.
  • All donations will go to Sightsavers - I will be paying all expenses, either directly or through Action Challenge which will be organising the trek.

What does Sightsavers do?

  • Sightsavers aims to prevent avoidable blindness by funding operations for people who need them, training eye care workers and surgeons. Through community volunteers in developing countries, Sightsavers arranges for medication to be distributed to prevent blinding diseases. Treating among other conditions:
  • cataracts - in developing countries it’s a huge problem for children (as well as older people) - cataracts are thought to cause up to 60% of blindness in parts of Africa, and 20 million people worldwide are blind because of the condition,
  • neglected tropical diseases (parasitic and bacterial infections that affect more than a billion people worldwide, causing severe and often lifelong physical impairment and affect some of the world’s poorest people, trapping them in a cycle of poverty and social isolation),
  • refractive errors.
  • Sightsavers also supports equality for people with disabilities and campaigns and advocates for change.
What will the trek entail?

  • Day 1: trek 11km through lush rain forest to Machame camp at 3km above sea level. 
  • Day 2: trek 5km across moorland but gaining altitude by making camp at 3.8km above sea level. 
  • Day 3 entails an 11km trek across barren semi-dessert, reaching 4.6km in altitude before descending to 4km to make camp. 
  • Day 4: after a 9km trek we sleep at Barafu Camp at 4.7m high (“barafu” being Swahili for “ice”). 
  • Day 5: starting at midnight, we start the 5km trek to the Uhuru Peak (Swahili for “freedom”) 5.9km above sea level to see the sun rise, before descending to camp for the last night on Kilimanjaro.
  • Day 6: descending down the Mweka route to a well deserved beer and much needed shower!

How your donation can help?

  • For every £1 Sightsavers receives, including donated supplies, 91p goes on vital charity work and the remainder helps grow awareness and funding.
  • £5 could help 14 people for trachoma, 
  • £28 could protect a whole community against river blindness, 
  • £50 could provide a cataract operation to restore a childs sight.
﻿﻿And finally...

  • whilst I’m concerned about how I’ll handle the altitude on Kilimanjaro, I think my biggest challenge will be the fund raising. 
  • Thank you kindly for making time to visit my fund raising page (and reading my “essay”) and donating to Sightsavers to help make a change. 

Bhav.


P.s. 

  • If you’d like to leave your name I’d like to thank you personally.  I hope to update this page (and social media eventually) with progress updates nearer June. 

How you can donate efficiently:

  • UK tax payers can tick the Gift Aid box to ensure that JustGiving recovers the tax you’ve already paid on your donation for Sightsavers.
  • Please also keep a record of your donation for your Self Assessment tax return where applicable.
  • Donations from companies may not recover Gift Aid, but may be a business expense.

A web link to Sightsavers home page is further down...
title: Bhavik Takes On Kilimanjaro
Name: Bhavik Takes On Kilimanjaro

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I’m running the Conakry 12km again but this year to raise money for equipment for the SOGUE (meaning “sun”) blind school in Conakry.  The school was founded in 2002 and has 45 children - 15 girls and 30 boys.  The funds raised will buy learning tools such as braille paper, slates, letters, styluses and cubarithmes. With these we hope to contribute a little more light to the lives of visually impaired children in this developing country.  

As ever I thought hard about  running the half marathon, but Conakry’s 30+ degree heat and high humidity beats me every time and I’ve decided that 12km is still my limit. 

I’ll be contributing through Sightsavers UK who have agreed to collect your contributions and donate them specifically to the SOGUE school. In Guinea Sightsavers are working on Neglected Tropical Diseases (NTDs) some of which are diseases of the  eyes such as River Blindness. I know the Sightsavers team here well and am certain that they will squeeze the maximum value for the school from even the smallest amounts of support.  

Sightsavers UK’s overall mission is to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote equality of opportunity for people with disabilities, and they work in over 30 countries.  In 2017 they hit a record 1 billion NTD treatments  across the world - a phenomenal milestone.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Along with four great friends, all racing towards our forties, I have
taken the decision to run the Brighton Marathon and tick off a massive
challenge from my bucket list.

﻿I have decided to run the marathon for Sightsavers.  This is a
fantastic charity which was incredibly well publicised when I was a child, but less known today.  They work tirelessly to eliminate avoidable blindness and promote the rights of people with disabilities in less developed countries.

There are so many deserving charities, it was hard to choose who to support.  One of the main factors which helped me decide to run for this charity was that a family member used to work for Sightsavers.  Last year at the age of just 31 she was diagnosed with cancer and sadly passed away.  Please support Sight Savers in her memory and "live like CT".

I am not a runner.  I'm certainly not built for it, so please, please, please, dig deep and sponsor me for this great cause.

charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
I did it! The picture above is at mile 17 with just 9 miles to go. Blow by blow account in updates section below but it was not pretty with a hamstring injury and cramps and 80 minutes slower than my last attempt in 2014. But together we have raised over £6,500 (inclusive of gift aid) for Sightsavers which is truly amazing. Thank you so much. 

I turned 60 this February and wanted to celebrate this by running to support this great charity. This was my sixth London marathon since my wife and kids told me (with good justification) in my mid-40s that I was going to seed so I am indebted to them. 

As a general surgeon who has served in a Kenyan mission hospital I've witnessed first-hand the devastating damage that blindness can do to individuals and communities but also know how effective and cheap preventive and curative measures are. 

As CEO of Christian Medical Fellowship I'm deeply committed to healthcare in the developing world.

In five previous marathons between 2004 and 2014  friends and colleagues generously helped me to raise over £25,000 for Whizz Kidz, Alzheimer's Society, Down's Syndrome, Help the Hospices and Christian Blind Mission so this latest effort brings the grand total to over £30,000. 

If you still want to give it is not too late.
