story:
Update: 

DRAW DATED EXTENDED. Since there are still some pledges for this fundraising Raffle I have postponed the draw until tomorrow evening,17 November. Thank you so much for many donations received so far, big and small. The target amount was raised in less than a week.

Donating £2 or more enters you into the raffle to to win an original Este MacLeod created from the 'tell me a story' template as used for the #Lettergardens drawing project, #Big Draw 2105. For every £2 donated you will get a virtual raffle ticket. The hope is to raise £300 for this important charity. Sight is so important, and all too often taken for granted.  100% of donations for Sightsavers, a charity focussing on curing blindness, a condition that can be prevented in many. See more info on http://www.sightsavers.org/



The winner of the painting will have it shipped at no additional cost, regardless of location.



More about the drawing project that inspired this painting: #lettergardens, I'm inviting everyone around the world to take part in creating a flower garden drawing using the letters as printed on a downloadable template.The project is happening in several schools and youth clubs in the UK, at Windsor Contemporary Art Fair and globally. On World Kindness day Friday 13 November the artworks are to be given to someone to colour in. Share your creation on Instagram #lettergardens #thebigdraw #exploredrawing.

For more information on the project see http://blog.estemacleod.com/2015/10/drawing-with-letters.html

https://www.facebook.com/EsteMacLeodArtist

God! I need a Jack Daniels.

AAAAAAnyway, Thank you so much for donating your hard earned cash, it is really appreciated and will make a huge difference to so many people.


Eat, sleep, run (puke), repeat.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

There are 39 million blind people in the world today. Out of these, 80% could have been prevented or cured, but due to a lack of available healthcare and research, over 31 million people will never see again.   

By donating to this page, you will help SightSavers to prevent thousands of cases of blindness across the world by not only offering eye checks and treatment to those who need it, but by working with national governments to tackle the causes leading to preventable blindness.

We are grateful for your donation which we promise no matter how small or big will make a massive difference for them!!  Please spread the word and tell everyone about our challenge.

story:

In order to raise money for Sight Savers, a charity close to my heart, I am going to abstain from ALL cakes and yummy deserts for a month. Your support is greatly appreciated for such a worthwhile cause!

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As many of you know I walked the 192 mile Coast to Coast path in September 2015 raising £2500 for Sightsavers.

I chose this charity as in 2015 I had laser eye surgery which meant I didn’t have to wear glasses anymore. I realised how lucky I was to have the choice and money to just make a decision and go to have the treatment unlike many others who have to live with their vision impairment.

When I read about A Million Miracles I felt the need to help as much as I could. Sightsavers work is very inspiring.

My Coast to Coast walk was an organised group that I joined with my friend Elizabeth. There were 14 of us in all and we soon became very good friends spending 14 days walking and chatting about anything and everything to while away the long hours across the Lake District, Yorkshire Dales and North York Moors. It was during these chats that 2 people, separate of each other suggested I take up running. I poo pooed them and said I had never even run across the road for a bus and there was no way I could go running but it stuck with me and I kept thinking about it.

When I got home I felt physically and mentally strong after walking 192 miles even though my feet felt like horse’s hooves.

I decided not to let the strength disappear and so I downloaded the app, Couch to 5K, and tentatively started the first 1 minute run that nearly killed me. Soon I was running a bit more every week and eventually I reached the 5K (30 minutes) and I cried. Not from pain but from the sense of achievement.

I quickly decided to down load the app 5k-10k and set off to double my distance over a period of months. Eventually cracking the 10K distance.

At this point I didn’t know if I should continue as I was worried I was too old and would destroy my knees. But my sensible head went out of the window as I downloaded the app 10K-21K and started to work towards the half marathon. I live in Ealing and there is a very good half marathon every year in September which goes right past the front of my house. I usually go out every year to clap the runners past, never dreaming that I would ever be able to do such a thing. (As of September 24th 2017 I have now completed that half marathon in 2 hours and 8 minutes and am very happy with that time for my first effort.)

I then received an email from Margaret (one of the ladies who was on the coast to Coast walk) to say that her friend Karen was going to be running in the London Marathon in April 2017 for charity and would we consider sponsoring her. Karen was very special to us, she was not just any old friend of Margaret, she went out of her way to drive across the UK with a box of homemade chocolate brownies and a bottle of fizz for us all on our last day. She met us in a small village about 2 hours walk from Robin Hood’s Bay (our final destination) with the brownies to share out amongst us to give us all a chocolate boost and then drove on to Robin Hood’s Bay with the fizz and shared it all out with a glass for each of us to celebrate our wonderful achievement as we dipped our toes in the water. What a wonderful friend.

Of course, I sponsored Karen, after all, one good turn deserves another even after one and a half years had gone by. I then spent all of Sunday morning trying to spot her on TV in the marathon. It was at this point that I decided I could do this. I could run that marathon too as I watched everyone running the course. So here I am with a place and am absolutely petrified, what have I done? But I WILL do this and hope to raise a good sum for Sightsavers and all those eyesights that will be restored to people who have lost hope.

I hated sports at school and was always useless. Sports day was my biggest nightmare as I ran around hurdles and under the high jump and would hide in the toilets. Who would think that in my 60th year I would attempt to do such a thing as run the London marathon? I wish my teachers could see me now.

Last year I ran in my first ever race, the Osterley 10K. it was 26 degrees that morning but I completed it in literally seconds over the hour and I was the proud owner of my first ever running medal. (I went to bed in it that night and woke up with the medal part under my armpit ) I have since hung it up to remind me of what i can achieve when I decide to do something. My Ealing Half marathon was run in 20 degrees and full sunshine but I completed it and now have a second medal which I also wore to bed that night!! I can feel a tradition starting here.

At the beginning of February I also completed, with a personal best of 57 minutes, the London Winter 10k run with 20,000 other people, starting in Trafalgar Square and running basically to St Paul's and back round the streets of London. It was freezing cold but so much fun and honestly, I felt like I would have liked to turn round and do it all again when I got to the end. I wanted to experience what it was like to run with so many people in London before the big MARATHON day.

I have now completed the hottest London marathon on record, 24.1 degrees officially, in a time I am really chuffed with, 4:59:17, a fraction under the 5 hour mark. It was challenging and hot but I was well trained (I had run 419 miles during the previous 5 months), well fuelled thanks to my lovely Craig and well hydrated due to no alcohol at all for at least a month before. I felt strong and determined and when it got tough around 23-24 miles I gave myself a good talking to and ran on to get over the line in just under the 5 hours which was my aim. 

I love my medal, its heavy and bears all the weight of the effort involved to obtain it. I will never forget that day for the rest of my life, I ran with a massive smile most of the way. Apologies in advance if you still see me wearing my medal now and again but I am chuffed to bits with it :)

I am now an official marathoner at the age of 59 and a half!!! xxx

I wrote a blog about my Coast to Coast walk if you want to read about my effort. How did I know that it would be the start of something much larger?

http://lozandherboots.blogspot.co.uk/

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit George's JustGiving page.

We decided to set up this page in memory of our Dad, George Kinross. Dad believed passionately in finding ways to support the world's poorest people. There are so many charities doing important development work; we have chosen Sightsavers because Dad was able to donate his corneas and hopefully save someone's sight. Sightsavers works in the world's poorest countries to prevent and treat avoidable blindness and to campaign for the rights of visually impaired people. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Thank you for your donation; it means a lot to us.

Jess & Kirsty x

eventName: Alison goes alcohol free for January!
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hi all I hope you all had a wonderful Christmas and New Year!

I have decided to give up alcohol for January in attempt to raise money for Sightsavers charity.

Did you know 75% of sight loss can be cured or prevented?! Imagine facing vision loss that could be cured or prevented.. but you are unable to get the help required due to your place of birth.

I was recently referred to hospital during an eyetest, without this intervention I may have risked losing my vision. I was sent to A&E by a lovely and very competent lady called Hannah at Vision Express Bury st Edmonds and was looked after very well by the NHS West Suffolk hospital where a diagnosis of viral meningitis was made. I am now home and I am under the care of the outpatient opthomology service. I was fortunate to get the help/care/treatment I needed, others born into poverty are not so lucky. Sightsavers can change lives of children and adults around the world, where there isn’t adequate healthcare services.

Sightsavers really do change lives. Every year, sightsavers support their partners to carry out millions of eye examinations and refer people for treatment to prevent blindness and restore sight.

Please donate generously if you can.. as you all know I am partial to a glass of wine, but it will be a pleasure to go without this month if it means I can raise some money for Sightsavers! 

If you can’t donate please take from this the importance of eye tests both routinely and if you notice any changes to vision or headaches etc.

Thanks for reading!!

Alison xxx

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Geoff Pyke
story:
Our brother, Geoff Pyke, died on Christmas Day after a short illness. Following a successful career as a chemical engineer, Geoff applied his considerable intellect to studying history and was finalising his PhD.  

Anne and Geoff loved to travel and visited many less developed countries where they saw the huge difference that organisations such as Sightsavers make to the quality of life. Relatively straightforward eye operations, such as the one Geoff had as a three year old, are beyond the means of so many families in developing countries. Sightsavers seeks to redress this balance.                                                                

Please join us in making donations in memory of Geoff to enable Sightsavers to continue this valuable work.

Thanks from Bill and Lin Pyke

story:
I've put my humble photography talent to work in the benefit of Sightsavers and organised a unique photo exhibition in London that captures the beauty and wildness of the most remote continents - Arctic and Antarctica - places I visited in the last 2 years.

Exhibition run from 14-19th of Oct 13 with a viewing night on the 15th of Oct with 200 guests.

Sightsavers an international charity that provides on-site treatment, education and training for blind and visually impaired people in developing countries.

Prints are now available online for consultation and order - 10% of all print sales will continue going to SightSavers:

http://smu.gs/1h6b4qf

Your donation is highly appreciated.

Too many people in this world don't have the chance to see or fully enjoy what Mother Nature has to offer but we can surely support them to progress through life and help them build a future that they're looking forward to.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Ellen Gillan
story:
Shave Santa - get rid of that hairy bundle and be clean shaven - Lose the beard!


SightSavers - the reason ... for those that don't know, I am totally blind in my left eye after many attempts to save the sight following a Giant Retinal Tear that turned into a Retinal Detachment. The other eye, well, it has had an operation to save the sight and the fear of becoming completely blind (complete darkness with no light perception at all) lives with me every single day. I am lucky, I can still see, some people around the world do not and it is worst in developing countries that lack resources. It is for others that we live on this planet, to love others and care for them.

As a bit of fun and considering so many people see my chubby cheeks, my real life belly, my white hair, my love of wearing a red suit at Christmas and ... of course ... the white beard, I decided to try raising funds for charities:

- Shave Santa cause will raise funds for SightSavers International being a charity that helps prevent blindness, supports blind people and performs so many good functions in the developing world.

- Save Santa cause will raise funds for the Ardgowan Hospice.

The cause that raises the most amount of money will see me either Shave the Santa trade mark beard or Save the Santa trade mark beard. On the 22nd December this year, my face will either continue to look like Santa or it will be clean shaven!!!


This page is to raise funds for SightSavers International, to help prevent blindness and help people who are blind in developing countries around the world.

They need our help, love and support.


The beard has been with me for many years now and over the years has become very white. I have been quite attached to it!!!


As for the Save Santa cause ... from the start of my mum's illness, all the early symptoms and no-one knowing the reasons, through the diagnosis of Pancreatic Cancer, followed by the horrific last few weeks was one of the most upsetting times of our lives.

The Save Santa page will raise funds for the Ardgowan Hospice to care for so many more people nearing the end of their lives and support so many families. As for the Save Santa page, it will raise funds for the Ardgowan Hospice who provide care that words just don't do justice. The incredible care for my mum and the kindness shown to my whole family was something that we will always remember. The people at the Ardgowan Hospice are fantastic and the place itself is somewhere so many families turn to throughout the year every year. The support before, during and after is second to none.

So, you decide. Save or Shave Santa this year ... for a good cause. Vote by donating. The winner is not me not matter, it is two great charities and a bit of fun at the same time. It will be exciting to see what will happen. I personally just hope both charities receive some good amounts of money from people around the world; as for the beard, I wonder what I will look like come the New Year. All will be revealed and please share this page far and wide. I am willing to do whatever it takes to raise as much money as possible in memory of Mum - the bravest person I have ever loved xxx

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Tom Palmer
story: As you know, Tom was a wonderful human being. He died of a heart attack whilst cycling in Kazakhstan in August this year.  In his memory, there will be a collection for the charity Sightsavers.  It is a charity he particularly favoured as his sight was so poor and he was always so careful of and dependent on his glasses.  Having been in Kenya for two years, he was keenly aware of how lucky we are in the UK to have the NHS to sort out eye problems and provide glasses for those that need them. Sightsavers is a UK-based international charity which fights avoidable blindness, and promotes equal opportunities for visually impaired people. It also supports surgeons in their cataract operations in the field in countries on many continents, including Africa.

story:
If you are looking at this page I have invited you to my 50th birthday party on June 16th. Instead of bringing me a present that I won't know what to do with on the night, I am asking everyone to give at least £5 to Sightsavers.  This is enough for them to restore sight to a child somewhere less fortunate than this. 

Just think about that for a moment.

If all 50 of you donate £5 to this page, 50 kids will see the sun catching a cobweb, or a rainbow, or their Mum's smile. That's quite a gift to give. 

I'd rather wake up to that thought on June 17th than a pile of presents.

You can always give more than £5 of course. 

And if you buy me a present as well, I'll forgive you :-)

THANK YOU 

Trainboy (and 50 kids who would stay blind otherwise)


Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
title: Trainboy's 50th Birthday - let there be light.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
I got my first (Lion King) glasses when I was 8 and with a prescription of -8.5 my specs have long been my safety net. I was fortunate to grow up with optional extras to make life easier; clip-on sunglasses (I was cool), prescription swimming goggles, then contact lenses and even some creative Dad-inventions (old lenses stuck inside a snorkelling mask). A few months ago I went one better and benefitted from the incredible technology of Laser Eye Surgery. Within 3 days I was deemed legal to drive without visual aid (pretty hard to comprehend when you've lived through -8.5).

Wearing glasses wasn't an issue (unsurprisingly I was used to it), but I always felt vulnerable to any situation in which they could be ripped away. In an emergency my confidence and independence would instantly be gone. And yet too many people don't even have the privilege of a simple pair of glasses or access to the everyday eye care that we can take for granted. I feel extremely fortunate to have grown up shortsighted in my world, yet others are unnecessarily losing their sight to treatable conditions or struggling with everyday activities.

As I celebrate my first spec-free birthday in over 20 years, I'm asking friends and family to donate towards my fundraising campaign to give others the gift of sight. Thank you!
title: A gift of sight
pageSummary: I am raising money because I'm celebrating a spec-free birthday
Name: A gift of sight

charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Say goodbye to our amazing flowing hair. 

Three of us here at Traveleyes - a tour company helping the visually impaired see the world - are shaving our heads for Sightsavers who do fantastic work all over the world. 

There are 39 million blind people in the world, but 80 per cent of blindness can be cured or prevented. That’s 31.2 million people who are blind when they needn’t be.

Sightsavers want to eliminate avoidable blindness and support people who are irreversibly blind or disabled to live independently.

So please give generously through our just giving page and remember to add gift aid.

We will put up a video on Facebook and YouTube so please make sure you like and subscribe to watch the shaving happen.

https://www.facebook.com/traveleyesltd
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC6yFbJDy43RPNfgUxrF1rhg

Thank you so much for your support.

The Traveleyes Team.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hellooo everyone! 

It's been a long time since I've been involved in any sort of fundraising events! Here I am, challenging myself to do a skydive (Yes I mean it!) to raise fund for sightsavers! 

Sightsavers is an international organisation that helps to combat blindness and provide support to people especially those who are less fortunate. Most importantly, sightsavers provide services to partially sighted or the blind to help them achieve a better quality of life they deserve. 

Sight and vision is important because it allows us to connect to the surroundings and to perceive beauty that nature has to offer. They also keep us safe.

Right now 39 million people in the world suffer from blindness - and 80% of them are potentially curable and preventable if they have the right resources.

Why not help make a difference? Help change the lives of people who are at risk of losing their sight.

Thank you!

When I reach the target - challenge accepted!

rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I've been growing my hair for almost 2 years now but on the 12th May I will be getting it all shaved off - who knows what's under there?!

I chose to raise money for Sightsavers for a couple of reasons. Firstly, the cause is something close to my heart; although not blind by any stretch, without corrective surgery for my short sight I'd be unable to drive or even recognise people standing a few meters away. If I'd been born in a different part of the world I'd have really struggled with everyday life due to my poor vision.

Secondly, I'm really keen on giving effectively - basically getting as much 'bang for your buck' when donating to charities. Sightsavers score highly in this regard as 91% or all money donated goes straight to helping people with sight issues and much of the treatments are very cost effective.

Any and all donations are massively appreciated and will be going to an extremely worthwhile cause.

Will be sure to share some before and after pics with all sponsors!

Thanks,

Stef﻿

﻿﻿

eventName: Shaving my head for children with Trachoma.
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
I will be shaving my head on May 18th 2017 in order to raise money for people suffering from Trachoma. Trachoma is a bacterial eye infection that makes the eyelids turn inwards until your eyelashes scrape against the surface of your eyes. Slowly, you go blind. However, this disease is easily preventable with antibiotics, but many cannot afford or access antibiotics. People affected with this are usually living in rural areas with no direct connection to a health centre and have no effective methods of transport. Even a small amount of money can buy a lot of antibiotics and treat a lot of people. 

Many thanks for considering giving to this cause.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Mariyah Jasrai
story:
We, as a family would like to fundraise for Sightsavers in loving memory of Mariyah Jasrai. Mariyah was diagnosed with Ewing's Sarcoma, an extremely aggressive form of cancer at the age of 7 and a half and engaged in a battle with it up until the age of 16, where she endured a plethora of treatments including chemotherapy, radiotherapy and surgery in both conventional and experimental variations. She was subjected to an overwhelming bombardment of hardship, pain and suffering throughout her years but despite that she continued to plough on with her strong character, will and determination. 

The tumour originated in her femur and then continued to grow and metastasise around her body but she continued to fight it at every step of its progression. She endured inhumane amounts of pain, sickness and suffering caused by combination of the disease and the side effects of the rudimentary treatments that exist today. These did not phase her up until December 2016 when she was experiencing severe headaches and blurry vision and we were told that the cancer had metastasised into her brain which is extremely rare for her form and that it was applying pressure to her eyes, thus distorting her vision. She underwent radiotherapy which was unsuccessful and we were not able to contain the tumour within her. It continued to colonise her brain and eventually it grew on her optic nerves and she effectively lost her vision. 

Mariyah had endured every side effect and possible manifestation of pain but it did not defeat her, however when she lost her eyesight, she was absolutely distraught. Her character had changed, her will wasted away and she began to lose herself and eventually so would we. For Mariyah, her vision was her connection to the outside world, even when she was cornered by the unstoppable forces of nature within her, it allowed her to see the comforting smile of her parents faces or even the photos that would evoke her favourite memories that would provide her with the hope and thus determination to fight; however when this connection was severed she was defeated as she entered the dark abyss of the end of her life. 

Sadly, she lost her battle on the 19th of April 2017. However, before she had passed she had heard about Sighsavers and their pledge to treat blind children and restore their vision by removing their cataracts. When she heard that it would only cost £4 per eye, she immediately wanted to contribute to restore the vision of as many children as she could as she was enraged that it could be done so easily. Even though she knew that her vision could not be restored, she wanted to impact the lives of those that could be treated as she had endured their pain. She wanted to add this extremely personal pledge to her portfolio of charitable work but unfortunately she was not able to do so. Therefore, we would like to carry out Mariyah's wish to pledge and continue her profound impact on this planet by giving the gift of sight.
title: Fundraising in loving memory of Mariyah Jasrai

Name: Fundraising in loving memory of Mariyah Jasrai

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Phoebe Woollcombe
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit Phoebe Woollcombe's JustGiving page.

Phoebe, who died suddenly of cancer in November, was always the most charitable of souls. She gave to dozens of charities, worked in a charity shop for years, and organized the Red Cross charity flag sellers in her parish for 30 years, all unpaid and out of the goodness of her large heart. 

But Sightsavers was especially close to that heart, the one cause above all others that she wanted to support. For her, blindness was the most terrible of afflictions, and Sightsavers' mission to eliminate avoidable blindness and to make the world a fairer place for people with such disabilities was something that deserved the widest possible support.

And while she loved flowers, she always thought it wrong that money would be lavished on flowers for a funeral (which wouldn't benefit the deceased), when it could be spent to much better effect and benefit far more by being given to a good cause such as Sightsavers.

Phoebe was not a great one for computers, always preferring handwritten letters, phone calls and face-to-face contact, but she diligently attended a computer class for years, learning (just about) how to read and write emails. She was a great pragmatist, however, and she did accept that, even if it was all gobbledygook to her, the internet could be harnessed for good purposes. Hence this page – and the comparable one for her late, much missed husband Dick (https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/richardwoollcombe) in aid of the Alzheimer's Society – had her blessing, in the hopes that it would help her precious cause of Sightsavers. 

So, whether you knew Phoebe and want to give something in her memory, or whether you think Sightsavers is an admirable cause and deserves support, thank you for whatever you can give.

PS  Why is this page called Phoebe's Online Egg Round? Simple: as anyone who lived near her will know, once a week she would go round the local village selling eggs from her hens to friends and neighbours. She always called this her egg round, and it became very much a social event, with her driving home full to the gills after 15 cups of tea and endless chat. She also milked it for all she was worth when she was selling flags for the Red Cross. This page is very much in the same shameless spirit, hence the name!

Finally, here's the official blurb:

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

...Other people run marathons, grow moustaches or give up drinking...

Instead in April 2006 I had a big birthday celebration (for my 50th) and in the process also managed to raise somewhere between £700 - £800 for Sightsavers in lieu of birthday presents.

Having reached 60 I decided to plan a ceilidh to try and get all my family and friends together...and I also decided to actively ﻿do at least one thing to try to raise money for charity this year... and so, I'm hoping that whether you're able to come to my party or not, you'll support me in contributing to this excellent cause.

 I know how awful it is not being able to see, but I've been lucky enough to have always been able to remedy that by wearing glasses or contact lenses. Millions of people don't have that option and have to go through their lives being needlessly blind.

Together we can help change that.. I pledge that I will match anything that I can raise up to £750.

35p can treat or protect one person against trachoma or a family against river blindness. (£5.60 to protect 16 individuals or families).

£8 can pay for a trichiasis operation for a patient suffering from advanced trachoma.

£2.62 can pay for a folding white cane (£10.48 to provide four).

Around 20 million people in the world are estimated to be needlessly blind due to cataracts...

£30 can pay for an adult's cataract operation.

£50 can pay for a child's cataract operation.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

﻿

story:
Clifford Derricutt died peacefully on 29th August 2016 with Eileen and Clare beside him.  As always his battle with dementia was fought with strength and  dignity but one that proved too much this time. 

Loosing his sight was the biggest challenge of all for him because it took away his love of photography and Formula One.  It was just not the same listening to the commentary as being able to watch it.

We request that there are no flowers but that donations are made to Sightsavers in his memory, so that others maybe given the gift of sight.
title: In Memory of Clifford Derricutt

eventName: My 60th birthday and retirement as a midwife
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
All of us know somebody whose sight has benefitted from glasses, contact lenses or cataract surgery. I used glasses and contacts for thirty years before my darling father paid for laser eye surgery for me, one of his most precious gifts. So I want to emulate his generosity and raise £10 for each year of my life for Sightsavers!  

http://www.sightsavers.org/

This money could buy 

  • 150 children's cataract operations, or
  • 900 trachoma operations, or
  • treat 109,200 people to prevent river blindness;

an awesome birthday shopping list for anybody don't you think?!

If I get my wishlist of sight goodies, I will match the amount with a donation of my own to another special charity that treats children for cleft lip and palate and, by so doing, gives them education, employment and marriage prospects:

https://smiletrain.org.uk/

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
eventName: The gift of sight in return for a gift of shoes
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks for taking the time out to visit my page.

Every day children are going blind from eye conditions or diseases that are easily preventable. This page is to help raise as much money as possible to SightSavers to help combat those diseases and give the gift of sight to those children. 

Please donate £10 and leave your name and email address in the donation message. On the 10th September 2016, a winner will be selected at random and a brand new pair of Valentino heels for women or a pair of Giuseppe Zanotti for men bought from Harrods will be gifted and sent to the winners chosen address. The chosen winner will be contacted on the day and size asked to make sure the shoe fits! 

All donations for this event will be 100% donated to the charity, the shoes will be gifted straight from myself. Your £10 donation will pay for the operations and aftercare to allow a child with bilateral cataract to see again.

Please donate today – you can be the difference between sight and blindness for children.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Richard Campbell
story:
A loving husband, father, and grandfather who sadly died on 20th June 2016. 

Richard was passionate about supporting efforts to eliminate avoidable blindness and help people who are irreversibly blind or disabled to live independently.

Richard gave monthly to the charity, donating £713 since 2008, and was
treated for cataracts himself just last year. 

There are 39 million blind people in the world, but 80 per cent of blindness could be prevented or cured. That’s 31.2 million people who are blind when it could have been avoided.

In memory of Richard, the family is raising money for Sightsavers' 'Million Miracles' appeal which aims to fund one million cataract operations across Africa and Asia by 2017.

It costs on average just £30 to restore the sight of somebody who is blind from cataracts, however in many of the communities in which the charity works, this opportunity is completely out of reach.

We hope to raise above and beyond Richard's contribution.

More about ‘Million Miracles’ can be found by visiting www.millionmiracles.org

A short video of the first beneficiary, Winesi March, can also be
found here: www.youtube.com/watch?v=6Pg2OenLC7U

We would like to thank friends and family for their thoughts, prayers, love, support and generosity (... not to forget the cakes!). x

Love Rosemary, Alexander, Samantha, Elizabeth and all the family. 

Thanks for taking the time to visit Richard's in memory JustGiving page. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story: We feel extremely fortunate to have each other, and everything life has given to us so far. So many people are far less fortunate than us and need your contributions a lot more than we do. Your presence at our wedding if gift enough for us. It would really make our day if we could raise our target of £600 (just £10 per person if everyone gives!!). We have chosen SightSavers because people in some of the poorest areas in the world lose their sight unnecessarily because they don't have the kind of health care services that we take for granted everyday. Contributions to this charity can make a huge difference and change people's lives in a fundamental way. Instead of giving us a gift, please give generously to this charity! We would really appreciate it!! :)

story:
Sightsavers is an extraordinary charity. For £50 they can protect a person from curable blindness. This changes the whole life of the individual (from children to elders) as well as their family and community. 

This was Caroline Jane Blair's favourite charity - she loved how they could do SO much with relatively little funding - and we would love to celebrate her memory by saving as many people as possible from preventable blindness. Please donate to help us achieve the lasting memorial of sight for others. Our greatest thanks. 

The Blair and Mayor Families

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Thanks so much for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page!

As part of our wedding gift list, we wanted to add charity donations as we know there are many people in the world who need gifts far more than we do. We wanted to use this opportunity to help support the charity Sightsavers and all the great work they do.

80 per cent of blindness could be prevented or cured which means there are 31.2 million people in the world who are blind when it could have been avoided.  Most of these people live in the poorest countries in the world where healthcare is limited, diseases which were wiped out decades ago in the UK still prevail and there is huge stigma around disease and disability.  

Sightsavers do great work supporting their partners to carry out millions of eye examinations and refer people for treatment to prevent blindness and restore sight. Through community volunteers in developing countries, they enable the distribution of medication to prevent blinding diseases, fund operations for people who need them, and train eye care workers and surgeons.

Because of Sightsavers, people who are visually impaired or have other disabilities are supported to live independently, get an education and earn an income.  They work with national governments, strengthening systems that tackle the problems at the root of avoidable blindness – like access to clean water, sanitation facilities and education.

Their goal is to bring about long-term change – making health systems stronger, educating communities and fighting for people with disabilities to be treated equally

Your donation could restore someone’s sight, prevent avoidable blindness or support someone who’s irreversibly blind to live independently.  Here's just a few examples of where the money will go:

  • £4- Cataract operation to give a child back their sight
  • £8 - Trachoma operation to stop 12 people going blind
  • £12 - Treatment to prevent 2,184 losing their sight to river blindness

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails.  Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity and make sure Gift Aid is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer. 

Thank you for your generosity for this great cause!

Rick and Emily xxx

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
If you're reading this page you have probably read my Facebook post and understand what this is about, but for those that haven't - 

I'm Andrew Foulkes and I, along with Vintage Whatnots want to try and do something amazing in 2015 with our family, friends and friends of friends. 

I want us all (or as many as possible) to come together and make a difference to the world. 

No gimmicks, no bath of beans, no run, cycle ride, or mountain climb, nothing. I just want us all to make a New Years pledge together, one that we can keep for the entire year. 

I want us all to give what we can afford every month (on the 1st, on pay day or whatever) for 12 months, I'm suggesting 1% of our income (which for someone earning £20,000pa is £16.66pm) but anything is of course fine, if you can only spare  £1 a month then donate that, it all adds to the pot. 

In 12 months time I want us to look back as a collective group of people who know each other and see what a difference we have made to the lives of people less fortunate than us. 

If we raise the £10,000 I'm aiming for we could have given the gift of sight to as many as 700 people around the world. 

Stop and think about that for a minute, consider how much we rely on sight. Think how much it means to give a person their sight back. There are over 30m people in the world who are blind due to preventable causes. We can change the lives of hundreds of them without sacrificing anything of our own. 

I'm not asking you to give anything up (unless you want to) and I don't want anyone to struggle for money (after all charity begins at home), but if we all give what we can, together we can do something truly amazing this year. 

Thank you for reading this far and for at least considering to donate. 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
On 2nd May 2015, I'm going to be joining the Traveleyes Team and abseiling down the front of the Royal Armouries dressed as a superhero, in aid of raising funds for Sightsavers.

Sightsavers is an international charity working to eliminate avoidable blindness and support people who are irreversibly blind to live independently. There are 39 million blind people in the world, but 80% of blindness could be prevented or cured. That's 31.2 million people who are blind when it could have been avoided.

Shocked at how unfair this is? So am I.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.
title: Mark's Superheroes Saving Sight Abseil
pageSummary: To help cure preventable Sight loss
pageSummaryWhat: To help cure preventable Sight loss
Name: Mark's Superheroes Saving Sight Abseil
ProfileWhat: To help cure preventable Sight loss

story:
On 2nd May 2015, Fiona O'Sullivan, Sally Lloyd and I are going to be joining the Traveleyes Team and abseiling down the front of the Royal Armouries in Leeds City Centre dressed as superheroes (if Charlie's Angels count as superheroes?!).


Our aim is to raise funds for Sightsavers.

 

Sightsavers is an international charity working to eliminate avoidable blindness and support people who are irreversibly blind to live independently. 


There are 39 million blind people in the world, but 80% of blindness could be prevented or cured. That's 31.2 million people who are blind when it could have been avoided.

 

Please donate and help us to raise mush-needed funds for Sightsavers, so that they can continue their amazing work.





Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

eventName: Anj's Royal Armouries Abseil as part of Superheroes Saving Sight
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Hi all, thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

At a dinner party recently, my friend Amar, CEO of Traveleyes, which provides multi-sensory group holidays for both blind and sighted travellers, was telling me about the 10th anniversary plans for his company (actually, he was trying to flog me a ticket to the ball, but when I heard about the plans for the charity abseil, I jumped in as the first volunteer).  I've jumped from a plane at 15,000 feet, surely stepping off the Armouries can't be that scary, right?!

Amar is blind himself and never lets it stand in his way.  Just one of the things he's done is a 220 mile trek from the Atlantic to the Pacific Coast of Nicaragua.  He and other blind and partially sighted friends inspire me and show that we can achieve anything we put our minds to!  There are some cases where sight can be saved though and this is why I’d like to raise funds for Sightsavers.  

Opposite my gran’s house in Delhi, India, was an Institution for the Blind.  My parents always took some form of donation when we visited, so I’ve seen first-hand how even simple procedures can restore sight.

Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. Thanks!
title: Anj's Abseil - Superheroes Saving Sight

<!--StartFragment-->

<p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
background:white;vertical-align:baseline"><span style="font-size:13.5pt;
font-family:"Comic Sans MS";mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;color:#4D4840;
border:none windowtext 1.0pt;mso-border-alt:none windowtext 0cm;padding:0cm">This
charity fundraising site has been set up in memory of Vinnette Louise Grey, our
mother, who passed away on 5th December 2014. </span><span style="font-size:13.5pt;font-family:"Comic Sans MS";mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
color:#262626"><o:p></o:p></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="mso-margin-top-alt:auto;mso-margin-bottom-alt:auto;
background:white;vertical-align:baseline"><span style="font-size:13.5pt;
font-family:"Comic Sans MS";mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;color:#4D4840;
border:none windowtext 1.0pt;mso-border-alt:none windowtext 0cm;padding:0cm">Not
long before she passed away, our mother had her cataracts removed and was
overwhelmed with the result that allowed her to see so clearly for the first
time in years.  For this reason, we would greatly appreciate donations to
the charity SIGHTSAVERS. This charity strives to eliminate avoidable blindness,
such as through funding cataract operations of the type that significantly
enriched our mother's life.</span><span style="font-size:13.5pt;font-family:
"Comic Sans MS";mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;color:#4D4840"> </span><span style="font-size:13.5pt;font-family:"Comic Sans MS";mso-bidi-font-family:Arial;
color:#262626"><o:p></o:p></span></p><p class="MsoNormal" style="background:white;vertical-align:baseline">

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Every wedding I cover I am asked for photographs from two or three suppliers – florists, make up artists, hairdressers, wedding planners, cake makers, caterers and venues to name just a few! I cover lots of lovely weddings every year and with the wedding supplier's best intentions of returning the favour with a link and/or a credit on a web page, this very rarely happens.

So to help out all those fabulous wedding suppliers out there who appreciate the value of good photograph, I am asking all suppliers who want images for their web pages and own marketing to donate to  www.sightsavers.org in return for the digital files. There are 39 million blind people in the world, but 80% of blindness could be prevented or cured. So this way it's a win win - suppliers get the images they really want and someone in need, somewhere in the world receives help from this wonderful charity.

Once you’ve made your donation, please e-mail me at info@barneyjonesphotography.com the image numbers of the photographs you would like.

Featuring a credit or a link in conjunction with the images (my name or website address) is welcome of course but that's up to you.
Suggested donations:
Selection of Web sized images with logo  £5
Selection of Web sized without logo         £10
Selection of Hi Res files with logo            £15
Selection of Hi Res files without logo       £25
Please feel free to donate more should you wish to.
Thank you in advance for your understanding and for your contribution.
Barney


Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity and make sure Gift Aid is reclaimed on every eligible donation by a UK taxpayer. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – I raise more, whilst saving time and cutting costs for the charity.So please dig deep and donate now.
title: Barney's Supplier Page
Name: Barney's Supplier Page

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
Giving the gift of sight...

Last Monday afternoon I decorated my Christmas tree with a very excited eight year old. Like most people, I have the usual mix of paraphernalia but also a few decorations that are special to me - baubles given to me by friends, things I have had for years that make an annual appearance and also an Italian glass Santa that started me thinking...

The Santa in question was a gift on my honeymoon in Venice back in April 2005. We couldn't really afford it and it seemed strange to be thinking of Christmas on a beautiful sunny day in spring but we got him anyway. We had just had coffee in Saint Mark's Square and were incredibly happy...

My husband and I have since separated and this lead me to question whether the Santa would be a source of sadness and irritation or whether it would remind me of a lovely memory. I decided that it had to be the latter and also to appreciate the little things at Christmas that I have so easily taken for granted in the past. As I continued decorating the tree, I realised that the sights of Christmas are so important and that vision (at all times of the year) makes a massive contribution as to how we interpret and experience the world and the joy we take from living.

On the Sightsavers website I learnt that: there are 39 million blind people in the world, 80% of blindness can be prevented or cured and 90% of visually impaired people live in the world's poorest countries. The idea of 'baubles for the blind' popped into my head and the concept that people could post the sights of Christmas that are uniquely theirs and part of their history but then donate a small amount to a charity where just £4 will fund a cataract operation and give a child back their sight, £8 provides a trachoma operation to stop 12 people going blind and £12 can prevent 2184 people losing their sight to river blindness...

Unlike most fundraising ideas however, 'Giving the gift of sight' will only work if everyone joins in! I had the idea but really after I have posted my story and photos (and got the ball rolling) it will be out of my hands what happens. I do not need to train for weeks to complete some impressive physical feat, bake cakes or buy expensive equipment. Also, there is no guarantee that anyone will post a picture or that those who do will then follow the link and give any money. My idea then rests on trust, it relies on goodwill and has at its heart a wish to make a small but significant difference. if this brings a positive change and can help one person, I will be happy and so, of course, will they...

For more information go to: http://www.sightsavers.net/

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: Sightsavers' vision is of a world where no one is blind from avoidable causes and where visually impaired people participate equally in society.
charity.name: Sightsavers
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
story:
There are so many things we love about Christmas, decorating the tree, enjoying a family feast or drinks with friends.  However every year we spend our money on gifts to each other when we already have so much stuff.  We can show our love at Christmas time in so many other ways.

Every day there are people in the third world who can't feed their family because they have a cateract or other treatable blindness.  

Let's do Christmas gifts differently this year.  What's the worse that could happen! 

B and I know that we will feel better if we give our money to Sightsavers instead this Christmas, so that's what we are going to do.

If you were thinking of buying us a gift please give a few pounds to this, or any other charity  if you prefer, instead.  Promise we won't ever hold it against you:))

Marion and Brendan xx

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

rememberedPersonSummary.name: Brian Holdsworth
story:
After retiring from the Royal Navy in 1985, Brian spent the winter months in South Africa where he encountered many people with terrible sight problems. Having procured the necessary medical expertise to restore the sight of an elderly Zulu woman, Brian adopted Sightsavers as his favourite charity. 

We - his family - hope that you will want to make a small contribution to Sightsavers in memory of Brian. And we thank you on his behalf. 

This is what JustGiving says about JustGiving: donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving – they’ll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they’ll send your money directly to the charity. So it’s the most efficient way to donate – saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

For years, Violet has supported Sightsavers by doing repairs (£1.00 each!) and making bags and many other things to raise money for a cause she loves - and Richard lets her!

This December, they will have been married for 70 years and I know that they would prefer a donation to this charity rather than gifts - they  have each other and anyone who knows them will know that they have all they need with just that! 

Send a cheque if you prefer or contact me for an invite to their celebration in November! 

Thank you so much - you know how much this will mean to them both!

story:
Hi

I will be taking part in The Vodafone Big Bold Challenge 70 mile cycling 
event on 25th September, 2014.

My challenge will be to cycle from Newbury to Olympic Park, London.

I am raising funds for Sightsavers; a charity run in developing countries 
to help prevent people from going blind unnecessarily and also support 
people to live independently if their sight loss can’t be undone.

If you would like to learn more then please visit: 
http://www.sightsavers.org/

You can also donate via text: SHEZ92 £5 to number 70070. (You can text donate between £1 and £10. All you have to do is change the amount that comes at the end of the text code. e.g. SHEZ92 £10)

Many thanks!

Shehzad
title: Cycling 70 miles - from Newbury to Olympic Park, London
Name: Cycling 70 miles - from Newbury to Olympic Park, London
